rdf:Description.dc:title: Rubbing of an inscription, Aberdeen.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
St. Machar's Cathedral (Aberdeen, Scotland)
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

There is no title attached to this sheet to clarify its provenance and context. It is among other drawings from Aberdeen in the Hutton Collection. It is most probably from St Machar’s Cathedral, as there is a sizeable body of copied inscriptions from the site held in the collection. The watermark in the paper dates it from 1809 onwards. Hutton was intent on collecting as full a record as possible of Scotland’s ecclesiastical monuments. As a result, there are many types of records held in the Hutton Drawings – including plans, elevations, engravings and sketches. There are also pages of handwritten notes. Rubbings come from monuments at other sites, although many of them are largely illegible. It is now difficult to understand their purpose but they were probably for a specific purpose at the time..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Inscription, relating to Henry de Lichton, Bishop of Aberdeen and his nephew Alexander de Rynd of Broxismoche, from St Machar’s Cathedral, Aberdeen.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Forbes, John, of Boynlie
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This is a transcript of an inscription from St Machar’s Cathedral, Aberdeen. There is no particular title attached to it but the note along the bottom reveals the sheet’s context. John Forbes of Boynlie made the transcript, and the inscription refers to Henry de Lichton, Bishop of Aberdeen and his nephew Alexander de Rynd of Broxismoche. There is no date attached to this drawing. There are a further twelve drawings of St Machar’s Cathedral included in the Hutton Drawings. St Machar’s Cathedral dates from 1131, and is on a site, which has been in Christian religious use since 580. St Machar was a disciple of Columba, who arrived in Iona during the seventh century, hence the connections between the early site and the dedication of the church. Most of the remains probably date from the fifteenth century onwards, this inscription included..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Home Castle, Berwickshire, S.E. View, 1789.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This sketch, of Hume Castle, Berwickshire, would probably have been completed just after preservation work on the structure had been completed in 1789. Hume Castle is the original seat of the Home family, with their lands here being granted to William Hume before 1214. A beacon station against English border raids, the plan of the castle is a simple rectangle courtyard. This is one of the earliest Scottish castle layouts. It also has a motte, or fabricated hill, that it stands on. It was bought over in 1770 by Lord Marchmont, also of the Home family, who then carried out vital preservation work - ensuring its survival to the present day..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Dryburgh Abbey.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Buchan, David Stewart Erskine, Earl of, 1742-1829
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This engraving of Dyburgh Abbey, Berwickshire, signed 'Ensign Erskine', was probably by David Stewart Erskine, 11th Earl of Buchan, a friend of George Henry Hutton, and fellow antiquary, who acquired the remains of the abbey in 1786. This is one of four views of Dryburgh Abbey in the Hutton Collection. Hugh de Moreville founded Dryburgh Abbey, near St Boswell’s in Berwickshire, in 1150 for the Premonstratensian Order of White Canons. Much of the abbey complex has been in ruins since the sixteenth century, and the site has a tranquil and deeply romantic atmosphere that Erskine has captured in this engraving. The Abbey held a special place in the heart of Sir Walter Scott and his and his wife's bodies are there..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Monumental rubbing, Aberdeen.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

There is no title attached to this sheet to clarify its provenance and context. The watermark in the paper reads 1809, implying that the rubbing was completed sometime in or after this year. It is amongst other drawings from Aberdeen in the Hutton Collection. It is most probably from St Machar’s Cathedral, as there is a sizeable body of copied inscriptions from the site held in the collection. There are three of these unidentified rubbings in the Hutton Drawings. They all depicted Latin script in this rolling and round style but none of them actually contain a full word. None of the rubbings has any sort of title and they have no obvious link to any other records in the Collection. This is very unusual for this Collection, as Hutton appears to have quite meticulously recorded provenance information about each sheet..

rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

Description of heraldry in Inverkeithing Parish Church, Fife - page 2 of 2. This is the second of a two-page set of notes regarding the armorial font in Inverkeithing Parish Church. There is no date or author's name carried on the first page, and there is none given here. The pages, however, were found between two engravings of the church's armorial font, which were made in 1811. There has been a community of Christian worshippers on this site since the 400s when St Erat and his followers visited this area. The tower and the fine armorial font are now the only remnants of the early stone church built here around 1120. Both of these have been incorporated into the modern buildings. Other ecclesiastical buildings in the near vicinity include the Franciscan house formally established in 1384..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Description of heraldry in Inverkeithing Parish Church, Fife.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

Description of heraldry in Inverkeithing Parish Church, Fife - page 1 of 2. There is no title, heading or dates written on this sheet, suggesting that it is simply personal notes, captured to aid memory recall and not intended for general consumption. This is page one of two, although the second page is a continuation of the first. The notes were found between two sheets that hold engravings of the armorial font in Inverkeithing Parish Church. This suggests that the notes were made around 1811. The most impressive armorial remains to be found in St Peter's Kirk or Inverkeithing Parish Church are those on the font. The font was part of the pre-Reformation church and is one of the oldest remains. It was found in 1806 when other restoration work was being carried out on the church. Armorial information can often help piece historical information together, with its inherent social record of important members of the aristocracy..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Dunfermline Abbey and Monastery, Fife.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Fernie, John, active 1812
Morton, Alexander, of Dunfermline, active 1813-1817
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This monochrome plan, of Dunfermline Abbey and Monastery, Fife, has no title attached to it. There is an orientation compass carried in the top right corner, a key to the letters down the side of the drawings and a scale opposite it. Alexander Morton completed the plan, and John Fernie had it after 1812. There are eight views of Dunfermline Abbey and Monastery contained in the Hutton Collection, two of which are building plans. The other plan shows how the abbey looked before its tower collapsed in the storms of 1809. Alexander Morton, the draughtsman, completed many of the Fife plans found in the Hutton Collection. Despite this, we know little about the man or his career..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Plan and section of the abbey Church of Dunfermline, as it was prior to the 19th August 1809, when part of the tower fell down.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

The section of the church appears above the plan with the scale along the bottom. The plans show a standard cruciform church, split into three aisles, the outside two of which have lowered roofs. In 1809, lightning struck the Abbey tower and it collapsed. When the work finished, in 1818, the towers at the west of the church no longer matched - one being square and the other round. The opportunity was there to add a new parish church to the east end of the building. The tomb and body of Robert the Bruce resurfaced during the work..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Celtic standing stone at Dogton, Fife.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This untitled drawing, made in 1785 and one of a pair in the Hutton Collection, depicts an ancient standing stone, which stands to the south of Dogton Farm by Kinglassie, in Fife. While this basic sketch does not show it, the stone would originally have been in the shape of a Celtic cross. The name of the artist is not given; it is likely that it was Hutton himself. If the local myths are true, then this sculptured standing stone at Dogton is there to mark the progress made by the marauding Danes during the ninth century. Sadly, this drawing does not do justice to the fine Celtic ornaments that appear on the stone. The stone is nearly 5 feet high, and goes by the name, the 'Dogton Stone'..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Grand plot of the Collegiate Kirk of Crail.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Bell, Andrew
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

Andrew Bell made this plan of the St Mary’s Collegiate Church in Crail in 1796. The church's rooms and main areas appear along with their exact measurements, while a scale and compass is included at the foot of the drawing. Although this large aisled church dates from 1243, it did not achieve collegiate status until 1517, when William Myrton was in charge of the architectural alterations that took place that year. Dedicated to the memory of the Irish saint, St Maelrubha, the church received further alterations in later centuries. The south entrance to the church is embellished with a Pictish cross slab, thus highlighting the church's origins..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Plan of Pittenweem Priory, Fife.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Morton, Alexander, of Dunfermline, active 1813-1817
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This plan of Pittenweem Priory in the East Neuk of Fife was made by Alexander Morton in 1813. The eight numbers included on the plan correspond with the numbered list on the right side of the drawing, and indicate the rooms and main areas of the building. The main door to the priory faces east out on to the Firth of Forth (number eight on the plan), with the top of the drawing being the direction of north. Pittenweem Priory was established in the twelfth century, when the Augustinian monks from the nearby Isle of May decided to construct a new building on the mainland, as it offered better protection from pirates. There is a cave between the priory and the sea, and legend has it that St Fillan, a disciple of St Columba, lived in this cave during the seventh century. The monks cut a staircase from the priory's garden to this cave. As with so many church buildings in Scotland, the priory at Pittenweem suffered extensive damage during the Reformation..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Ruins of the Cathedral of St Andrews.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Morton, Alexander, of Dunfermline, active 1813-1817
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

Alexander Morton made this plan of St Andrews Cathedral, Fife, in 1813. The plan employs the usual technical drawing conventions. On the right side of the plan is a list of the buildings and important areas that exist within the cathedral's perimeter wall. Roman numerals indicate these buildings and areas on the plan. The origins of the cathedral date back to AD 732, when Bishop Acca supposedly brought the relics (bones) of St Andrew to the settlement. Work started on the cathedral in 1160 and finished in 1318. They consecrated it that same year in the presence of Robert the Bruce. The cathedral did not have good luck, however, and a mixture of stormy weather, invading English armies, the dawning of the Reformation and John Knox’s fiery sermons, combined to leave the long-suffering building in ruins..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Watercolour drawing of Dunfermline Abbey, Fife.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

The title of this watercolour drawing reads, 'Dunfermline Abbey, Fifeshire No 117'. There is no date or artist's name. Drawn from a distance, it shows the abbey towering above surrounding treetops. Queen Margaret - wife of King Malcolm III - founded Dunfermline Abbey around 1070, on the site of a much earlier Celtic church. Established as a Benedictine monastery dedicated to the Holy Trinity, Margaret's son, David I, eventually extended and elevated the Priory to Abbey status in the early-twelfth century. Margaret and Malcolm's bodies lie in the Abbey and, almost 160 years after her death, Margaret became a saint..

rdf:Description.dc:title: View of St Rule's Tower & the west end of the Cathedral of St Andrews, Fifeshire.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Morton, Alexander, of Dunfermline, active 1813-1817
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This painting, a watercolour of St Andrews Castle, Fife, possibly by Alexander Morton, shows the ruins of the Castle, with the remnants of the west end of the Cathedral and St Regulus' or Rule's Tower in the background. Although no date is included, Morton probably painted it in 1813. St Andrews Castle dates back to the twelfth century, and was the main residence and administrative centre for the bishops and archbishops of St Andrews. As the ruins suggest, the castle has a stormy history and was destroyed and rebuilt on several occasions during the Middle Ages. The castle is strongly associated with Cardinal David Beaton, who met his death, thrown from one of the castle's towers by a group of local landowners, in revenge for the public burning of the Protestant preacher, George Wishart..

rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

Watercolour of the Holy Trinity Church, St Andrews, Fife, numbered 109. This painting shows the Holy Trinity Church, which is located in the centre of St Andrews. The painting is undated. The origins of the Holy Trinity Church go back as far as 1163. The present building dates from 1412. John Knox preached in a fiery manner at this church during the Reformation, and incited a congregational mob to destroy the Cathedral in 1559. The church underwent a major renovation in 1800, which affected its original 1412 design. Another renovation reversed this in 1909..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Old Abbey of Lindores, or Lindoris.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Morton, Alexander, of Dunfermline, active 1813-1817
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This undated plan of Lindores Abbey was made by Alexander Morton, who drew many plans of Scottish church buildings in the early 1800s. A numbered index list appears in the top left corner of the drawing, with the numbers referring to the rooms and areas that form the abbey. The symbol of a compass in the top right of the drawing indicates the direction in which the abbey is facing. Lindores Abbey, located on the southern banks of the River Tay, was founded some time at the end of the twelfth century, by David, Earl of Huntingdon, brother of King William I. The first people to inhabit the abbey were Benedictine monks belonging to the Order of Tiron. These monks were led by Abbot Guido, who had previously been the priory at Kelso Abbey. Another victim of the Scottish Reformation, the abbey was finally destroyed by Reformers in 1559..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Plan of the Monastery of Inch Colm, N: Britain, 1822.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This coloured plan, of Inchcolm Priory, Inchcolm Island, Firth of Forth, includes a scale and compass, a key to the red lines used on the plan and useful notes regarding the monastery. Along the bottom of the plan, elevations of different parts of the building have been included along with an alphabetical listing that corresponds with the plan. Incholm Priory was founded in the early-twelfth century by King Alexander I, and dedicated to St Columba. Alexander is purported to have sought shelter with a small group of hermits on the island when his boat ran into trouble. In response to their hospitality, he ordered the construction of a priory. Built by Augustinian monks, it was elevated to the status of an abbey in the mid-thirteenth century. After suffering extensive damage during an English invasion in the fourteenth century, the abbey was largely restored during the 1400s..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Sketch of a Celtic standing stone at Dogton, Fife.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This drawing, made in 1785 and one of a pair in the Hutton Collection, shows an ancient standing stone, which is located in a field to the south of Dogton Farm by Kinglassie, in Fife. Although this drawing does not show it, the stone would originally have been in the shape of a cross. The artist is not named but was, perhaps, Hutton himself.. According to local legend, the sculptured standing stone at Dogton marks the inroads made by the invading Danes during the ninth century. Although this Celtic stone is highly ornamental, this drawing does not show up the many the symbols and decorations that appear on it..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Plans and elevations of St Salvator's Chapel, St Andrews, and of St Monans Church, Fife.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Morton, Alexander, of Dunfermline, active 1813-1817
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This image shows plan and side elevation technical drawings of St Salvator's Chapel in St Andrews, and the church of St Monans. A list of the areas of each church appears in a content section in the middle of the drawing, with accompanying numbers for identification purposes. Alexander Morton made this drawing around 1813. Also known as the Old College, St Salvator's Chapel and Tower lies at the heart of the medieval St Andrews, and was founded in 1450 by Bishop James Kennedy as the College of the Holy Saviour. Protestant reformers damaged it during the Reformation, and it was rebuilt from 1680 onwards. St Monans Church dates back to the thirteenth century. King David II ordered the church built, after surviving a terrible storm in the River Forth. English soldiers burnt it down in 1544, but the town rebuilt it in 1646. Unusually, an eighteenth century ship hangs from the church's ceiling..

This drawing, of Dunfermline Abbey, Fife, shows the exterior of the Abbey in some detail. It is one of several in the Hutton Collection. It is undated and unsigned. Although there is no date attached to this drawing, it most likely dates from the late-eighteenth or early-nineteenth century. As considerable work was undertaken between 1818 and 1821, with the construction of the new abbey church to replace the ruined east-end of the old church, this drawing offers a view of the abbey before these dramatic changes were undertaken..

Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

There are no details attached to drawing of Dunfermline Abbey, although it is one of eight views of the Abbey and its ruined monastery. This, the east end, now houses Dunfermline Parish Church and is a flourishing community focal point. A member of the Scottish Culdee Church married Malcolm Canmore and Margaret Aethling in Dunfermline in about 1070. It was about two years after this that Queen Margaret, of Anglo-Saxon descent and of Roman-Catholic persuasion, invited the Benedictine Order to establish a house there. This also led to the demise of the Celtic-Culdee faith in the area. The original church and monastery were smaller and of wattle and daub..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Gravemarker from Inverkeithing Parish Church, Fife.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

There is no title or date attached to this drawing of a tombstone, but it probably dates from 1814. There are four other images of Inverkeithing Parish Church or St Peter's Kirk in the Hutton Collection. None of them portrays the outside of the building, which would have been relatively modern, highlighting the important features of the site. There are many images of carved gravestones and markers amongst the Hutton Collection and their origins spread across Scotland. This unique and accessible record then makes it easy to trace and research the development of monument symbolism, fashion and importance. They range from flat slabs in the tenth century, to ornate niches in the seventeenth and then this simple upright cross in the eighteenth..

rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Morton, Alexander, of Dunfermline, active 1813-1817
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

Alexander Morton made this drawing of Balmerino Abbey in 1813. It complements a plan drawing that Morton made of the abbey that same year. The Abbey stands on the south bank of the River Tay, near Newport-on-Tay. Lady Ermengarde, the second wife and widowed queen of William the Lyon, founded Balmerino Abbey in 1229. It was set up for an order of Cistercian monks. The Reformation destroyed the Abbey. The abbey boasts magnificent views over and along the River Tay, while a Spanish Chestnut tree in the abbey's grounds is one of the oldest of its type in Scotland..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Lindores Abbey, Newburgh, Fife.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

Made in July 1790, this fine drawing, based on a sketch made by Thomas Cocking, shows the ruined walls of Lindores Abbey. A note in the bottom left corner of the page attributes the original source for the drawing. The name of the artist is not included. Situated on the southern banks of the River Tay, Lindores Abbey was founded by David, Earl of Huntingdon, brother of King William I, near the end of the twelfth century. Benedictine monks from the Order of Tiron were the first cleric to inhabit the abbey. Abbot Lawrence, a noted theologian and one of the founders of St Andrews University, was probably the most famous leader of the abbey. As with so many church buildings in Scotland, the abbey was destroyed by mobs during the Reformation period..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Loch Leven Castle, 1783.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This drawing shows the Kinross shoreline of Loch Leven in Fife, with the outline of Loch Leven Castle just visible on the very far left of the picture. The name of the island in the distance is Castle Island. Dating back to the thirteenth century, this castle is most famous for being the place where Mary Queen of Scots was imprisoned in June 1567. The Castle was gifted to the Douglas family by King Robert II in 1372. Sir William Douglas was Mary's gaoler during her imprisonment, although his younger son, Willie Douglas, helped Mary to escape in 1568, principally because he was besotted with the young queen. The Castle was bought from the impoverished Douglas family by Sir William Bruce in 1764. Since the eighteenth century, it has been a ruin..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Castle of Loch Leven, July 23, 1781.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This drawing shows the ruins of Loch Leven Castle in Fife. It is now known who made this drawing. The castle is located on Castle Island, which is located on the western edge of the loch, near the town of Kinross. Loch Leven Castle was probably built sometime in the thirteenth century. The castle is strongly associated with the Douglas family, who received it as a gift from King Robert II of Scotland in 1372. Mary, Queen of Scots was imprisoned there in 1567 during the Reformation period, although she escaped the following year with the help of her gaoler's son, Willie Douglas. Sir William Bruce bought Loch Leven Castle from the impoverished Douglas family in 1764..

This drawing of Loch Leven Castle was made by Miss Alicia Jones (later Mrs Duke Crofton of Lakefield, Co. Leitrim, Ireland) in 1807. A note at the foot of the drawing states the artist's name and that she was from 'Belleville near Athlone'. Loch Leven Castle is probably most famous as being the location where Mary, Queen of Scots was imprisoned in June 1567, during the Scottish Reformation. Dating back to the thirteenth century, King Robert II of Scotland granted the castle to the Douglas family in 1372. Indeed, Willie Douglas helped the young queen escape in 1568, even though his father was Mary's gaoler. Sir William Bruce purchased the castle from the impoverished Douglas family in 1764..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Muness Castle in Shetland, 1792.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Columbine, Edward Henry, 1762-1811
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

Drawing and description of Muness Castle, Shetland. The information under the title goes on to compare this castle to Scalloway Castle, also on Shetland and gives a brief description of the building. The original was completed by Edward H. Columbine in 1792 and this copy was made for Hutton in 1802. Edward Columbine is known to have worked for the Office of the Admiralty, mainly as a hydrographer and captain. The records of his career, however, are patchy. He made three drawings on Shetland in 1792 and left descriptions with them, implying he had some time to spend at the sites. These sheets then, although recording important monuments themselves, also help to fill the gaps in his career! The note correcting the name to 'Buness' is incorrect..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Chart of Whithorn shoreline, Galloway.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

There is an orientation arrow in the top left corner of this chart, while the right-hand side of the sheet carries an explanation of the shorthand used. It was drawn up in 1780 and delineates areas belonging to the Burgh. Places of local and Christian importance have also been plotted. The Christian site at Whithorn was founded in 397 by St Ninian and was the first Christian settlement to be built north of Hadrian’s wall. The name is thought to derive from the Pictish translation of ‘white house’ or ‘Hwit Aerne’. Ninian’s church was painted white and so earned the Latin name ‘Candida Casa’ or ‘white house’. Ninian originally from Galloway is known to have visited Rome and is thought to have been close friends with St Martin of Tours. Whithorn is one of the most important early-European Christian sites..

Hutton, George Henry, -1827

"the first founder of the Trinity Friers at Aberdeen, where he had his chappell the chief place of retirement for his devotions. He reigned 49 years, beginning 1165. Dyed at Striviling 1214 & was buried at Aberbrothick." A note at the bottom of this portrait of William I reads, 'From the original (in the Trinity Hall, Aberdeen) by R. Munro (artist, Aberdeen, July 1821)'. The King is an older man in this picture. A letter from Hutton to John Dillon, who was the secretary of the Society of Antiquaries of Scotland, accompanies this Munro painting: it would appear there was some doubt over the authenticity of the original. This has still not been resolved and is the subject of continuing debate..

This sketch was created in 1811, although there is no artist’s name attached to the piece. The fragment is part of a tombstone, dating from 1478, which marked the grave of a deceased Dominican friar. There are many images depicting Scottish gravemarkers held in the Hutton Drawings. They were collected from all over Scotland and cover a very wide time period. Together they form a comprehensive record of Scottish burial traditions and fashions. This tombstone is interesting because it holds its information in Latin script rather than pictorial symbols..

There is no title attached to this sheet to clarify its provenance and context. The watermark in the paper reads 1809, implying that the rubbing was completed sometime in or after this year. It can be found amongst other drawings from Aberdeen and is most probably taken from St Machar’s Cathedral as there are fifteen views of the complex, some of which are transcriptions and inscriptions. This rubbing is only one of many held across the whole of the Hutton Drawings. Like the others, it does not contain a complete word suggesting that it was created for analysis of the lettering and carving style..

rdf:Description.dc:title: View of the encampment, 1782.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Buccleuch, Henry Scott, Duke of, 1746-1812
Wales, James, 1746 or 7-1795
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

The dedication on this print explains that it is a drawing of a military encampment, by James Wales, and dedicated to the Henry Scott, 3rd Duke of Buccleuch. It is dated 1782 and is thought to be an incomplete picture. It has been suggested as a result that it is a proof run of the eventual final print. No further information is given either on the sheet or in the Hutton Drawings to explain its purpose in the collection or how it found a home there. The Dukes of Buccleuch and their families were always a formidable political force in Scotland’s power machinations but they are perhaps better remembered as military leaders and organisers. The Duke’s regularly issued broadsides in and around the Edinburgh area, especially, advertising the King’s coin, and the adventures which could be found as a regular soldier..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Transcript mentioning St Christopher.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

There are many fragments of transcriptions or rubbings held amongst the Hutton Drawings. Most of them, however, at least have their original location recorded with them. This example has no provenance attached to it and it is not clear from its location in the collection. On the other hand it is the most complete transcription held in the Drawings. St Christopher is thought to have been a been a Roman soldier who was martyred for his faith sometime in the third century in Syria. Despite these relatively humble origins the mediaeval West built up a fantastical myth. The legendary giant, Christopher, is thought to have carried Christ on his shoulder across the river – a totally unsubstantiated fabrication. Nevertheless the story has a popular moral appeal and has, and still does, enjoy great popularity..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Crowned head on back of a charter, 1322, in College of Glasgow.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

The note along the bottom of this sketch reads, ‘Copy of sketch of crowned head on back of a charter, 1322, in College of Glasgow’. There are no artist’s names attached or copy dates, just the original. This sketch is to be found with other ‘miscellaneous’ drawings at the end of the Hutton Drawings and as such no further information about the sheet can be guessed at. Robert the Bruce was King of Scotland at this time, reigning from 1306 to 1329. However, from the style of the crown, it is more likely that this drawing, or doodle, is meant to represent Edward II, King of England from 1307 to 1327. (1322 was the date of Edward's last invasion of Scotland.) There are many representations of mediaeval art and stylised figures to be found in the Hutton Drawings and this is one of the helpful aspects of the collection. The lack of context to this drawing makes it difficult to interpret and therefore more difficult for researchers to use..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Loch Leven Priory (south-east view) October 16, 1789, with a distant view of the castle.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This drawing shows the ruins of the priory on St Serf's Island in Loch Leven, Fife. A note below the drawing reads, 'The roof fell 1788'. Loch Leven Castle is located on Castle Island, north-east of St Serf's Island. Although St Serfs Island, also known as the Inch, was inhabited by Culdee monks as long as 800 years ago, the ninth century priory was built by monks from St Andrews. Up until the Reformation, the priory was occupied by priors of the Augustinian Order, who had quite a reputation for their literary output. The 'Oryginale Cronykil of Scotland', written by Prior Andrew Wyntoun at the beginning of the fifteenth century, is one such example of the order's erudite endeavours. A ruined chapel is the only remainder of the priory, while the island now forms part of the Loch Leven Nature Reserve..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Loch Orr or Lochore Castle, Fife.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Grose, Francis, 1731?-1791
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This sketch shows the castle at Loch Orr, which is nowadays known as Lochore or Loch Ore Castle. A note at the foot of the drawing reads, 'Castle of Loch Orr, Fifeshire 1781'. This drawing was reproduced in France Grose's book, 'The Antiquities of Scotland', published in 1791. The name of the artist is not given, but it is likely that it was Hutton himself. Also known as, Inchgall Castle, Lochore Castle was built during the 1400s, and located near Ballingry in Fife. The castle is famously associated with the Wardlaw family, who gained control of the building following the marriage of Andrew Wardlaw of Torry sometime during the fifteenth century. Lochore Castle remained a possession of the Wardlaw family until the beginning of the seventeenth century..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Part of Lindores Abbey, Newburgh, Fife.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This drawing, made in July 1784, shows part of the ruins of Lindores Abbey. The drawing's title, included at the bottom of the page, reads, 'Part of Lindores Abbey 1784'. The name of the artist has not been included, although it is quite likely to have been Hutton himself. David, Earl of Huntingdon established Lindores Abbey in 1191. It is located by the town of Newburgh, on the northern banks of the River Tay. A Tironesian Abbey inhabited by Benedictine monks, it was dedicated to St Mary, St Andrew and All Saints. As with so many church buildings, Lindores Abbey was destroyed by Reformers during the Scottish Reformation..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Pittenweem Priory, Fife.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Grose, Francis, 1731?-1791
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This drawing of the priory at Pittenweem was made in 1783, and appeared in volume I of Captain Francis Grose's book, 'The Antiquities of Scotland', which was published in 1791. The artist, probably Hutton himself, was looking at the ruins of the priory from the north, with the River Forth - complete with ships -shown in the left side of the drawing. The Priory is located in the East Neuk of Fife, at the mouth of the River Forth. Pittenweem Priory has its origins in the ancient religious settlements that previously existed on the nearby Isle of May. In their desire to find a safer location for their community, the Augustinian monks from the island decided to construct a new building on the mainland, sometime during the twelfth century. The famous cave that lies among the cliffs below the priory is rumoured to have been the home of St Fillan, who was a disciple of St Columba. The Priory suffered extensive damage during the Reformation period..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Roch Abbey in Yorkshire.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Barrett, George, active 1785-1798
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

The title and note along the bottom of this drawing reads, 'Roch Abbey in Yorkshire etched by Barrett'. This drawing is unique in the Hutton collection as it is depicting a building in England. There is no further information about the artist. It is difficult to say which part of the Abbey the drawing is depicting. It does not seem to be the church as the transepts of the church remain almost to their full height although many of the other buildings now survive only as low standing walls. Set in the deep enchanting valley and contained within the natural boundaries of magnesium limestone cliffs, Roch Abbey is a magnificent example of the French-influenced early Gothic architecture. The Abbey was founded in 1147 and it is known that there were 14 monks and 4 novices at the monastery at the time of the Dissolution in 1538 after which the buildings were plundered by local people..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Rosyth Castle, Fife, where Oliver Cromwell's mother was born.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Grose, Francis, 1731?-1791
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This drawing shows Rosyth Castle in Fife, which is located in the town's navy dockyards by the River Forth. The anonymous drawing of the castle was made in 1784, and appeared in volume I of Captain Francis Grose's book, 'The Antiquities of Scotland', which was published in 1791. Rosyth Castle was built sometime during the thirteenth century, and is closely associated with two of Scotland's most famous families, the Stewarts and the Wardlaws. As the drawing's title indicates, Rosyth Castle is most famous as being the birthplace of Elizabeth Cromwell, the mother of Oliver, in or around 1564..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Abbey of Inchcolm - West View.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This picture is one of two views of the ruins, of Inchcolm Abbey, on the island. The other one is dated 1784 but there is no artist attached to either. The building at the front centre of the image houses the dormitories on the second floor and storage rooms underneath. The cloisters were directly behind this building. Alexander I invited the Augustinian canons onto the island in 1123, when the hermits sheltered him there after a shipwreck. The island, however, has a much older ecclesiastical history, and is known as the Iona of the east. As the island's name implies it has associations with St Columba. In the intervening years, many members of Danish descent were buried here..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Scalloway Castle in Shetland.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Columbine, Edward Henry, 1762-1811
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This drawing reads, ‘From a sketch made by Captain Columbine 1792’. This copy is thought to have been made in 1802, at Hutton’s request. It is one of two records of Scalloway, the other being a written description left by Columbine. The Castle was built in 1600 by Patrick Stewart, who was the grandson of James V. His father, Robert Stewart was the natural son of James, who granted his illegitimate son the earldom of Orkney along with lands on Shetland. Unlike many of the buildings on Shetland which tended to reflect the very mixed cultural inheritance of the island, this building is a traditional lowland ‘z’ shaped tower house..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Old College at St Andrews.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Cordiner, James, 1786-1849
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This undated drawing shows the late Gothic architecture of St Salvator's Chapel and Tower (also known as the Old College), in the centre of St Andrews. The drawing is from a sketch by the Rev J. Cordiner'. The St Salvator quadrangle is located immediately beside the Old College. Founded in 1450 by Bishop James Kennedy as the College of the Holy Saviour, St Salvator's Chapel and Tower is the medieval lynchpin of St Andrews. Protestant reformers damaged the Chapel during the Reformation, and it underwent a major rebuilding programme from 1680 onwards. The quadrangle area beside St Salvator's is highly popular with the university's students..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Abbey at Lindores, Newburgh, Fife.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This drawing, made in July 1790, depicts the ruins of Lindores Abbey. A note at the bottom of the page reads, 'Lindores Abbey Perthshire July 17 - 1790'. It is not known who made this drawing. Although the artist writes that the location is 'Perthshire', Newburgh is now regarded as part of Fife. Located near Newburgh on the southern banks of the River Tay, Lindores Abbey was established in 1191 by David, Earl of Huntingdon. It was a Tironesian Abbey, and was dedicated to St Mary, St Andrew and All Saints. During the Scottish Reformation, it was attacked by mobs in 1543 and 1559, which destroyed it. Only a few fragments of the church and the bell-tower now remain..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Vaults in Dumferling [Dunfermline] Abbey, Fifeshire, No. 120.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Grose, Francis, 1731?-1791
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This sketch is associated with Captain Francis Grose's 'Antiquities of Scotland', published in 1791. Barrel vaulting was a fabulous medieval discovery. Improved weight distribution and wider vault spaces resulted in changes in architecture and lifestyles. David I, King of Scotland, as a tribute to his mother's piety, personality and achievements decided to replace Margaret's tiny original chapel with a grand new church, and in 1150, he granted the Priory abbey status. Margaret, the founder and patron of Dunfermline Abbey, was canonised in 1250 and her relics moved to a new shrine in 1259. This event not only involved further new building projects at the abbey but also increased the site's prestige as a pilgrimage centre..

Drawing of the monastery ruins, Dunfermline Abbey, Fife. There are no dates or artists attached to this sheet. This image shows the south wall of the Benedictine monastery, the room behind which was the refectory. English troops sacked the Abbey during the War of Independence in 1303. Robert the Bruce rebuilt it once peace came. These buildings all date from this time. Post-Reformation, the abbey and its possessions became the property of the Crown, the process taking until 1593. This area in particular became the Royal Palace..

rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This damaged drawing shows the ruins of Balmerino Abbey, which is located on the south bank of the River Tay, opposite the western edge of Dundee. The drawing is entitled 'Part of Balmerino [missing text]', and dates from around 1781. It is one of several drawings of the Abbey in the Hutton Collection. This drawing appeared in volume I of Captain Francis Grose's book, 'The Antiquities of Scotland', which was published in 1791. The human figures included in this drawing provide the viewer with a sense of proportion regarding the ruined abbey's size. Lady Ermengarde, the widow of William the Lyon, founded Balmerino Abbey in 1229 for a group of Cistercian monks. The Abbey was dedicated to the memory of the Blessed Virgin and Lady Ermengarde's relative, King Edward the Confessor. The Abbey was a victim of the widespread destruction of Scottish churches that took place during the Reformation period..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Abbey of Inchcolm, N.E. View, 1782.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This is a drawing of the ruins of Inchcolm Abbey on Inchcolm Island in the Firth of Forth. Much of what you see is still extant today. The buildings immediately visible in the centre of the image are the ruins of the sacristy and directly behind it to the left is the still-complete chapter house. The ruins at Inchcolm are the best-preserved medieval male monastic ruins in Britain. David I founded the buildings on Inchcolm, many of which, the tower included, are still intact, in 1223. One of David's policies was to regularise and officially endorse many of Scotland's ecclesiastical establishments, and he was heavily involved in issuing foundation charters. Despite this, the community of Augustinian canons had been living on the island since their invitation in 1123 by Alexander I..

rdf:Description.dc:creator: Paterson, W., artist
Mitchell, E.
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This engraving is by E. Mitchell from a drawing by W. Paterson, and is one of two such engravings in the Hutton Collection. Mounted on a decorative pedestal, the font includes stone carvings of several coats of arms held in place by angels. There is no date attached. In this instance, the church being referred to is probably St Peter's Kirk, which dates from the early-twelfth century and is located on Church Street in the centre of Inverkeithing. The armorial font, seen here, and the church tower are all that remain of the original pre-Reformation parish church. According to Groome (1894), the sculpted font was one of the finest in Scotland. He also noted that it was 'disinterred from the rubbish in 1806 in making foundations for repairs on the church'..

Hutton, George Henry, -1827

There are no details attached to this engraving of Culross Abbey and town, Fife. The Abbey tower dominates the skyline and the whole building stands at the top of the hill overlooking the town. Culross was founded as a Cistercian house in 1218, by Malcolm the Earl of Fife. Although once very prosperous it had fallen into decay by the time, the east choir was restructured to house the parish church. The town itself enjoyed a flourishing economy based on trade, coal and salt panning. This too, however, was on the wan by the middle of the nineteenth century..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Abby church of Culross.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

There are no details given on this engraving of Culross Abbey, Fife. The drawing was completed standing in the north, looking to the north-east, which is a relatively unusual view. There are a further two images of Culross in amongst the Hutton Collection which together give a rounded impression of the abbey and town. Culross Abbey was founded in 1218 by Malcolm, 7th Earl of Fife. It established itself as a small Cistercian monastery, which is probably best-remembered as the birthplace and school of St Kentigern. The area also has associations with St Serf. At its height, the abbey had a first class reputation for its scriptorium and the binding and illuminations it produced, as well as for its gardens..

This engraving is by E. Mitchell from a drawing by W. Paterson. It is one of two such engravings in the Hutton Collection. The font is highly decorative and includes stone carvings of coats of arms held in place by angels. There is no date attached. In this instance, the church of Inverkeithing is probably St Peter's Kirk, which dates from the early-twelfth century. The armorial font, seen here, and the church tower are all that remain of the original pre-Reformation parish church. Prior to this, the site was purportedly the location of a church founded in the fifth century by a follower of St Ninian..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Notes on Scalloway Castle, Shetland.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Columbine, Edward Henry, 1762-1811
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This only one page from a series, which together would have constituted a letter between Edward H. Columbine and Hutton. The other pages are now, unfortunately missing. The original description was thought to have been written in 1792 and this copy was made in 1802. Here Columbine talks about the style and condition of houses on Shetland in general and then goes on to talk about the castle specifically. Columbine was not known for his written descriptions and so this page is relatively unusual. Columbine mainly worked for the Office of the Admiralty as a hydrographer and a substantial amount of his work was completed around the coast of Scotland. Virtually simultaneously he was producing sketches of interesting monuments and the profiles of interesting pieces of coastline. Hutton then had substantial amounts of his worked copied so that he could add it to his collection..

rdf:Description.dc:creator: Thurot, François, 1727-1760

Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.
Date of event depicted: between 1756 and 1763

This is a panoramic view of St Andrews, Fife, 'from an etching by Mr Clark'. You can see both the distinctive church spires and its exposed position. The French frigate the Belle Isle was on a mission round the British coast. Francois Thurot of Boulogne engineered and commanded the expedition. The ship was to harass the British coastline, this act being an initiation of war. This incident was a relatively minor affair compared to the havoc that Thurot wreaked on the Western Isles, Ireland and the Isle of Man, later in 1759..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Remains of the ancient building on the Isle of May.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Stevenson, Robert, 1772-1850
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This is a plan and elevation of ancient ecclesiastical buildings on the Isle of May, Firth of Forth, made by Robert Stevenson in or around 1818. The top part of the page contains the elevation drawing, while the lower part contains the plan of the building. Robert Stevenson was a relative of the writer, Robert Louis Stevenson. The Isle of May is located at the entrance to the River Forth, just off the East Neuk coast of Fife. One of Scotland's most important archaeological sites, excavations suggest that there was a Christian community on the Isle of May as early as the seventh century. Certainly, it is known that a Benedictine church existed on the island from 1145 onwards. During the fourteenth and fifteenth centuries, this church was a popular place with pilgrims. It is likely that the first religious settlers on the island were Irish and Pictish clerics who had trained at Iona, and who were chosen to visit the Fife area to convert the people there to Christianity..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Old Abbey of Balmerino.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Morton, Alexander, of Dunfermline, active 1813-1817
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

Plan of Balmerino Abbey, Fife made by Alexander Morton in 1813. A numbered list of the abbey's rooms and areas is included on the right side of the drawing, together with a compass. The artist's signature is included at the foot of the drawing. Balmerino Abbey is located on the south bank of the River Tay, opposite the city of Dundee. Founded in 1229 by Lady Ermengarde, second wife and widow of William the Lyon, Balmerino Abbey is a Cistercian Abbey. Sadly, as with so many of Scotland's church buildings, the Reformation destroyed Balmerino Abbey. Mary, Queen of Scots visited the abbey in 1565 during the Reformation era, probably staying in the Abbot's House as a guest of Sir John Hay, the first Lay Commendator of the abbey..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Sketch of Dunfermline Abbey, Fife.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This rough sketch shows the exterior of Dunfermline Abbey viewed from the side. Another drawing in the Hutton Collection shows the abbey from the same angle in much more detail. It is possible they are both by the same artist and that this example was merely a preliminary sketch. There is no date or artist's name. Founded around 1070 by Queen Margaret as a house for Benedictine monks, and elevated to the status of an abbey by her son David I in the early-twelfth century, Dunfermline Abbey soon became an important ecclesiastical centre and burial place for Scottish monarchs. Queen Margaret and her husband, King Malcolm III, were both buried in the abbey, as was their son, King David I, and perhaps most famously, the abbey was the final resting place for Robert the Bruce..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Jeddsworth from the North.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Augustinians
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

Copy of an engraving of a north view of Jedburgh Abbey, Roxburghshire. It appears to be entitled 'Jeddsworth from the North'. It is undoubtedly a view of Jedburgh Abbey, and it is unclear whether the misspelled name was George Henry Hutton's mistake, or whether the original engraving was given this title. The engraving was made by R. Godfrey and appeared in 'The Antiquarian Repertory, volume IV', by Francis Grose, in 1776. This copy, which was probably made by Hutton himself, is one of six views of Jedburgh Abbey in the Hutton Collection. Jedburgh Abbey was founded as a priory by King David I in 1138, but in 1147 was raised to abbey status and populated by a community of Augustinian or 'black' canons. It is thought that the abbey church, built to a grand Romanseque design, took the better part of a century to complete. Between the thirteenth and the sixteenth centuries the abbey was the subject of many attacks by English troops, and after the Reformation in 1560 its dwindling community of canons died out. The abbey, however, continued in use as Jedburgh's parish church until 1875, which perhaps explains how so much of the building has remained intact compared to the other great Scottish border abbeys..

rdf:Description.dc:creator: Shand, James
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This ground plan of Dornoch Cathedral was drawn up by James Shand in 1815. There is a scale and orientation compass in the top left corner of the sheet. The rest of the sheet is covered in notes made by Shand. These clarify some of the architectural details and the history of the building. Dornoch is best known in its capacity as the mediaeval administration centre of the area of Sutherland. Its prestige and power was further reinforced by the towns ecclesiastical role, the Cathedral functioning as the area’s spiritual focus. The town and its surrounding shoreline is better known today for its romantic highland atmosphere and the relaxing leisure activities it has to offer..

rdf:Description.dc:title: At Applecross.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This is a drawing of a cruciform monument, Applecross, Ross-shire. It shows a large stone slab carved with a Celtic cross. The only information provided on the sheet is the location, 'at Applecross', and various measurements. The artist's name and the date have not been included. The village of Applecross lies on a peninsula between Loch Torridon and Loch Kishorn, in Ross-shire. Until the 1970s, the only overland route into Applecross was across the 'Bealach na Ba' or 'The Pass of the Cattle'. Originally, an old drove road, it rises from sea level to just over 2,000 feet in around 5 miles and is one of the highest roads in Scotland. Despite its isolation from the rest of the country for so many centuries, Applecross was home to one of the earliest Christian settlements in Scotland; in the seventh century an Irish monk by the name of Maelrubha founded a monastery here. Although little remains of the early settlement, a few ancient relics still lie near the local church, including the Celtic cross-slab in the churchyard..

rdf:Description.dc:creator: Shand, James
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

Plan of St Duthac's Collegiate Church, Tain, Ross-shire. It was surveyed and drawn by James Shand in 1819, and shows the interior of St Duthac's Collegiate Church, Tain. Shand has included measurements and a scale, and has also provided an alphabetical list of 'Remarks' that correspond with the letters on the plan. St Duthac's Collegiate Church was built between the fourteenth and fifteenth centuries on the site of a much earlier church, part of which still remains in the churchyard today. It replaced St Duthac's Chapel as a place of pilgrimage and sanctuary after the chapel was destroyed by fire in 1427. After the fire, St Duthac's remains were transferred from the ruined chapel to the collegiate church..

rdf:Description.dc:title: St Mary's Chapel on the Shiant Isles.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Daniell, William, 1769-1837
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

Sketched ground-plan of St Mary's Chapel, Shiant Islands, Ross-shire. It is dated July 6th 1818, and was made by William Daniell, who was responsible for several works in the Hutton Collection, including a drawing of St Mary's Chapel showing its spectucular geographical setting. That drawing, and this plan, are the only two images relating to the Shiant Islands in the Hutton Collection. Hutton's plan shows that the ruined Chapel of St Mary was built to a very simple, rectangular plan. The age of the chapel is unknown, but it is believed that a priest sought sanctuary here during the period around the Reformation in 1560. The chapel sits on Eilean Mhuire, or Mary's Island, one of three habitable islands in the Shiant archipelago, which lies south-east of the Isle of Lewis. Only one of the islands, Eilean an Tighe, remains inhabited today..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Tain.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Shand, James
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This page is signed by James Shand. It contains what appear to be sketches of two views of St Duthac's Collegiate Church, Tain, Ross-shire: one an end elevation and the other an incomplete side elevation. The sketches were jotted down on the back of a printed form, and it is possible that they were merely preliminary sketches for more formal drawings made later by Shand. The Hutton Collection contains several more detailed and formal views of St Duthac's Collegiate Church by Shand. St Duthac's Collegiate Church sits on Castle Brae in the centre of Tain, on the coast of the Dornoch Firth. The building dates from 1360, although the church did not become collegiate until 1487. Unlike many collegiate or monastic institutions, St Duthac's did not suffer significant damage during the Reformation, and although some of its interior ornamentation is thought to have been stripped, a statue of St Duthac on the outside of the west wall survived. At the time these sketches were made, the church was beginning to fall into disrepair, but it was restored and re-roofed in 1877..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Fearn.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This undated ground-plan of Fearn Abbey is one of three ground-plans of this building in the Hutton Collection, and one of at least nine items relating to Fearn. The other two ground-plans in the collection are attributed to a draughtsman named James Shand, but this rougher plan does not carry the artist's name, and may have been sketched by Hutton himself. The details marked on this plan are mainly restricted to the locations of doors and windows in Fearn Abbey. Due to the lack of explanatory notes, it is difficult to know whether this is meant to represent a ground-plan of the abbey as it once might have been, or whether it is a ground plan of the building as it existed in Hutton's lifetime. The architectural history of the site has been eventful, and the abbey is known to have been rebuilt in the fourteenth and again in the eighteenth centuries, and to have undergone further restoration after the second rebuilding..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Sketch of an arch, Fearn Abbey, Ross-shire.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This rough sketch shows an arch that once formed part of a funerary monument in Fearn Abbey. The artist, possibly Hutton himself, has included a note: 'Arch in the Ruins of the abbey of Fearn, under which the Effigies of Ferquhard, Earl of Ross, the Founder, is said to have laid. The figure greatly mutilated [?], now lies in the church Yard over one of the Graves'. Ferquhard, Earl of Ross is said to have founded the abbey in the thirteenth century. Originally located at Edderton, the abbey was moved to its present location soon after and was rebuilt in the fourteenth century under the instructions of William, Earl of Ross. This sketch appears to illustrate all that remains of Ferquhard's tomb. It was not unusual for graveslabs to be removed from their original location, as the earl's obviously was, and placed over modern graves..

This sketch shows the south view of Jedburgh Abbey. The artist has chosen to sketch it from a considerable distance and has included much of the surrounding countryside. Jedburgh Abbey is situated on the north bank of the Jed Water, Jedburgh. It was established, initially as a priory, in the early-twelfth century by King David I. Due to the abbey's close proximity to the English border, it was the scene of much fighting between the Scots and the English and suffered repeated attacks throughout the centuries..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Fearn Island Priory.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This sketch, possibly of Fearn Abbey, Ross-shire, is not dated and is unsigned by the artist but may be one of Hutton's own works. There are at least nine items relating to Fearn Abbey in the Hutton Collection, but it is not entirely clear whether this sketch refers to the same site. The title 'Fearn Island Priory' under this sketch introduces an element of doubt about what the sketch is supposed to represent. Fearn Abbey is not on an island, but it is in the eastern peninsula of Ross-shire erroneously known as the Black Isle. Moreover, the religious foundation at Fearn seems to have been an abbey from its beginnings, rather than having been promoted from priory status. It may be that the artist, whether Hutton or not, made this sketch while still unsure of the history and exact geography of the site. However, the sketch is too incomplete to be conclusively recognisable as Fearn Abbey, and the possibility remains that it may be of a completely different site, and that there may be some error in the location ascribed to it..

Rutherford, A.

Someone has scored out the word 'church' from the title and replaced it with 'abbey' in this print. It shows the abbey ruins from the north-east and is by A. Rutherford, 1775. J. Ainslie of Edinburgh sold the print. Jedburgh Abbey is located on the north bank of the Jed Water, Jedburgh. King David I founded it as a priory in the early-twelfth century. Soon after was elevated to the status of an abbey. Home to a community of Augustinian canons and dedicated to St Mary, Jedburgh Abbey was one of four great abbeys built in the Scottish Borders during the Middle Ages: the others being Melrose Abbey, Kelso Abbey and Dryburgh Abbey..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Jedburgh Church.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Rutherford, A.

This print is entitled 'JEDBURGH CHURCH'. It shows the abbey ruins from the north-east and was executed by A. Rutherford in 1776. The print was produced for and sold by Robert Jameson of Parliament Square, Edinburgh, and is one of three by Rutherford in the Hutton Collection. Rutherford was responsible for another print of Jedburgh Abbey viewed from the north-east. It is also contained in the Hutton Collection and shows a very similar scene to this one, and is dated 1775. Initially a priory, Jedburgh Abbey was founded in the early-twelfth century by King David I and for many years was home to canons of the Augustinian Order..

rdf:Description.dc:creator: Rutherford, A.
Ainslie, J.
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

Another print in which someone has scored out the word 'church' from the title and replaced it with 'abbey'. It shows the abbey ruins from the north and was executed by A. Rutherford in 1777. The print could be purchased from J. Ainslie of Edinburgh and is one of three by Rutherford in the Hutton Collection. Jedburgh Abbey was founded in the early-twelfth century by King David I. Originally a priory, it soon achieved abbey status and was populated by Augustinian canons from the abbey of St Quentin, at Beauvais, France. Due to the abbey's close proximity to the English border, it was the scene of much fighting between the Scots and the English and suffered repeated attacks throughout the centuries..

rdf:Description.dc:title: View of Portpatrick, Galloway.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This view shows is of the south wall of the church and the adjacent houses. It is though to have been drawn in 1811 but there is no artist’s name attached. Portpatrick lies opposite Donaghdee in Ireland, which is only 2 miles away and the gulf stream from the Irish Channel results in the areas mild climate. The town itself lies at the bottom of a cleft in the hills and provides easy access to Stranraer and Galloway. These factors meant that Portpatrick enjoyed a busy harbour industry, with fishing, freight, mail packets, coastguards and lifeboats all operating from its shore. It also provided an enjoyable holiday resort for Victorians to relax in during their leisure time..

This sketch shows the north-east view of the abbey from a distance and includes much of the surrounding area. The artist's name and the date have not been provided. There are a number of other drawings in the Hutton Collection that detail Fearn Abbey. Fearn Abbey is thought to have been founded in the thirteenth century by Ferquhard, Earl of Ross. It was home to monks of the Premonstratensian Order, who divided their time between prayer and working the surrounding land. The monks occupied the abbey until the Reformation (1560), after which it was used as the local parish church..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Nunnery of Manuel.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Morton, Alexander, of Dunfermline, active 1813-1817
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

The note on this drawing reveals that it was drawn in 1813 by Alexander Morton. A key to his annotations has been included down the right of the sheet and he has written a further note on the condition of the remains at the time, underneath this. There are three views of the nunnery contained in the Hutton Drawings, and they all focus on the architectural detail of the remains. Alexander Morton was a prolific draughtsman, according to the volume of plans contained in the Hutton Drawings. Hutton was interested in recording all aspects of ecclesiastical buildings and plans and elevations are interesting and useful tools, which help form a complete record of a site. It is also known that Hutton often contracted the record making process out. It is thought that Morton was a builder, based in Dunfermline, and so this would have made him an ideal candidate to make schematic drawings of sites in south-east Scotland..

rdf:Description.dc:creator: Blore, Edward, 1787-1879
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827

It is likely that Hutton himself made this copy of the plan from the original by the celebrated architect Edward Blore (1790-1879). It shows an overhead plan of the main abbey building. Melrose Abbey was founded in 1136. It was almost destroyed in the Scottish Wars of Independence, but was rebuilt between the fourteenth and sixteenth centuries. It is these more elegant and intricate remains which are visible today. Robert the Bruce's heart is buried within the abbey, as are the remains of many of the powerful Border family, the Douglases..

There is no information attached to this rubbing at all. It is to be found amongst five other views of Whithorn Priory, most were created in 1811. Hutton seems to have collected many of these miscellaneous rubbings of parts of carved stones. The Hutton Drawings contain many representations of stone carvings from all over Scotland and covering many time periods. Together they form a fascinating record of decorative Scottish stone monuments. There were many fine carved stones found at Whithorn, including the Latinus stone, the earliest Christian monument in Scotland and the Monreith Cross, embodying the finest elements of the Whithorn school of carving..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Ground plan of the ruins of the Cathedral of Ross.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: MacQueen, John, artist in Fortrose
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

Annotated ground-plan of Fortrose Cathedral, Ross-shire. It is dated 1815, and was drawn by John Macqueen. Maqueen's extensively annotated plan occupies two pages, both held in the Hutton Collection. This page contains the ground-plans of the different parts of the cathedral complex, some physical description, and the beginning of a list of references to parts of the building, denoted by different numbers and letters on the ground-plans. The second page continues the list of references, and describes the dimensions and proportions of various aspects of the buildings. This is one of at least nine images relating to Fortrose Cathedral in the Hutton Collection. Like several other of the images, however, the page's title refers to the cathedral as 'The Cathedral Church of Ross'. This is because when the cathedral was built by Bishop Robert of Ross about 1214, Fortrose became the 'see' or centre of the Roman Catholic diocese of Ross, and the cathedral represented a focal point for the religious life of the whole county, rather than just the village of Fortrose..
