Drawing of a north view of Fortrose Cathedral, Ross-shire. It is dated October 1815, and, as not attributed to any particular artist, may be one of George Henry Hutton's own works. This is one of nine views of Fortrose Cathedral in the Hutton Collection. Fortrose Cathedral is situated in the centre of the village of Fortrose, on the south-east coast of the Black Isle north of Inverness. The Cathedral was built some time between 1214 and 1249 by Robert, Bishop of Ross, and thereafter Fortrose became the 'see', or centre, of the Roman Catholic diocese of Ross-shire..

rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

Drawing of a north view of Littledean Tower, Roxburghshire. It shows the ruins of Littledean Tower in its wooded, elevated situation above the River Tweed. The drawing, which is unsigned by the artist, is the only image relating to this site in the Hutton Collection. Littledean Tower was built in the late-fifteenth century as the family home of the Kers of Littledean, who were a branch of the Kers of Cessford, a prominent Borders family. Various legends and supernatural stories have become attached to the tower, the most famous of which is that of the Old Lady of Littledean. This was a former mistress of the tower whose spirit could not rest because of her guilt over the covetous and greedy life she had led, and haunted the tower..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Kelso Abbey, N.E. View.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Grose, Francis, 1731?-1791
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

Drawing of a north-east view of Kelso Abbey, dated 1788. It is one of five items relating to Kelso in the Hutton Collection, and was reproduced in Francis Grose's book 'The Antiquities of Scotland, volume I', which was published in London in 1789. As the page does not carry the signature of the artist, it is not clear whether Grose made the drawing himself, or whether it is one of George Henry Hutton's own works. Very little of Kelso Abbey now remains - the east end of the nave, shown here in Hutton's drawing, is the only substantial part of the building to have survived a raid by English troops in 1550, the Reformation ten years later, and the likely subsequent pillaging of the site for building stone. However, it is thought that at its height, Kelso Abbey was one of the most spectacular and ambitious buildings ever to have stood in Scotland. The Romanesque-style abbey, founded by King David I in 1128, is believed to have been double-cruciform in its layout, having four transepts instead of two, and two towers instead of one..

There is no artist’s name attached to this sketch although the date 1811 has been noted along the edge of it. The location of this feature within the castle is also unclear. This is one of two images of features from the Rhinns of Galloway area. Dunskey Castle was built in 1510 by the Adairs of Kilhilt and is protected on three sides by rock face and on the fourth by a 15 metre rock-cut ditch crossed by a draw bridge. The buildings themselves would have formed a fashionable renaissance internal coutryard but many of the individual buildings are now largely indistinguishable. This structure replaced an earlier L-shaped tower house which was burnt down during a siege in 1489..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Font at the east end of Fortrose Cathedral, Ross-shire.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This drawing is dated October 9th 1815 and, as not attributed to any artist, is likely to have been drawn by Hutton himself. This is one of several drawings made at Fortrose Cathedral in the Hutton Collection. The font is the octagonal basin in the left foreground of the picture. A window in the eastern wall occupies the centre-ground, and there are what appear to be a number of gravestones against the wall. The font in a church or chapel contains the holy water in which infants and church members are baptised. The font is usually found near to the altar, which is traditionally in the east end of a church building. This tradition derives from Mosaic Law (the instructions that the Old Testament describes being given by God to Moses), which dictated that the apostles should pray facing the east..

rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This drawing appears to be a funerary monument in Fortrose Cathedral, Ross-shire. It consists of a stone effigy of a human figure lying on a plinth, underneath an ornamented arch. There are short descriptive notes on either side of the arch, but there are no notes to indicate the date of the drawing or the identity of the artist. This is one of at least nine items relating to Fortrose Cathedral in the Hutton Collection. The ruins of Fortrose Cathedral contain three arched tombs. One commemorates the Countess of Ross-shire, who was the wife of Alexander Stewart, Earl of Buchan, better known as the 'Wolf of Badenoch'. The other two tombs mark the graves of Bishop Fraser, who died in 1507, and Bishop Cairncross, who died in 1545. The notes on the page do not indicate which of these tombs is reproduced in the drawing..

rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827

rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This drawing is one of a number of images relating to Fortrose Cathedral in the Hutton Collection, and the majority of them are dated 1815. Although this drawing is not attributed to any particular artist, it is likely that this was one of George Henry Hutton's own works. This view of Fortrose Cathedral shows that it was in roughly the same state of repair, or disrepair, as it is today. Most of what remains of the cathedral dates from the fourteenth century, but the foundations are of the original thirteenth century building, which was established by Robert, Bishop of Ross, some time between 1214 and 1249. The cathedral made Fortrose the 'see', or centre, of the diocese of Ross-shire, which is why the drawing's original title refers to it as 'the Cathedral Church of Ross'..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Kelso Abbey, S.E. View.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This drawing is dated 1788, and as not attributed to any artist, is likely to be the work of George Henry Hutton himself. It is one of around five items relating to Kelso in the Hutton Collection, and shows the ruined east end of the abbey church, which is the only substantial part of the abbey complex remaining. To the right of the abbey in the background is the squat clock-tower of Kelso town hall. Built on the north bank of the River Tweed, immediately to the north-east of the ancient burgh and castle of Roxburgh, Kelso Abbey was founded by King David I in 1128. Its inhabitants were Tironensians, a community of monks from Tiron in France who had left the Benedictine order in 1105. In 1550 the abbey was largely destroyed by English troops, and as the Reformation occurred only ten years later, the monks never had a proper chance to rebuild the abbey and revive their dwindling numbers..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Jedburgh Abbey, S.W. View.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Grose, Francis, 1731?-1791
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This drawing is dated 1788. The drawing, which is one of six views of Jedburgh Abbey in the Hutton Collection, was reproduced in Francis Grose's book 'The Antiquities of Scotland, volume I', which was published in London in 1789. It does not carry the signature of the artist, so it is not clear whether Grose made the drawing himself, or whether it is one of George Henry Hutton's own works. This view shows in quite fine detail the southern side and western façade of Jedburgh Abbey, which remains one of the most intact of the great medieval Scottish abbeys. The abbey, situated on the north bank of the Jed Water, was founded in 1138 by King David I. The ostentatious design of the building, which was modelled on European cathedrals, is believed to have been intended as a gesture of defiance towards England. At the time, Scotland and England were in regular dispute about ownership of the border lands around Jedsburgh. Consequently, the Abbey was attacked by invading English troops on many occasions over the subsequent four centuries..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Kelso Abbey, S.W. View.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This drawing is dated 1789, and although not attributed to any artist, is likely to be one of George Henry Hutton's own works. The drawing was made from the south bank of the River Tweed. On the north bank, the ruined tower of the abbey, just to the right of centre, dominates the town of Kelso, and beyond that to the right again is the squat spire of the town hall. The stone bridge on the left of the picture is not the current Kelso Bridge, which was opened in 1803, but is probably its predecessor, which was swept away in a flood in 1797. The Benedictine Abbey at Kelso was founded in 1128 by King David I, for a group of monks from Tiron in France. It grew to become the largest and wealthiest of the four great Border Abbeys, a coronation place and burial place of Scottish Kings. In the mid-sixteenth century, however, it was destroyed by Henry VIII of England's troops, and with the Reformation sweeping away monastic foundations in Scotland in the 1550s and 1560s, Kelso Abbey was never rebuilt..

There are many representations of carved stones, most of them grave markers of some description, contained in the Hutton Drawings. In total, they span about 1,300 years of Scottish carving and together form a comprehensive record of Scottish fashion and skills..

rdf:Description.dc:creator: Daniell, William, 1769-1837
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

Tombstone in St Columba's Chapel, Eye Peninsula, Isle of Lewis. The carved tombstone appears to show the figure of a warrior in a tunic, clutching a sword. The drawing is not dated but seems to have been the work of William Daniell, who drew a number of items in the Hutton Collection. This is the only image relating to St Columba's Chapel at Eye in the collection. The Eye Peninsula is the easternmost part of Lewis, and is connected to Stornoway and the rest of the island by a very narrow isthmus. The fourteenth-century St Columba's Chapel is the historic burial ground of the Macleod Chiefs of Lewis and the Mackenzies of Seaforth, and the tomb drawn by Daniell was clearly that of a highly regarded head of the Macleod family..

The decorative detail on the stone is clearly shown, and measurements have been included in a note underneath the sketch. It has also been recorded that 'no trace of the arms on the two shields remain'. Originally a tombstone for one of the Abbots, at the time of this sketch the stone had been placed on a modern grave at the south side of the church. Fearn Abbey lies in the village of Hill of Fearn and is located around five miles south-east of Tain. The abbey moved to Fearn in the thirteenth century from its original location near Edderton and served as a monastery until the Reformation (1560), after which it became the parish church. Disaster struck in 1742 when the abbey was hit by lightning. Around 40 people were killed and the building itself was so badly damaged that a new church was erected close to the south-west door..

Whithorn Priory (Whithorn, Scotland)
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This, untitled, pencil sketch of an archway is thought to have been made at Whithorn Priory. There is very little information attached to it, but it is to be found amongst other images of Whithorn. Most of these other drawings were also completed in 1811. Whithorn Priory church also served as the diocese Cathedral – the church eventually forming the centre of the Galloway diocese. The layout comprised an equidistant choir and nave, both of which were without aisles and then a lady chapel to terminate the building. It is known that in 1684, the western tower and nave were still intact but this state of affairs did not last long and the structure is now roofless..

rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This drawing shows the east façade of St Duthac's Collegiate Church in Tain, and is dated 1815. The drawing is unsigned by any artist, and is probably the work of George Henry Hutton himself. There are several drawings from Tain in the Hutton Collection, the majority of them depicting this church. St Duthac's Church originates 1360 but was only converted to a collegiate church in 1487, by Thomas Hay, Bishop of Ross. Collegiate churches supported a 'college' of monks or canons who were devoted to theological study and contemplation, but who were often also dedicated to holding special prayers or masses for the family or individual who founded the church. Until the rise of Protestantism in the sixteenth century, the wealthy were often encouraged to found or support churches, on the premise that this was a 'good work' that would help to gain salvation for their souls..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Stone dug up in St James's Green near Kelso, now built into the new wall on the Edin. road near the 40 mile stone, 1790.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Cocking, Thomas, active approximately 1783-1791
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

The writing on this drawing continues, 'Drawn by Captain Grose's servant'. 'Captain Grose' is a reference to Francis Grose, an author, antiquary and friend of George Henry Hutton. Grose's servant was named Thomas Cocking, and like his master, Cocking was responsible for several drawings in the Hutton Collection. This is one of a number of items relating to Kelso in the collection. This carved stone may have originated in the ancient burgh or castle of Roxburgh, which stood on a site immediately to the south-west of Kelso, at the confluence of the River Tweed and Teviot Water. Roxburgh's patron saint was St James, and although no trace of the original burgh now remains, its history lives on in the annual fair of St James, which is held on the site of the former burgh. It is probable that this site is the area referred to by Hutton as 'St James's Green'..

rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827

rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

Inscription from Melrose Abbey, Roxburghshire. A note reveals that the inscription dates from 1788 and that the drawing was actually made on 20th August 1807. It is also recorded that the stele was found against the east wall above the staircase. There are no further details. Although founded in 660, the abbey precinct was burned down in 1385 and so most of the remains date from after this time. The remains are one of the richest sources for medieval and post-medieval carvings, such as this. Other themes captured in stone, in the precinct, include the Virgin’s life, the stories of St James, St Peter, St Catherine and St Thomas. There are also fine examples of decorative motifs such as dragons, gargoyles and flowers..

rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This drawing shows the south-east view of the abbey and is dated September 1815. The artist has also included a note underneath the sketch: 'In the little aisle or chapel adjoining the East end, shown in the view, the Earl of Ross, the Founder, is said to have been interred, and in the Enclosure to the west of it is Abbot McFayd's monument'. Known as the 'Lamp of the North', Fearn Abbey is the most northerly medieval monastery in Scotland and is one of the oldest pre-Reformation churches still used for worship today. Founded in the early-thirteenth century by Ferquhard, Earl of Ross, the abbey was a Premonstratensian house dedicated to St Augustine. The monks remained there until the Reformation (1560), at which point the abbey became the local parish church..

Here the remains of the castle can be seen halfway up the hill, in the centre of the sketch. The castle still looks much the same and so this image is a good gauge and check of the deterioration process. The castle once comprised a curtain wall 360 metres by 90 metres and four corner towers and the hill has thought to have been a fortified residence since the Saxon age. Roxburgh Castle, also known as Marchmont, was once the property of the crown and then various members of the nobility, most notably the Douglases. As such it played a pivotal role in much of Scotland’s politics and power machinations..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Roxburgh Friary.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This drawing is dated 1784, and as not attributed to any artist, is likely to be the work of George Henry Hutton himself. It is the only drawing of Roxburgh Friary in the Hutton Collection, and shows two humble buildings that, in contrast to the grand border abbeys, look like little more than cottages. Roxburgh Friary was located on a peninsula at the confluence of the River Tweed and Teviot Water, adjacent to Roxburgh Castle. The Friary was founded in 1232, and was home to a community of Franciscan monks. It is believed that at one stage, a bridge connected the Friary to Kelso Abbey, which stood east of Roxburgh on the opposite bank of the Tweed. Today nothing of the original burgh of Roxburgh remains, although a hamlet bearing the same name lies approximately two miles to the south-west.

There is no title, date or artist attached to this sheet. There are, however, notes written underneath each sketch. The first sketch is of a knight, with crossed legs, lying on pillow. The effigy lay in a vault near the north door of the Abbey. The other two sketches were made in the Chapter House at Glenluce Abbey. The carvings now preserved is one of the most complete records of a mediaeval design scheme in Europe. Very little information about the Abbey was recorded and all that remains of the early buildings are foundations. There is, however, an impressive but later Chapter House, thought to have been built about 1500, whose structure remains largely intact. The room was vaulted and lit by two large traceried windows. Some of the glazed floor tiles were discovered and there are highly decorated ceiling bosses and corbels..

rdf:Description.dc:title: St Duthac's Chapel, Tain, Ross-shire.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This untitled drawing shows the ruins of St Duthac's Chapel in Tain. Although the Hutton Collection contains at least ten drawings relating to St Duthac's Collegiate Church, this is the only drawing in the collection that solely depicts St Duthac's Chapel, an older building on a separate site. The drawing is not dated and not signed by the artist, and it is likely that it was the work of George Henry Hutton himself. The ruins of St Duthac's Chapel sit on a grassy knoll overlooking the Dornoch Firth in the north-east part of the burgh of Tain. The chapel is believed to have been built to house the relics of St Duthac or Duthus, which were returned to his home town of Tain from Ireland around 1253. The saint's relics were later moved to St Duthac's Collegiate Church, built a century after the chapel, in the centre of Tain..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Collegiate Church at Tain in Ross-shire - S.W. View - Sept 1815.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

Pencil sketch of St Duthac's Collegiate Church, Tain, Ross-shire. The double entrance to the church and the arched window above it can be clearly seen, as can the private burial enclosures of the gentry, down the side of the building. This is one of a total of fourteen images captured of the Collegiate Church at Tain, in the Hutton Collection. The original chapel of St Duthac is now situated to the north-east of the town and housed the saint's relics, which were interred in the mid-eleventh century. The village then grew in popularity as place of pilgrimage and sanctuary. It was the latter function which led to its destruction in 1427. The enemy sought refuge within while his pursuer overcame this obstacle by burning the building down. The relics were then translated to the Collegiate Church which had been founded in 1360, thus transferring the pilgrimage and sanctuary functions. St Duthac's remains disappeared during the Reformation..

rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This drawing captures a spectacular view of the remains of St Mary's Chapel, in a rocky bay in the Shiant Islands, south-east of the Isle of Lewis. The drawing is dated 1818 and is the work of William Daniell, who was responsible for several drawings in the Hutton Collection. This is one of two images relating to this site in the collection. The Shiant Islands are made up of twelve islands, only six of which are large and fertile enough to support any vegetation. The Shiants are best known as the habitat of a huge colony of sea-birds, but at least three of the islands have been populated by humans at some time in their history, and Eilean an Tighe remains inhabited. The historic origins of the ruined chapel of St Mary are unknown, but the island on which it sits also carries the name of the saint, being known as Eilean Mhuire, or Mary's Island..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Tomb of Walderus, 2d Abbot of Melros, who died in 1159.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

St Waltheof's tomb from Melrose Abbey, Roxburghshire. The note goes on to explain that the tomb could be found on the south side of the High Altar. The drawing was copied from Gough’s ‘Sepulchural Monuments of Great Britain'. There are other depictions of Melrose Abbey contained in the Hutton Collection which together form a unique record of this ecclesiastical site, captured almost two centuries ago. Melrose Abbey was founded in 660 by St Aidan, with St Boisil enjoying the prestige of being its first Prior. He was then succeeded by the more then famous Prior, St Cuthbert. After this time the abbey fell into gradual decline until 1134. David I founded a new Abbey, occupied by the Cistercian Order. The Cistercians then implemented a building programme which is now famous for its light, ethereal qualities. The Abbot referred to here is most likely to be St Waltheof, who was also the step-son of David I..

rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This drawing shows the Royal Burgh of Tain in the distance, set within the surrounding countryside. The artist has chosen to include significant landmarks, including (from left to right) St Duthac's Chapel, the Tolbooth, the Collegiate Church and the Academy. The name of the artist has not been included. Tain is famous as the birthplace and final resting place of St Duthac, who was probably born around the ninth or tenth century. It is believed by some that St Duthac's Chapel in Tain was built on the site of his birth. Although St Duthac eventually died in Ireland, his remains were brought to Tain and buried in the chapel. The chapel ruins are still visible today and are located in the old town cemetery..

This drawing shows the south-east prospect of the village of Tain, including the Collegiate Church - seen on the left-hand side of this sketch. The artist's name has not been included. The village of Tain is located close to the southern shore of the Dornoch Firth and is Scotland's oldest royal burgh. It was granted its first royal charter in 1066 by King Malcom III and is home to several buildings of great historical significance, including the Collegiate Church, St Duthac's Chapel, the Tolbooth and the Royal Academy of Tain..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Interior of Melrose Abbey, Roxburghshire.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This pencil drawing, although unsigned and undated, was probably made by George Henry Hutton. It shows the interior of the ruins of Melrose Abbey in the Scottish Borders. Melrose Abbey was founded by King David I in 1136. It was the earliest Cistercian monastery in Scotland, and became one of the wealthiest. Like many ecclesiastical buildings located around the border with England, it was attacked several times by marauding troops. The English sacked the abbey in 1322, 1385 and 1545, after which it never recovered..

rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

There is no artist’s name attached to this sketch, which shows much of the architectural detail. There are three drawings of this Nunnery to be found amongst the Hutton Drawings. Manuel Nunnery was founded in 1156, as a Cistercian House, by Malcolm IV. The Cistercian Order was concerned with the contemplation and worshipping of God. As a result many of their houses were built in beautiful but relatively secluded spots. Manuel’s situation, on the banks of the River Avon, was therefore ideal. They were also renowned for their clean, soaring architectural style – a reflection of God’s omnipotence. This is clearly highlighted in the detail included in this sketch..

Ruins of Manuel Priory, West Lothian. The Priory of Manuel was built over an earlier Culdee, or Celtic, church foundation which was dedicated to 'Our Lord in his aspect as Emmanuel', hence the new name. This house was founded in 1156 by Malcolm IV, as a Cistercian nunnery. Situated on the banks of the River Avon, the house conformed to the more reclusive and contemplative goals of the order..

rdf:Description.dc:creator: Blore, Edward, 1787-1879

Side view of Melrose Abbey, Roxburghshire. It is most probable that Hutton himself copied this sketch from the architect Edward Blore's (1790-1879) original. Blore is most famous for completing Buckingham Palace after John Nash was dismissed from his post, following George IV's death in 1830. Melrose Abbey is one of the most famous abbeys in Scotland, and certainly its ruins are among the most beautiful to be found anywhere in the country. Founded in 1136 by David I, it was settled by monks of the Cistercian Order and dedicated to the Blessed Virgin Mary. The heart of Robert the Bruce is buried in the nave, and many of the Douglas family are interred there..

South-east view of Cambuskenneth Abbey, Stirlingshire. Other images of the abbey in the Hutton Collection show features of the buildings, as well as long distance prespectives. This is a popular view of the abbey and has been captured down the ages as an embodiment of Scotland’s romantic past. The most famous depiction from this angle, and remarkably similar in layout, is Alexander Kay’s watercolour south view of the abbey, looking towards Stirling, made in about 1830. There is a popular engraving of the abbey also included in the Hutton Collection, which admirably conveys the abbey in context and surrounded by life - a pleasant daydream for many researchers..

West doorway of the Cambuskenneth Abbey Church, Stirlingshire. The drawing is dated 20 July 1789. This image is one of five of Cambuskenneth Abbey which are held in the Hutton Collection. Very little structural evidence of the expansive Cambuskenneth Abbey now remains. The campanile and many of the foundations remain along with this - the arched west entrance to the abbey church. Built sometime during the thirteenth century, this displays all the heavy grandeur, mixed with clean lines which characterise Norman architecture. The church itself would have been a large cruciform shape and the cloisters would have been to the south..

Unfortunately there is no artist’s name attached to this drawing. The architectural details are clearly visible on the arch, as is the remodelling of the arch to create a window space rather than a door space. This is one of five views of Whithorn Priory in the Hutton Collection. Whithorn Priory was established around 1150 by Fergus, Lord of Galloway. It was founded as a Premonstratensian house under the suffragan of the Diocese of York. Fergus, by patronising a large ecclesiastical organisation was following the Royal policies of David I, and thus confirming his support of the King. He was also helping to expand and express his own power as lord of his realm – an important part of mediaeval administration..

Drawing showing the front of Melrose Abbey, Roxburghshire. This faint pencil sketch is undated and unsigned, but it is likely that Hutton himself made this sketch, from the original by Edward Blore (1790-1879). Blore is most celebrated as the architect who completed the renovations on Buckingham Palace, begun by John Nash in 1825. The Cistercian abbey of Melrose was fonded in 1136 by David I and dedicated to the Blessed Virgin Mary. The church itself is well preserved although the domestic buildings and cloister are in a bad state of repair. The abbey was dissolved after the Reformation in 1560 although the nave was used as a parish church from 1618 to 1810, when it was finally abandoned..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Kelso Abbey, Roxburghshire.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This page shows an engraving of Kelso Abbey from the north-east. The engraving is not titled, nor is it attributed to any artist, and there is nothing to suggest what publication or occasion the engraving might have been made for. It appears, however, that it might have been made from a 1788 drawing of Kelso Abbey from the same perspective, also in the Hutton Collection and probably the work of George Henry Hutton himself. This is one of five items relating to Kelso in the collection. Kelso Abbey was founded for a group of Tironensian monks by King David I in 1128, on a site on the north bank of the River Tweed. At that time the principal settlement in the area was Roxburgh, immediately to the south-west, which had held royal burgh status since 1120. The town of Kelso grew up around the abbey, initially starting as a small village, but being granted ecclesiastical burgh status and extended trading rights by 1237, and as Roxburgh went into decline, Kelso became an increasingly important market town which prospered from its location on the main route between Edinburgh and Newcastle..

Plan of Cambuskenneth Abbey's campanile, Stirlingshire. The scale has been included along the bottom of the sheet and there is an orientation compass in the top right corner. This plan is one of five depictions of the abbey, which together make a comprehensive record of the site. Very little now remains of this extensive and powerful Abbey complex - simply the bell tower, the arched west doorway of the church and the foundations of most of the complex. The church itself was a large cruciform building, which also formed the north side of the cloisters. The bell tower, to the north, was always unattached to the church, the only example of this in Scotland, making it a campanile. The roof was remodelled in the nineteenth century, but the rest of the tower dates from the thirteenth century..

This is a drawing of the north aspect of Inchmahome Priory in the Lake of Menteith. The artist, William M. Stirling, appears to have been a minister based in Port of Menteith in the early nineteenth century. Stirling, who wrote 'Notes, historical and descriptive, on the Priory of Inchmahome' (1815), was responsible for a number of the images of the Priory in the Hutton Collection. A large number of Scottish medieval monastic foundations were destroyed, or went into rapid decline, after the Reformation replaced Roman Catholicism with Presbyterianism as the Established religion of Scotland. Inchmahome was one of those ecclesiastical buildings that fell into ruin after the Reformation, and was never fully restored. However, the chapter house has been re-roofed, and many gravestones and memorials have been moved into it to protect them from the elements..

Descriptive notes of St Fillan's Priory, Strathfillan, Perthshire. These notes are entitled simply 'Strathfillan'. They are undated and unattributed, but the handwriting makes it appear likely that George Henry Hutton was the author. The text of the notes suggest that they may once have been attached to a sketch or drawing of St Fillan's Priory. This is one of four items relating to St Fillan's Priory in the Hutton Collection. The notes read: 'The small remains of walls here exhibited, appear to have been part of the south wall of the Conventual Church, or Chapel. The foundations of the other sides of the Building may be also traced. It is about 36 paces by 11 or 12 over walls. And at the East end of the Ruins, stands the little Kirk, in a ruinous state, a chapel of Ease to the Mother Church, where Divine Service is performed every Sunday. Its external measurt. is about 16 paces by 8'..

Coloured drawing of a north view of Inchmahome Priory, Perthshire. This drawing shows Inchmahome Priory from the north shore of the Lake of Menteith in Perthshire. It is dated 1789 and is one of a number of images relating to Inchmahome Priory in the Hutton Collection. The name of the artist is not recorded on the page, and it is likely that this is one of George Henry Hutton's own works. The Lake of Menteith is in the heart of an area of eastern Lowland Scotland rich in medieval royal palaces and castles, and probably because of this, Inchmahome priory has illustrious royal connections. Robert the Bruce is known to have visited the priory on at least three occasions, and its easily defensible location, on an island in the lake, also made it an ideal refuge for the infant Mary Queen of Scots after the Battle of Pinkie in 1547..

rdf:Description.dc:title: West face of Inchmahome Priory.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Stirling, William MacGregor
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

Copy of drawing of the west face of Inchmahome Priory. This drawing is not titled. It is a copy of a drawing of the west face of Inchmahome Priory by William M. Stirling, and dates from 1827. William Macgregor Stirling was the minister in the hamlet of Port of Menteith, on the shores of the Lake of Menteith, in the 1820s. He was responsible for several drawings of Inchmahome Priory in the Hutton Collection. The ruins of Inchmahome Priory are stituated on an island in the Lake of Menteith in Perthshire, fifteen miles west of Stirling. The priory was founded in 1238 by Walter Comyn, Earl of Menteith, for a group of monks of the Augustinian Order. It declined after Reformation of 1560 but was a very significant religious foundation in its day, and was visited on several occasions by King Robert the Bruce, and also by Mary Queen of Scots..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Cross about three miles from Perth, on the road to Huntingtower.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Grose, Francis, 1731?-1791

Hutton, George Henry, -1827

Drawing of a monument near Huntingtower, Perthshire. This sketch shows a stone cross that is located just outside Perth, on the road to the historic village of Huntingtower. The halo above the figure's head suggests that it would probably have been some sort of religious symbol. Although the drawing is not dated, it is known to be one of George Henry Hutton's sketches, based on an earlier sketch made by Captain Francis Grose in 1790. A note at the foot of the drawing reads, 'Cross about three miles from Perth, on the road to Huntingtower - From a sketch by the late Capt Grose June 1790'. Captain Francis Grose made many fine drawings of Scottish churches and landmarks, and is well known for his book, 'The Antiquities of Scotland', which was published in 1791..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Chapel of Holyroodhouse.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Morton, Alexander, of Dunfermline, active 1813-1817
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

Alexander Morton, who drew many plans of famous Scottish buildings during the early 1800s, made this plan in 1813. The Roman numerals that appear in the plan indicate the main rooms and areas, and correspond with the numbered list that is included at the bottom right corner of the drawing. The scale is at the foot of the page. Known as the palace of Holyroodhouse or Holyrood House, the Queen's official residence in Scotland was originally founded as a monastery by David I in 1128. Located at the bottom of the Royal Mile, the palace is rich in history, and is particularly associated with Mary, Queen of Scots, who lived here from 1561 to 1567. Until the Union of the Crowns in 1603, when James VI left Scotland to become the King of England, Holyrood Palace was where the Scottish royal court was held..

rdf:Description.dc:title: St Nicholas's Hospital, & part of the Bishop's Palace.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Wilson, Alexander, bookseller in Glasgow
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This is a copy of a drawing of St Nicholas Hospital and part of the Bishop's Palace, Glasgow 'from a drawing in the possession of Mr Wilson, Bookseller, Glasgow, 1813'. The name of the artist is unknown. Hutton's note beneath the title reads, 'N.B. This Hospital was pulled down to make way for a new street, about the year 1810'. Perhaps surprisingly, this is the only drawing or sketch from Glasgow contained in the Hutton Collection. St Nicholas's Hospital and the Bishop's Palace stood in the heart of medieval Glasgow, just yards from Glasgow Cathedral. St Nicholas's Hospital was not a hospital in the modern sense, but rather an alms house, which was endowed by Bishop Andrew Muirhead of Glasgow to provide care for twelve old men. It may date from between 1456 and 1471. Provand's Lordship, the oldest surviving house in Glasgow, which dates from 1471, was attached to the hospital and served as the manse of the Master or Preceptor of St Nicholas's Hospital chapel..

rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827

This is a copy of a print of Dunkeld Cathedral, Perthshire. There is no information about either the original or the copy. This is one of two images relating to Dunkeld Cathedral in the Hutton Collection. This view shows the southern aspect of Dunkeld Cathedral, in its setting among hills on the north bank of the River Tay. The cathedral grew up in stages between 1260 and 1501, on the site of an eight-century Celtic monastery. The Reformation of 1560 partially destroyed the Cathedral. Restored, it served as Dunkeld's parish church at the start of the seventeenth century but the Jacobite rising of 1689 badly damaged it again. Much remains in ruin..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Trinity College Church, Edinburgh.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Morton, Alexander, of Dunfermline, active 1813-1817
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827

This plan of Trinity College Kirk is by Andrew Morton in 1813. Mary of Guelders, wife of James II, founded the Collegiate Church of the Holy Trinity in 1460. She dedicated the church to the Holy Trinity, the Virgin Mary, Saint Ninian the Confessor and 'all the saints and elect people of God'. A fine example of Scottish Gothic architecture, the church was located in the hollow between the New and the Old Town sections of Edinburgh. The City demolished the Church in 1848 to make may for Waverley Rail Station..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Restalrig Loch, Edinburghshire, No. 99.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Logan family
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

Restalrig Loch and the ruins of Restalrig (also known as Lochend) Castle, Mid-Lothian. There are no names or dates attached to this colour drawing but it is one of two images of Restalrig amongst the Hutton Collection. The building on the hill is the ruined remains of the old Castle of the Logan family. People commonly know this area and the loch as Lochend. The land around Restalrig, and the village itself, was once the possession of the de Lestalric family. They may have been Norman immigrants, who arrived under David I's settlement policy. The first mention of them and their Restalrig lands was in 1198 and it was in connection with ecclesiastical patron, and so recorded by Dunfermline Abbey. The name may be a corruption of their family name. The Logans of Coatfield eventually took possession of the de Lestalric barony and built their own stronghold on this hill..

rdf:Description.dc:creator: Morton, Alexander, of Dunfermline, active 1813-1817

Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Knights of St. John of Jerusalem in Scotland
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

Alexander Morton, who drew many plans of Scottish church buildings during the early 1800s, made this one of Torphichen Preceptory, West Lothian, in 1813. The numbers included on the plan correspond with the numbered list on the right side of the drawing, and indicate the rooms and main areas of the building. In contrast to Morton's other plans, the exact dimensions of each room and area are not included on the drawing. Founded by David I of Scotland in 1153, Torphichen Preceptory was the Scottish seat of the Knights Hospitallers or Knights of St John of Jerusalem. The nave, transept and choir date from around 1300, and traces of them still exist. However, little now remains of the domestic buildings and the cloister. The building changed a lot during the fifteenth century, while the parish church appeared on this site in 1756..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Plan of the City of Perth.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Stobie, James
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Morison, James, 1762-1809
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This is the second of two copies in the Hutton Collection of a plan that was inset in the 1805 edition of James Stobie's 'The counties of Perth and Clackmannan', originally published in 1783. This is one a large number of images from Perth and Perthshire that were collected by Hutton. This plan shows in fine detail the medieval layout of Perth and later development of the city, and annotations identify Perth's foremost public buildings. The High Street, running west to east in the centre of the plan, was designed in the twelfth century along typical Scottish lines. However, South Street, running parallel to the High Street, was developed shortly afterwards, and this gave Perth's town centre a square appearance that was unusual in Scotland, and led some early antiquaries to believe, erroneously, that the town must have had Roman origins..

This drawing of a bridge at the Falls of Bruar, Perthshire is undated, but may be about 1794. The inclusion of 'Duke of Athol' in the title is probably a reference to the owner of the land around the Falls of Bruar.This is the only drawing relating to Bruar in the Hutton Collection. The Falls of Bruar are located on the Bruar water about three miles north-west of Blair Atholl, in northern Perthshire. The falls divide naturally into three sections, known as the lower falls, middle falls and upper falls. Similar stone bridges cross both the lower and upper falls. It is likely that the bridge shown in this drawing is the upper bridge..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Old Church of Corstorphine.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Morton, Alexander, of Dunfermline, active 1813-1817
Hutton, George Henry, -1827

This plan of St John the Baptist Collegiate Church, Corstorphine, Edinburgh, dates from 1813. It is by Alexander Morton, who drew many plans of Scottish church buildings during the early 1800s. The numbers included on the plan correspond with the numbered list on the left side of the drawing, and indicate the rooms and main areas of the building. Unlike Morton's other church plans, the exact dimensions of each room and area are not included on this drawing. There are records of church buildings having existed on this site from at least as early as 1128. However, the Collegiate Church of St John the Baptist is especially associated with the Forrester family, who lived in the city during the fourteenth and fifteenth centuries. Sir Adam Forrester, a provost of Edinburgh, built a chapel dedicated to St John the Baptist in the late-fourteenth century. His son, Sir John Forrester, raised the church to collegiate status in 1429. The church is now the parish church of Corstorphine..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Cathedral of St. Giles.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Morton, Alexander, of Dunfermline, active 1813-1817
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

Alexander Morton, who drew many fine plans of Scottish church buildings during the early 1800s, made this plan of St Gile's Cathedral in 1817. The Roman numerals that appear in the plan indicate the main rooms and areas in the cathedral, and correspond with the numbered list that is included at the left hand side of the drawing. One of Scotland's most famous cathedrals, St Giles' is after a French saint, in honour of the Auld Alliance between Scotland and France. Also known as the High Kirk of Edinburgh, the Bishop of St. Andrews officially consecrated it in 1243, although the massive pillars in the building date back to 1120. Rich in history, St Gile's is particular associated with the Scottish Reformation, as John Knox preached here during the sixteenth century. Legend has it that it was also here that Jenny Geddes threw her chair at the minister when Charles I tried to impose Laud’s new prayer book in 1637..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Plan of St Magnus’ Cathedral, Kirkwall, Orkney.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Daniell, William, 1769-1837
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

William Daniell drew this plan of St Magnus’ Cathedral in 1818. There are eight views of the Cathedral in the Hutton Collection and William Daniell completed four of them. Daniell had established his reputation as a landscape painter by this time, but unusually, three of his Cathedral drawings are of the interior. Kirkwall today retains an air of antiquity due to street system and the appearance of the houses. There was a huge expansion in the fishing industry during the seventeenth century, which stabilized into the eighteenth. This resulted in more modern, stone Burgh houses replacing many of the timber Norse buildings. They have narrow gable ends, facing the street, and spread out along the main street in the town. This layout was subsequently, never interfered with as new buildings were established on the newly reclaimed land, or around the edges of the town..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Carmelite Church Queensferry 1813.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Morton, Alexander, of Dunfermline, active 1813-1817
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

Alexander Morton has signed the bottom right corner, of this plan of the Carmelite Church, South Queensferry, on 10th May 1813. The top left corner also carries a note about the cloister remains. The plan contains a scale, along the bottom, a navigation compass and key to the notation used on the plan. Although the house was founded in 1330, the remains shown on this plan mainly date from the 1440s. The only standing parts of the church at this time were the choir, tower, south transept and nave. The nave collapsed later into this century and was, unusually, shorter than the choir was. In 1889, the Episcopalian community refurbished the whole building for worship.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Perth, 1783.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Smeaton, John, 1724-1792
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This incomplete drawing, made in 1783, shows the Old Bridge over the River Tay at Perth, as viewed from the east bank and looking south. Although the name of the artist has not been included on the drawing, it is quite likely to have been George Hutton himself. The artist who drew this sketch would have been upriver, looking down towards the bridge, with the city of Perth located on the right side of the sketch. The Old Bridge, also known as Smeaton's Bridge, was built in 1771, and replaced the ferry. The original bridge was destroyed in a flood in 1621. Taking four years to construct, at a cost of £26,631 (about £2,129,000 in today's terms), the bridge was named after the engineer who built it, John Smeaton..

rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

Sketch of remains of St Fillan's Priory, Strathfillan, Perthshire. It is dated September 8th 1820, and although not signed, is likely to be the work of George Henry Hutton himself. This is one of four views of Strathfillan in the Hutton Collection. The area takes its name from St Fillan, who is reputed to have founded the priory there in the eighth century. A note beneath the title of this sketch reads: 'The little wall on the left, below the Ruins, is modern, & contains the monument of a man who was drowned in 1808 when bathing in the adjacent River Fill'. Another note identifies the Kirk, or church, in the right foreground of the sketch..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Hamilton Col. Ch. Oct. 15. 1800.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This sketched plan is one of four views of Hamilton Collegiate Church, Lanarkshire, contained in the Hutton Collection. It is unsigned by the artist. The measurements of most of the walls are given in feet, but some distances are measured in paces, and beside an incomplete line, perhaps indicating a gap in the walls of the building, a note reads, 'Should meet the line of 15 paces at right angles'. Hamilton Collegiate Church was located on a site close to the River Clyde and adjoining the family seat of the Barons of Cadzow, later Dukes of Hamilton. The church was founded by Sir James Hamilton, 6th Lord Cadzow, in 1450-1, and was dedicated to St Mary, although it is not associated with the current St Mary's Church in Hamilton. With the exception of the transept housing the Hamilton family burial vaults, the church was demolished in the eighteenth century while Hamilton Palace was being extended..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Weigh House.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This is a sketch of the Weigh House, Edinburgh. The Weigh House stood in Edinburgh's West Bow, in the centre of Castlehill Street where it intersects with Lawnmarket and Johnston Terrace. In this quick sketch, the artist has created a sense of the bustling city by including a human figure and passing traffic. Another name for the Weigh House was the Butter Tron, as it was where butter and cheese were on sale. The English destroyed the first weigh house in 1384, but the Town Council built a new one in 1614. However, Cromwell's troops destroyed the second building in 1650. The building shown here dates from 1660. It finally disappeared in 1822 in order to widen the road for King George IV's visit..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Tron Church, Edinburgh.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This untitled drawing depicts the Tron Church, which is located in the Royal Mile, at the junction between the High Street and the South Bridge. Although the name of the artist is not included, the sketch dates from around 1781. King Charles I founded the Tron Kirk in 1637, to house the displaced congregation from nearby St Giles, after it became a cathedral. The Tron Church is named after a salt-tron, which was a public weighing beam that was previously located outside the church's main entrance. The original wooden spire was burnt down in 1824, and was replaced by a stone spire. Although it remains open as tourist attraction, the church closed its doors to its congregation in 1952..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Inchaffray Abbey, near Perth 1781.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This drawing, was probably made by George Henry Hutton himself, although no artist is named. Inchaffray Abbey was founded in 1200. Maurice, Abbot of Inchaffray, was chaplain to Robert the Bruce and carried relics of St Fillan before the Scottish army at the Battle of Bannockburn in 1314. Laurence Oliphant, a later Abbot at Inchaffray, was killed at the Battle of Flodden 200 years later..

rdf:Description.dc:title: West Door of the Cross Church of Peebles.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

Under the title of this watercolour, there is a note that appears to have read 'as it stood in 1806'. The artist's surname is Turnbull, and this is one of at least two views of Peebles Cross Church in the Hutton Collection painted by this artist. Standing on an elevated position on the west bank of the Eddleston Water, you can still see the remains of Peebles Cross Church today, although much of what was once there has disappeared. A Trinitarian monastery was an addition to the thirteenth-century church in 1473-4, but fell into disuse after the Reformation in 1560. The Monastery became building stone, while the church was temporarily the parish church of Peebles. When a new parish church opened in 1784, the Cross Church fell into complete ruin..

rdf:Description.dc:title: West End of the Cross Church, Peebles.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This watercolour of the west end of Peebles Cross Church, Peeblesshire, is undated, but the surname of the artist is Turnbull. This is one of at least eight views of Peebles Cross Church in the Hutton Collection. The doorways shown here in Turnbull's painting were probably part of the main entrance into Peebles Cross Church. It was traditional in medieval church design for the entrance to be in the west wall, at the opposite end of the church from the altar. Altars were usually at the east end, because the Mosaic laws communicated by God to Moses in the Old Testament stipulated that the apostles should pray facing the east. The Cross Church, whose remains still stand in Peebles, dates from AD 1261..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Palace and ruins of the Chapel of Holyroodhouse, from the north west.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This print of Holyrood House shows the north-west view of the building, with Arthur's Seat providing the background. The ruins of the chapel are to the left of the palace. The original drawing appeared in Volume I of Captain Francis Grose's book, 'The Antiquities of Scotland', published in 1789. Located at the bottom of the Royal Mile, the palace of Holyroodhouse or Holyrood House was established as a monastery by David I of Scotland in 1128. The Queen's official residence in Scotland, the baroque palace is rich in history, and is especially associated with the royal Stewarts. Mary, Queen of Scots, lived here from 1561 to 1567, while her son, James VI, resided here until the Union of the Crowns took him to England in 1603. Although the palace was neglected after James VI left for England, it was renovated by Queen Victoria during the nineteenth century..

rdf:Description.dc:title: North East view of Dunblane Cathedral.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This watercolour drawing of Dunblane Cathedral, Stirlingshire shows the cathedral set within its own grounds. The artist also includes two figures in the foreground, possibly to offer perspective, and a number of nearby buildings. The Hutton Collection also includes views of the south-east and distant south-east, and an elevation of the east window. Although this drawing is undated, it was probably before the late-nineteenth century. The artist has clearly shown the roofless nave, which was not restored to its former glory until 1893. The deterioration began during the Reformation and continued for years; whilst the choir remained in constant use, the roof of the nave finally fell in around 1600 leaving the interior open to the elements for almost 300 years..

rdf:Description.dc:title: View of Dunkeld from an original drawing.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

Print of the southern aspect of Dunkeld Cathedral, Perthshire. It is one of two copies of the same print in the Hutton Collection. There is no information about the date or the artist of either the original or the copy. In addition to the two copies of this drawing, there is one other image relating to Dunkeld Cathedral in the Hutton Collection. Dunkeld is one of the earliest known ecclesiastical centres in Scotland. The Pictish King Constantine may have established a religious foundation there in 729, and a later abbey, founded by Celtic Culdee monks from Iona, existed by 820. The relics of St Columba moved from Iona to Dunkeld in 849, establishing Dunkeld as the principal religious centre in the new Kingdom of Scotland. David I confirmed Dunkeld's status as a bishopric in 1127. The stone Cathedral, pictured here, dates from about 1234 and had extensions in the fifteenth century..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Quod Inschemachame.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Stirling, William MacGregor
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

These lines of poetry are the third canto from a poem, here entitled 'Quod Inschemachame'. They are written on the back of an 1815 pencil sketch of Inchmahome Priory by William MacGregor Stirling, who was the parish minister at Port of Menteith. The poem was published in Stirling's 'Notes, historical and descriptive, on the Priory of Inchmahome' (Edinburgh: Printed by J. Ballantyne and Co. for W. Blackwood, 1815). This is one of a number of images relating to Inchmahome Priory in the Hutton Collection. The thirteenth-century Augustinan Priory of Inchmahome stands on an island in the Lake of Menteith, Perthshire. Documents signed by King Robert Bruce at Inchmahome indicated that he visited the priory on at least three occasions, in 1305, 1308 and 1310. It is appropriate, then, that the lines shown here are about Bruce's heroism..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Palace of Scone.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Rutherford, A.
Ainslie, J.
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This print, dated 1775, shows the front view of Scone Palace, which is located by the village of Scone, near Perth. The print was made by A. Rutherford, whose name appears at the bottom right of the drawing, and a note underneath the title states it was 'Sold by J Ainslie of Parliament Square', which is a central Edinburgh address. Originally the capital of Pictavia, Scone Palace was traditionally the crowning venue for Scottish monarchs, hence its association with the Stewarts and the Stone of Destiny. Strategically located by the River Tay and the road to the Highlands, the Bishops' Palace and the Abbey of Scone were destroyed by a mob during the Reformation era. The Gowrie family built a new palace in 1580, and this is the beautiful building that exists today. Following 'the Gowrie Conspiracy' against James VI of Scotland in 1600, however, the thankful King gifted the palace and its grounds to Sir David Murray as a reward for his loyalty..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Edinburgh Castle.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This undated drawing depicts Edinburgh Castle, as viewed from Princes Street. The bridge in the bottom right corner crossed over the loch that previously existed at this point in the Princes Street Gardens. It is quite likely to have been Hutton himself who made this drawing. Located on top of an old volcano 300 feet above sea level, Edinburgh Castle boasts an eagle-eye's view of the surrounding area. Although there has probably been a fort here for about 3000 years, the modern castle is a mixture of buildings constructed over various centuries. The famous Castle Esplanade is immediately below the flag to the left of the drawing, and is the location for the Edinburgh Military Tattoo, which takes place during the festival in August..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Edinburgh, 1784.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This drawing, dated 1784, shows a panoramic view of the city of Edinburgh, as viewed from the south and looking in a north-easterly direction. In the middle of the drawing, it is possible to discern the vague outlines of Arthur's Seat and Salisbury Crags. The artist of this sketch is unknown. Arthur's Seat is an extinct volcano that is located in the middle of the city. There is some debate regarding who or what the volcano is named after, with some people believing is named after King Arthur of Round Table fame, while others maintain that it was named in honour of a local hero who had nothing to do with the King Arthur legend. Salisbury Crags are the spectacular remains of glaciated rock formations, and, like Arthur's Seat, are located in Holyrood Park..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Inscribed stone in South Leith Church, Midlothian.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.
Date of event depicted: 1560

This untitled sketch is of an inscribed stone in South Leith Parish Church. The inscription appears to comprise a crown or mace and the number sixty. There are no notes on the page to indicate the significance of the inscription, but two possible subjects may be the destruction of the church, which occurred in 1560, or the coronation of George III in 1760. The sketch is not dated, and is unsigned. South Leith Church grew out of a chapel founded about 1483. The chapel was partially destroyed when Protestant Lords of Congregation bombarded Leith during the Reformation, and the restored building became the parish church of Leith in 1609. The current South Leith Parish Church was erected on the same site in 1847-8. It incorporates some stones and memorials from the previous buildings..

This pencil sketch bears the date 1781. The artist is unknown. Crichton Castle is about two miles south of Pathhead. It originated as a fourteenth-century tower house, but grew in the fifteenth century into an impressive castle. It is especially famous for Earl Bothwell's Lodging, one of the earliest and most impressive examples of Renaissance architecture in Scotland..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Plan of the City of Perth.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Stobie, James
Morison, James, 1762-1809
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This is an inset from the 'corrected to 1805' edition of James Stobie's 'The counties of Perth and Clackmannan', originally engraved by Thomas Condor, and published in London in 1783. This edition was printed by J. Morison, in Perth, in 1805. It reveals much about the nature of life in 'the fair city' of Perth, towards the end of the eighteenth century. For instance, a cavalry barracks can be seen to the left of the main buildings' list, while an artillery barracks exists immediately left of the word 'Tay'. The famous Perth racecourse surrounds the map title at the top of the page..

This ink sketch is undated and unsigned by the artist. It is one of at least eight images of Peebles Cross Church in the collection. This sketch looks as if the artist was standing inside the ruins of Peebles Cross Church. There is a figure standing by bushes in the church grounds. The church has a largely rural setting, to the north of Peebles' town centre overlooking the Eddleston Water. The location was reputedly the site of an ancient stone cross, but at the time of its foundation, in 1261, it would have lain closer to the centre of Peebles than it does today. Originally, built north of the Eddleston water, the town relocated to a more defensible site between the Eddleston and the Tweed in the sixteenth century, after English troops had burned it down several times..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Paisley, S.W.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This sketch of a south-west view of Paisley Abbey, Renfrewshire, shows the main entrance and western façade. The sketch, which dates from 1813, is unsigned and may be by George Henry Hutton himself. This is the only image relating to Paisley Abbey in the Hutton Collection. Paisley, on the White Cart Water in Renfrewshire south-west of Glasgow, has long been an important ecclesiastical site in Scotland. St Mirren reputedly established a Celtic monastery there in the eighth century and, in 1163, Walter Fitz-Alan founded a Cluniac Priory that became an abbey in 1219. Destroyed by English troops in 1307, rebuilt in the fifteenth century, it partially collapsed in 1533. The work, which restored the building to its present impressive state, took place between the eighteenth and twentieth centuries..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Sculpted stone in the Trinity almshouse, Leith, Midlothian.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This page is not titled, but the sketch on it is of a sculpted stone that was set in the wall of an alms house or hospital in Leith. The words on the stone read: 'IN • THE • NAME • OF • THE LORD • VE • MASTERIS AND • MARENELIS • BYLIS THIS • HOVS • TO • VE • POVR ANNO DOMM • 1555'. The sketch is not dated and is unsigned. The Masters and Mariners of Trinity House, Leith's oldest and wealthiest trade incorporation, built the alms house or hospital in which this sculpted stone was set. At that date, in the sixteenth century, 'hospital' did not necessarily refer to an institution that provided medical care, but might rather be a place where the poor received some sort of food, shelter or financial relief. The original building came down in 1816, but the sculpted stones were preserved and incorporated into a new Trinity House, built on the same site as a guildhall for the trade incorporation..

Sketch of a north-west view of St Fillan's Priory, Perthshire. It is dated September 8th 1820, and although unsigned by the artist, is probably the work of George Henry Hutton himself. A note under the title reads, 'with the Hills of Cruachandoren in the distance'. A second note, in the bottom right corner of the sketch, identifies 'The Road to Tynedrum'. This is one of four images relating to St Fillan's Priory in the Hutton Collection. The ruined eighth-century Culdee Priory of St Fillan is located in Strathfillan, at the east end of Loch Earn in Perthshire. This sketch gives a wider view of the setting than the other views of the priory in the Hutton Collection. One of the two buildings to the left of centre is probably the chapel of ease, which was still in use in the early nineteenth century. The ruined walls of the priory are evident slightly to the right of centre, beyond the farmland and sketched labourers that occupy the foreground. In the background are the dramatic peaks of Ben Cruachan and Ben Dorain..

rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827

Although this sketch of a north-west view of Peebles Cross Church is undated and unsigned by the artist, it is likely that this was one of George Henry Hutton's own works. It is one of a number of views of Peebles Cross Church in the Hutton Collection. Peebles Cross Church was so-called because it was founded on a site where an ancient stone cross once stood, slightly to the north of the medieval burgh of Peebles. Legend has it that an urn containing the relics of the martyr St Nicholas was also found at the site, and consequently, the church was dedicated to St Nicholas by its founder Alexander III. A niche in the south wall of the church represents the reputed last resting place of St Nicholas's relics..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Restalrig Old Church.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Morton, Alexander, of Dunfermline, active 1813-1817
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

Plan of Restalrig Collegiate Church, Mid-Lothian, signed by Alexander Morton and dated 1813. Below this is an explanation of Morton's notation and the plan itself has compass points written onto it. The hexagonal shape in the middle of the plan is the only example of this shape of rib-vaulted room in Scotland, and as such is outstanding. The building itself houses St Triduana's well, a shrine to the saint, which was also renowned for its healing properties. There was a new trend prevalent in late-fifteenth-century Scottish society for the foundation of collegiate, or corporate, churches. In keeping with this trend, the Logan family built St Margaret's Church, incorporating St Triduana's Well, in 1487 as a gift to King James III. Seven or eight priests then said prayers and masses for the King and the Logan family. The chapel was partially destroyed in 1560 and partially undermined by St Triduana's well and as a result restoration work was carried out in 1837..

Sketch of a north view of St Fillan's Priory, Strathfillan, Perthshire. It is dated 13th July 1789, but is unsigned by the artist. This is one of four images relating to St Fillan's Priory in the Hutton Collection. Of the other three, one image is undated, and two are dated 1820. It is quite possible, however, that George Henry Hutton was responsible for all four images, as his career as an amateur antiquary spanned almost forty years. The remains of St Fillan's Priory stand in Strathfillan at the east end of Loch Earn in Perthshire. The priory is reputed to have been founded by St Fillan, the son of St Kentigern, in the eighth century. Little remains of the priory beyond the foundations, as it was quarried to provide building stone for surrounding farms, but the ruins suggest that the priory complex was once quite extensive..

rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827

This is a drawing of a north-east view of St Andrew's Collegiate Church, Peebles. The page, which is dated 1802, is unsigned by the artist, and the drawing may be one of George Henry Hutton's own works. There are a number of drawings made in Peebles in the Hutton Collection, but only two are views of St Andrew's Collegiate Church. St Andrew's in Peebles was one of the latest churches in Scotland to become collegiate, a status it attained in 1542. The church itself had existed since 1195. Collegiate status means a college of secular canons establishing themselves at a church. The canons dedicated their lives to ecclesiastical learning, and to holding special prayers and masses for the souls of the individuals and families who had been founders or sponsors of the church..

The drawing of the Monastery, which is dated 1801, is unsigned by the artist, and may be the work of George Henry Hutton himself. This is one of several pictures of Peebles Cross Church, made from different perspectives, in the Hutton Collection. Peebles Cross Church or Kirk stands to the north of the modern town of Peebles, on the west bank of the Eddleston Water. Peebles High Street and market cross were originally west of the Eddleston, nearer the Cross Kirk, but after repeated burnings by English invaders, the town centre moved to a more defensible position east of the river in the sixteenth century. The name Monastery of the Holy Cross, used in the title of this drawing, is from a Trinitarian attached to the thirteenth century church in 1474..
