This drawing of a monument in Dunkeld Cathedral, Perthshire is undated and unsigned. [The pencil note ('in the Cathedral Church of Dunkeld'), apparently added by Hutton, suggests, however, that this may not be his work.] This is one of two images relating to Dunkeld Cathedral in the Hutton Collection. 'Lord Badenoch', who is commemorated by this monument, was Alexander Stewart, Earl of Buchan, the second son of King Robert II of Scotland. Known as the 'Wolf of Badenoch', Stewart was notorious for his acts of lawlessness, which included burning down the towns of Forres and Elgin in 1390. The monument sits behind the High Altar in Dunkeld Cathedral..

The drawing is dated 1788 but is unsigned by the artist. This is one of two drawings from Elcho in the Hutton Collection, the other being a view of Elcho Castle. The remains of the nunnery at Elcho stand near Elcho Castle, on the south bank of the Tay about three miles south-east of Perth. Apparently founded by David Lindsay of Glenesk, this was the only Cistercian nunnery in Scotland north of the Forth. It burnt in 1548..

This drawing is dated 1783 but is unsigned by the artist. This is one of several images in the Hutton Collection relating to Gowrie House, referred to by Hutton as Gowrie Castle. Gowrie House was a baronial mansion overlooking the River Tay, at the east end of present-day South Street in Perth. Before demolition in 1809, it had an eventful history. In 1600, attendants of King James VI killed its owner, the third Earl of Gowrie, there, along with his brother. In the eighteenth century, the Town presented the house to the Duke of Cumberland, who sold the House to the British government for use as a military barracks..

This drawing shows the remains of the old priory on Priory Island in Loch Tay, Perthshire. The drawing is dated 1789, and may be the work of George Henry Hutton himself, as no other artist is credited on the page. This is one of at least five items relating to Loch Tay in the Hutton Collection. Priory Island, at the east end of Loch Tay, is also known by the Scots Gaelic name Eilean nan Bannoamh, which means 'Isle of the Female Saints'. This name is a reference to Queen Sybilla, wife of King Alexander I of Scotland, who is believed to have died on the island in 1122 or slightly earlier. The island later became known as Priory Island, after the priory reputedly founded there by monks from Scone, in memory of Queen Sybilla..

The drawing, which is dated 1796 and unsigned by the artist, is a south-west view of Peebles Cross Church, Peeblesshire and may be the work of Hutton himself. It is one of a number of views of the Cross Church in the Hutton Collection. The remains of the church and the surrounding countryside are in bold pencil strokes, but in addition, in the foreground, the artist has included a fainter outline drawing of a plough pulled by a team of oxen, which provides an indication that this was farming country without obscuring the view of the church. The Cross Church or Cross Kirk in Peebles, founded in 1261, got its name because it stood on the site of an ancient stone cross. The church commemorates St Nicholas..

Drawing of the Carmelite Church, South Queensferry. There is no artist's name attached to this sketch. You can see the ruined state of the nave here, although they rebuilt it in 1889. There is some controversy surrounding the origins of the Carmelite Order, with many researchers believing it has a direct link to early Christianity. However, the first official record of the order is dated 1155. The Carmelite Order began as a contemplative, hermetical lifestyle, although community living became more popular in the thirteenth century. It remains one of the most strict and extreme of the mendicant houses. This establishment at Queensferry is one of twelve houses founded in Scotland..

This drawing of a west view of the Church of the Holy Cross, later known as Cross Kirk, Peebles, dates from 4th October 1800, but is unsigned by the artist. There are at least seven other drawings or sketches of this same church in the Hutton Collection. The title of this drawing refers to Peebles Cross Church or Kirk by its pre-Reformation name. Alexander III of Scotland founded the Church in 1261. It is the Church of the Holy Rood or Cross after an ancient cross that stood on the same site. In the fifteenth century, a Trinitarian monastery joined the Church. It is almost certain that the monastery's life ended with the Reformation of 1560, when the Cross Kirk temporarily became the parish church of Peebles..

This drawing is an east view of St Andrew's Collegiate Church, Peebles. It is unsigned, and may be one of Hutton's own works. This is one of two views of St Andrew's Collegiate Church in the Hutton Collection, and one of several drawings made in the town of Peebles. The tower on the left-hand side of the picture is the only remaining part of St Andrew's Church. The Church dates from 1195, and gained collegiate status in 1542. The upper part of Neidpath Castle, which stands in the Tweed Valley, is visible beyond a row of houses and a ridge, just right of centre..

rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This drawing, made in 1781, depicts the ruins of Borthwick Castle, which is located beside the village of Borthwick, twelve miles south of Edinburgh. As the drawing shows, the castle stands strategically on the summit of a knoll, in order to make it more difficult to attack. The name of the artist is not included. Built in 1430 by the first Lord Borthwick, Borthwick Castle is a twin-towered baronial keep, steeped in history. It is particularly famous as the place where Mary, Queen of Scots and the Earl of Bothwell escaped to in 1567, after taking flight from Edinburgh. Local legend has it that Mary’s ghost haunts the Red Room in the castle. When the castle was besieged, Mary only escaped by disguising herself as a man. The ghost that is rumoured to haunt the castle is Mary dressed up as a page-boy..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Monument said to be of Sir William Sinclair in the Col-Church of Roslin, 24th Oct 1800.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

The Sinclair family may have established itself in the Lothian area under the ‘Normanisation’ programme which David I is supposed to have instigated. The family hailed from Saint-Clair-sur-l'Epte in Normandy and Henry de St Clair of Roslin was granted lands in 1162. The family were always closely involved in Scottish politics and bought their Orkney Earldom from King Hakon of Norway in 1379. King James swapped this title for Ravenscraig Castle in Fife, in 1470, as he felt the Earls were too powerful..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Castle Comrie, near Cushville, Perthshire.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

The drawing, which is dated 1781, is unsigned by the artist, but may be one of George Henry Hutton's own works. It is the only picture relating to Comrie Castle in the Hutton Collection. 'Cushville' is these days more commonly spelled 'Coshieville' and is a hamlet near Aberfeldy. Comrie Castle is reasonably removed from the Perthshire village of Comrie, lying approximately twenty miles further north on the banks of the River Lyon, in the parish of Dull. The tower house dates from the sixteenth century, and was built by the Menzies family as a replacement for their stronghold of the same name, which was destroyed by fire in 1488, and its successor, the palace of Weem, which was burned in 1502. The castle has been uninhabited since 1748 and is now largely ruinous..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Craig Miller, Lothian, 1781.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This drawing, made in 1781, shows Craigmillar Castle, the ruins of which are located in the south-east part of Edinburgh. By the time of this drawing, the castle was already becoming a ruin, as highlighted by the missing roof. The artist is unknown. King David I of Scotland granted the lands and houses at Craigmillar to Dunfermline Abbey during the twelfth century, although there is no record of a castle then existing. Often used by Scots royalty, it is most likely that the Preston family started the building of Craigmillar Castle in 1374, after John de Capella awarded them the Barony for the region. The castle boasts a rich history, and is particularly associated with Mary, Queen of Scots, and her husband, the ill-fated Lord Darnley. A nearby village was home to Mary's French servants. This still has the name of 'Little France'..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Col. church Crichton from the North West, with Crichton Castle, Oct. 13, 1789.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This drawing depicts the Collegiate Church at Crichton, which is located in the village of Crichton, in Midlothian. The name of the artist has not been included. William Crichton, the Lord Chancellor of Scotland, founded Crichton Collegiate Church in 1449. Located close to the remnants of Crichton Castle, the church is in memory of St Kentigern, St Mungo and St Mary. The church's original design was unusual because it had no nave. They restored it in 1898.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Doune Castle from wood side of Doune.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This drawing is not dated but may be from about 1781. Although the page is unsigned, it appears likely that the artist was George Henry Hutton himself, who seems to have drawn several different castles in west Perthshire in 1781. This is the only image relating to Doune Castle in the Hutton Collection. Doune Castle sits on an elevated site overlooking the River Teith at Doune, north-west of Stirling. The castle dates from the late-fourteenth century, built for Robert Stewart, first Duke of Albany, who was the regent of Scotland from 1406 until 1420 during the imprisonment of the young James I by the English. Despite the fortress-like appearance of the castle, it was mainly a hunting lodge for monarchs throughout the fifteenth and sixteenth centuries. Sir James Stewart, first Lord Doune, assumed ownership of the castle in 1570, and eventually, through marriage, the castle became part of the estates of the Earls of Moray, to whom it has belonged ever since..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Elcho Castle near Perth.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Grose, Francis, 1731?-1791
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This drawing is dated 1783, but is unsigned by the artist. It appeared in Captain Francis Grose's book 'The Antiquities of Scotland, volume II', published by Samuel Hooper of London in 1791. There are several pictures from Grose's books in the Hutton Collection. Elcho Castle stands on the south bank of the River Tay about three miles south-east of Perth. James III of Scotland granted lands to the Wemyss family in 1468, although the present castle probably dates from about 1570. Originally, the castle comprised the large central tower house that still stands today, and smaller buildings ranged round a courtyard to the south. In the 1830s, however, the Eighth Earl of Wemyss demolished most of the minor buildings..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Collegiate Church of Foulis, S.W. view.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This drawing, dates from 15th September 1814, is unsigned by the artist, and it appears likely that this is one of George Henry Hutton's own works. Beneath the title and date, a note, apparently by Hutton, reads, 'B. a little footbridge. Put a female at the right side loading clothes in a tub'. The first part of the note explains an annotation on the drawing. The second part appears to be a suggested addition for a more finished drawing of the scene. Fowlis Easter is a hamlet in the Sidlaw Hills, several miles north-west of Dundee. Its first church dated from 1142, and in 1452-3 Sir Andrew, first Lord Gray, built the collegiate church depicted in this drawing on the same site. It remains intact, and is one of the best preserved fifteenth-century churches in Scotland..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Garth Castle near Cushville, Perthshire.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This drawing is dated 1781, and although it is unsigned, it is likely that the artist was George Henry Hutton himself, and that the picture was drawn in the same period as the drawing of nearby Comrie Castle. This is the only image relating to Garth Castle in the Hutton Collection. The square tower house of Garth Castle stands in the Strath of Appin, in north-west Perthshire. Dating from the fourteenth century, the castle was a stronghold of the Royal Stewart family, and may be by Alexander Stewart, Lord of Buchan (1343-c.1406). Stewart, more famously known as the 'Wolf of Badenoch', was the younger son of King Robert II of Scotland, and became notorious for his lawless behaviour, which included burning the towns of Forres and Elgin..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Gowrie House, Perth, looking north.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

The title of this drawing is 'Gowrie Castle, Perth, looking north'. It is dated 1783 but is unsigned by the artist. It is likely, however, that this was one of George Henry Hutton's own drawings. He appears to have made a series of studies of the Gowrie House in 1783, some of which are engravings that also appear in the Hutton Collection. Gowrie House, on the banks of the Tay in Perth, was the town residence of the Earls of Gowrie until James VI forfeited the family in the early seventeenth century. This occurred after a dispute, which had seen the third earl, and his brother killed in an alleged assassination attempt on the King. Thereafter the house was mooted as the site for a new university, belonged briefly to the Duke of Cumberland, and finally served as a military barracks before its demolition in 1809..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Part of Gowrie Castle, Perth, from the entrance looking south.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This drawing s dated 1783, and although not signed by the artist, it is likely that this was one of Hutton's own drawings. There are several views of Gowrie House in the Hutton Collection, most of which date from this period. In the late eighteenth century, Gowrie House was in use as a military barracks, and several of the Hutton Collection from this period contain evidence of this. In the drawing shown here, a sentry box stands in the courtyard to the right of centre, and what may be ammunition boxes are piled against a wall beyond the sentry box. The house was became a barracks after it had been sold by the Duke of Cumberland, to whom it was gifted by Perth Burgh Council during the Jacobite Rising of 1745-6. Gowrie House was demolished in 1809..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Abbey of Inchaffray, 10 miles nearly west from Perth.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

Drawing of Inchaffray Abbey, Perthshire. It is dated June 18th 1781, and although not signed, it is likely that this is one of George Henry Hutton's own works. This is one of three views of Inchaffray Abbey in the Hutton Collection. The ruins of Inchaffray Abbey stand by the Pow Water in the valley of Strathearn, Perthshire. The abbey was founded as an Augustinian priory in 1200, by the Earl of Strathearn, and was inhabited by canons previously based at Scone. In about 1220-1, the priory was raised to the status of an abbey, and in the early fourteenth century its Abbot is reputed to have served as chaplain to King Robert the Bruce. By the fifteenth century the abbey was indecline, and eventually it was used as a quarry for building stone..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Interior detail in St Magnus’ Cathedral, Kirkwall, Orkney.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Daniell, William, 1769-1837
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

William Daniell may have drawn this sketch, possibly during his sojourn on the island in 1818. Daniell made three sketches of the interior of the Cathedral although there are a further eight views of the building held in the Hutton Drawings. The eighteenth century had seen very little expansion or progression in Kirkwall as developments tended to focus on the more popular fishing village of Stromness. The nineteenth century, however, saw much of the natural Peerie Sea harbour reclaimed so that the town could expand. Money went into two new piers – East and West – and a new connecting road between them, for improved access. This resulted in the bottom-half of the town’s more modern architectural look..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Leith from the Fort, with North Berwick Law and the Bass.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

The ramparts and walls of Leith Fort are in the right foreground of the drawing, with the rooftops and harbour of Leith in the middle distance in the centre of the picture. The Bass Rock and the distinctive peak of North Berwick Law are on the left-hand side of the page, and appear so distant that they are quite difficult to see. The drawing is dated 1784, but is unsigned by the artist. Leith Fort dates from shortly before this 1779 drawing. Its architect was James Craig (1744-95) who also designed Edinburgh's New Town. Today only the entrance, walls and a couple of minor buildings remain of the fort..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Priory of the Isle of Loch Tay, looking west, Oct. 7, 1820.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This drawing is dated October 7th 1820, but is not attributed to any artist, and may be one of George Henry Hutton's own works. This is one of several items relating to Loch Tay Priory which were collected or created by Hutton over a number of years. Priory Island is a small wooded island at the east end of Loch Tay, near to the outlet of the River Tay. The island is believed to have been the site of the death of Queen Sybilla, the consort of Alexander I of Scotland. The King is reputed to have granted the island to the monks of Scone Abbey in 1122, on the condition that a priory was erected there in Queen Sybilla's memory. After the Reformation in 1560, the remains of the priory were incorporated into a fortified home by a local landowner, Campbell of Glenorchy, and much of what remains today probably dates from the later building..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Cowgate.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This sketch depicts part of Edinburgh's Cowgate area, located in the heart of the Old Town section of the city. Although the exact section of the Cowgate represented in this sketch is unknown, it is likely to be somewhere very close to George IV Bridge. The name of the artist is not given, although it is likely that it was Hutton himself and no date has been included on the drawing. Running underneath George IV Bridge and the South Bridge, the Cowgate was the underworld of Edinburgh's Old Town. Located at the eastern end of the Grassmarket, the Cowgate was once the Irish Quarter, populated by the thousands of impoverished Irish immigrants who immigrated to Scotland during the Great Potato Famine of 1846-47. A rabbit warren of dark alleys and passageways, the Cowgate was formerly associated with poverty, crime and vice..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Four flat stones standing on an arc of a circle, near the Lake of Stenhouse, in Pomona, one of the Orkney islands.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Columbine, Edward Henry, 1762-1811
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

The title below this drawing explains that this is a copy of a drawing, originally by Edward H. Columbine completed in 1792. This copy most likely dates from 1802, when many copies of his work appeared. The note goes on to explain the location of the stones, which are in close proximity to Stenness loch. The figures contained in the image adequately convey the fashion of the era. Hutton, the collector of these images and responsible for ordering this copy, was attempting to record the then current, state of Scotland’s pre-Reformation sites. Although this site is pre-Reformation, it is also not a Christian site and so its inclusion is quite unusual. It perhaps had pagan-ritual significance but this is open to wide interpretation. There are other ‘odd’ images of castles and monuments included so perhaps this site simply appealed to Hutton personally..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Peebles from the North.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

Although this drawing dates from 20th October 1800, the modern skyline of Peebles is still recognisable. It is unsigned by the artist, but may be one of George Henry Hutton's own works. Two notes to the right of the title read 'Cross Church' and 'Par. Ch'. These notes identify, the two spires shown in the picture. The ruined thirteenth-century Cross Church, in an elevated position north of the town centre, is the most obvious landmark. The rebuilt sixteenth-century High Street lies beyond that, south-east of the Eddleston Water, and the roofs of its buildings are discernible, culminating in the spire of the parish church which stands at its west end of the High Street. The hills behind the town are Preston Law, Hundleshope Heights and Stob Law..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Part of the Barracks at Perth 1783.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This drawing is dated 1783, and is unsigned by the artist, but it is likely that this is one of George Henry Hutton's own works. Under the title that is written in ink, the words 'Gowrie Castle looking south' can be made out. The barracks at Perth was the subject of a series of drawings in the Hutton Collection, made in 1783. The drawing of this particular site were almost certainly all by Hutton: later engravings made of some of them name him as the artist. In the titles of all but two of the drawings, however, the barracks is named 'Gowrie Castle'. Gowrie Castle, or Gowrie House, situated on the west bank of the River Tay at the foot of South Sreet in Perth, was the town residence of the Ruthvens, Earls of Gowrie, until the seventeenth century when the family was forfeited by James VI, and its property removed. The building was converted into a barracks after the 1745-6 Jacobite Rising..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Behind the Barracks at Perth 1783, looking West.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This is one of a series of drawings in the Hutton Collection made at Perth Barracks in 1783. Although this drawing is unsigned, it was almost certainly the work of George Henry Hutton himself, who is named as the artist on engravings made in the early nineteenth century. In the titles of all but two of the series, however, the barracks is named Gowrie Castle. The baronial mansion which housed Perth Barracks in 1783 was originally the town residence of the Ruthvens, Earls of Gowrie. After an incident in 1600 when the third Earl and His brother was killed by James VI's attendants during an alleged assassination attempt on the King, the Ruthvens were forfeited and Gowrie House handed over to Perth burgh council. In 1746, after the Battle of Culloden, the council presented the house to the Duke of Cumberland, who promptly sold Gowrie House to the British Government so that it could be converted into barracks..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Pillars from St Magnus’ Cathedral, Kirkwall, Orkney.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Daniell, William, 1769-1837
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This drawing may be by William Daniell, sketched during his island stay in 1818. There are a further two interior sketches attributed to him. The interior design of the Cathedral has always stirred interest amongst researchers due to the similarities with both Durham Cathedral and Dunfermline Abbey. The sophistication of the scheme also places Orkney in the heart of European fashion and political awareness. During the Cromwellian wars the English government built two forts at the harbour mouth, as Cromwell was worried about the strength of royalist support on the island. The town at this time, and until the reclamation of the Peerie Sea, enjoyed one long main axis road, with the area split into three districts – Burgh, Midtown and Laverock. The town also enjoyed the attentions of the aristocracy as many built fine town houses so they could winter over in relative comfort..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Sciennes near Edinburgh, S.W. View.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

Sciennes Convent, Edinburgh, from the south-west. The page, which reads, 14th July 1802, is unsigned by the artist, and may be the work of Hutton himself. In the background of the drawing is the village of Newington, now very much part of Edinburgh and beyond that is the familiar outline of Arthur's Seat. This is one of two views of Sciennes Convent in the Hutton Collection. The area in Edinburgh known as Sciennes may have taken its name from the medieval convent there, dedicated to St Catherine of Siena. The convent housed a community of Dominican nuns. Although it does not appear to have been one of Edinburgh's more significant ecclesiastical foundations, there is a reference to Sciennes Convent in Sir David Lindsay’s poem 'The Complaint of the Papingo'. The convent probably fell into disuse after the Reformation, and its stones helped build Greyfriars Kirk, Edinburgh, in 1602..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Scone, 1783.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This sketch shows the front view of Scone Palace, which is located in the village of Scone, near Perth. Although the name of the artist has not been included on the drawing, it is quite likely to have been George Hutton himself. Overlooking the River Tay and the 'gateway to the Highlands', Scone Palace was originally the capital of Pictavia, and the crowning venue - using the Stone of Destiny - for new Scottish monarchs. As with so many Scottish buildings, the abbey of Scone and the Bishops' Palace were destroyed by a mob in 1559 during the Reformation. A new palace was subsequently built by the Gowrie family in 1580. However, following 'the Gowrie Conspiracy' against James VI of Scotland in 1600, the relieved King gifted the palace to Sir David Murray as a reward for his loyalty..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Ruins of St Anthony's Chapel near Edinburgh, from the Duke's Walk.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This drawing, made in 1781, depicts St Anthony's Chapel, which is located on the north side of Arthur's Seat in Holyrood Park, Edinburgh. The name of the artist is not included. Overlooking St Margaret's Loch, St Anthony's Chapel may date back to the mid-fifteenth century. Local legend has it that the chapel was associated with the Knights Hospitallers of St Anthony of Leith, and that it sat high up on Arthur's Seat so that they could see ships sailing up the River Forth. Apparently, a light in the tower welcomed seafarers. All that now remains are parts of the north and west walls, plus the nearby hermitage, which may have been a storeroom. 77.

rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This pencil sketch of St Matthew's Collegiate Church, or Rosslyn Chapel, is one of two that depict features found at Rosslyn. The years 1400 to 1460 saw the growth in popularity of collegiate foundation in Scotland, collegiate indicating an ecclesiastical corporation. William Sinclair, 3rd Earl of Orkney, who also held land in this area, established St Matthew’s in 1446. Sinclair was more interested in quality than speed and as a result, when he passed away in 1482, the church was far from complete. Originally intended to be a large cruciform church with a central tower, only the choir, east transept walls and the nave foundations were ever completed..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Stones of Stenness, near Kirkwall, Orkney.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Daniell, William, 1769-1837
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

The title along the bottom of the sheet reveals that William Daniell drew this sketch of the standing stones at Stenness, probably in 1818. The stones have been set in the context of their mountainous surroundings, and a figure gives perspective. There are another three views of the Stenness stones contained in the Hutton Drawings. William Daniell is more famous for his images of some of the more remote areas of India. His Uncle, Thomas, and Daniell travelled around India in the late 1800s visiting places, which were considered 'uncivilised’. As a result, their powerful representations caused much comment when they returned to this country. There are other sketches in the Hutton Drawings by William Daniell but they are of other Scottish locations. All together, they stand as a testament to Daniell’s skill in depicting his native landscape..

rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This drawing was by a J. Mc [?], the rest of the name now being lost. It may date from 1807. This picture, although labelled Stenness, may actually be a representation of the Ring of Brodgar, further along the same track. The standing stones at Stenness reach 5.6 metres in height, although only four of the original 12 remain standing. Excavators discovered grooved ware pottery on the site in 1973. The Stenness circle is near the larger and more well-known Ring of Brodgar, although this larger henge may be slightly younger. There is no clear indication of who used the circle or why but it has now gained the nickname 'the lunar circle'. ircle was used but it has now gained the nickname ‘the lunar circle’..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Chapel of St Regulus at Cromarty - Sept. 30th 1815 - S.W. View.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This is the only drawing or sketch of this site in the Hutton Collection, and as it does not carry the name of any artist, it is likely to be the work of George Henry Hutton himself. Beneath the title, a handwritten note gives a brief description of the location and appearance of the chapel. Today the chapel in Cromarty dedicated to St Regulus has almost completely disappeared except for the foundations, but more substantial remains existed in Hutton's day, and are described in the memoirs of the nineteenth century geologist, preacher and author Hugh Miller, who was born in Cromarty. St Regulus is reputed to have arrived in Scotland around AD 345, and Cromarty is believed to have had a church from about the sixth century, but it is not known whether this church was the chapel of St Regulus. The legacy of St Regulus lives on in an Episcopal church bearing his name in modern Cromarty..

rdf:Description.dc:title: East View of the palace at Linlithgow 1784.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This drawing shows Linlithgow Palace as viewed from the east. The arch-shaped entrance door in the middle of the drawing would once have been the main entrance to the palace, and a drawbridge would have been located in front of it. Although the palace is now a ruin, you can still see the ornate stonework above this entrance door. The name of the artist is not included. Linlithgow Palace has been a royal residence since the twelfth century. Although there was probably a royal manor-house on this site during the 1100s, it was not until Edward I of England built around the existing buildings in 1301 that a royal pedigree was established. However, David II destroyed Edward's buildings following the Battle of Bannockburn in 1314. The ruined palace buildings seen today were built for James I of Scotland in 1425. The Scottish Parliament was also held here on several occasions..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Priory of the Isle of Loch Tay, from the east, Oct. 7th, 1820.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This sketch, made in October 1820, shows the island in Loch Tay as viewed from the east side of the loch, on the old stone bridge next to the village of Kenmore. Looking very closely at the clump of trees on the island, it is possible to discern the vague remains of some building - possibly the remnants of a priory or a fort. Below the title is a note in brackets which reads, 'Drawn from the North end of the Bridge. The name of the artist is not included. Also known as the Isle of Loch Tay, Priory Island was gifted by Alexander I to the monks of Scone Abbey in 1122, after his wife, Queen Sybilla, died on the island - so it is reputed. It is not clear if the ruins on the island are that of an ancient priory or a fort. It is recorded that the Campbells of Glenorchy built a fort on the island during the sixteenth century, with some of the ruins still remaining. This area of Loch Tay is especially famous for its crannogs..

This detailed drawing shows the east window of Dunblane Cathedral. A note in the bottom right-hand corner reads, 'Elevation of the E window Dunblane cathedral'. Although there is no artist and date attached, it may be the work of Alexander Morton and may date from around 1813. Alexander Morton executed a large number of the drawings that form the Hutton Collection in the 1810s. He is renowned for his floor plans of ecclesiastical buildings, many of which are in the Hutton Collection. If this drawing is indeed by him, it is an unusual and interesting example of his work..

rdf:Description.dc:creator: Columbine, Edward Henry, 1762-1811
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

Elevation of the standing stones at Stenness, Orkney. Edward H. Columbine completed the original drawing in 1792 and then it was copied, probably at Hutton's request in 1802. It captures the suddenness of this feature in the landscape admirably, as the visitor can find the situation of the stones quite arresting. There is another three views of Stenness in the Hutton Drawings, one of is a copy of another of Captain Columbine’s composition. Columbine’s career can be a little difficult to piece together in places. It is known that he work as a hydrographer and captain for the Office of the Admiralty. These drawings, of which there are many copies in the Hutton Drawings, help fill in some of the blanks. He completed many drawings of Orkney and Shetland in 1792 suggesting that he spent at least a season in the north of Scotland..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Lord Ferquhard's Grave Stone at Fearn.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This drawing is dated 19th September 1819, and although not attributed to any artist, is most likely the work of George Henry Hutton himself. The extensive description beneath the title was copied, probably by Hutton, from notes made by a local man named Hugh Ross. This is one of at least nine items relating to Fearn in the Hutton Collection. Ferquhard MacTaggart, called in Scots Gaelic 'Farquhar O'Beolan, Mac an t'Sagairt', was the first Earl of Ross, and is believed to have lived from about 1195 to 1256. He founded Fearn Abbey, dedicated to St Ninian, for the Premonstratensian Order of monks in 1227. In around 1246, the abbey was moved a few miles inland from its original site on the south shore of the Dornoch Firth, to its present location, where Earl Ferquhard was buried after his death..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Interior of the Collegiate Church of Tain in Ross-shire, looking East.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

Interior of St Duthac's Collegiate Church in Tain, Ross-shire. It is dated September 2nd 1819. The page is unsigned by the artist, and it is likely that George Henry Hutton himself made the drawing. Despite not being one of Scotland's most celebrated ecclesiastical buildings, St Duthac's Collegiate Church clearly held a lot of interest for Hutton, and there are at least ten items relating to it in his collection of drawings. This detailed drawing provides an excellent impression of the layout of St Duthac's Collegiate Church. The pulpit is on the right hand side, and much of the space for worshippers in the narrow church appears to be concentrated in split-level galleries. In this drawing the church seems to be intact and in good condition, but it is known that it fell into disrepair some time early in the nineteenth century, and had to be re-roofed and restored in 1877..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Interior of the Cathedral at Kirkwall, Orkney.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Daniell, William, 1769-1837
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

William Daniell drew this sketch, of the interior of St Magnus’ Cathedral, Kirkwall, Orkney, probably in 1818, when he visited the island. Daniell went on to record another two interior sketches and all together there are eight views of the Cathedral to be found in the Hutton Drawings. There has been much speculation over the origins of the architects and masons responsible for the work carried out at the Cathedral. There appear to be strong similarities between the work at Durham Cathedral and Dunfermline Abbey and the architecture in evidence on Orkney. The Cathedral commemorates Earl Rognvald's, martyred uncle, St Magnus. This link was always tenuous but excavations in 1919 discovered a skull high up in the structure of the wall. The skull had split in two, which is the reported manner of Magnus’ death!.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Monks' Tower, Gowrie Castle, Perth.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This drawing is dated 1783 but is unsigned by the artist. This is one of several images relating to the Gowrie House in the Hutton Collection. In each title, its name is 'Gowrie Castle', although the building was a baronial mansion rather than a castle, and went by the name 'Gowrie House'. Situated on the banks of the Tay in the centre of Perth, Gowrie House was the town residence of the Earls of Gowrie, who also owned nearby Ruthven Castle (now Huntingtower Castle). In the seventeenth century the town assumed ownership of Gowrie House, which was demolished in 1809 having served latterly as a military barracks..

rdf:Description.dc:title: North side of St Duthac's Collegiate Church at Tain in Ross-shire.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Shand, James
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This drawing is dated September 25th, 1819, but is unsigned by the artist. The drawing could be the work of James Shand, who was responsible for several views of St Duthac's Collegiate Church in the Hutton Collection, but is it is more likely to be the work of George Henry Hutton himself. St Duthac's Collegiate Church, which was built in 1360, is the most modern of three buildings dedicated to St Duthac in the Ross-shire town of Tain, where Duthac or Duthus is reputed to have been born about 1000. The earliest is a small twelfth-century chapel a few yards south-east the church, which has been derelict since being damaged by fire in 1427. In the north of the town, on a knoll overlooking the Dornoch Firth, is another chapel which was reputedly built to house the relics of St Duthac when they were returned to the town from Ireland, about 1253. These are the three oldest surviving buildings in Tain, although only the collegiate church remains intact..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Loch Tay Priory, north view, July 16, 1789.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This sketch, made in July 1789, shows the island in Loch Tay as viewed from the south side of the loch, next to the village of Kenmore. Looking closely at the island, it is possible to see the remains of buildings. Although the name of the artist has not been included on the drawing, it is quite likely to have been George Hutton himself. The island in this sketch is known as Priory Island and also as Eilean Nam Ban, Sybilla's Island or the Isle Of Loch Tay. The island was gifted by Alexander I of Scotland to the monks of Scone Abbey in 1122, as the burial place of his wife, Queen Sybilla. A fort was built on the island during the sixteenth century by the Campbells of Glenorchy, with some of the ruins still standing. This section of Loch Tay is famous for its crannogs (ancient lake dwellings)..

rdf:Description.dc:title: N. West view of the Cathedral of Kirkwall, Orkney.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Daniell, William, 1769-1837
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This sketch, of St Magnus' Cathedral in Orkney, may be by William Daniell in about 1818. The cruciform shape, rising in levels to the tower is clear in this image. This is one of eight views of the cathedral held in the Hutton Drawings. Daniell, a well-known artist of his day, completed many sketches and drawings of Scottish sites of importance, many of which are now in the Hutton Drawings. He is more famous for his English and Indian landscapes and so these items are a refreshing testament to his skill in representing this countries landscape. How he became involved in adding to Hutton’s Scottish ecclesiastical record, however, is unclear..

rdf:Description.dc:title: North-east view of Torphichen Preceptory, West Lothian.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Knights of St. John of Jerusalem in Scotland
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This sketch, made in June 1807, shows the north-east view of Torphichen Preceptory, which is located in the West Lothian village of Torphichen. Although the name of the artist has not been included on the drawing, it is quite likely to have been Hutton himself. St Ninian established the first church to exist at this site in about 400. King Arthur supposedly visited in 516. King David I of Scotland, meanwhile, founded Torphichen Preceptory, in 1153. The preceptory was the Scottish seat of the Knights Hospitallers or Knights of St John of Jerusalem. The nave, transept and choir date from the thirteenth century, and traces of them still exist. However, very little now remains of the cloister and the domestic buildings, while the preceptory was much altered during the fifteenth century, while the parish church at this site was built in 1756..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Fala Tower on Caik Moor, 1781.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This sketch, drawn in 1781, shows the ruins of Fala Luggie Tower, which is located on Fala Moor, close to the village of Fala, in Midlothian. Although the name of the artist has not been included on the drawing, it is quite likely to have been Hutton himself. While known as Fala 'Tower', this building is likely to be the ruins of a twelfth-century monastery. Built by monks of the Augustinian Order, this monastery was the highest in Britain, at 370 metres above sea level. Built on the site of an ancient Roman road, the monastery was located beside what was then the main land route into Scotland. Fala Tower is mentioned in verse eight (canto IV) of Sir Walter Scott's epic poem, 'The Lay of the Last Minstrel'..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Soutra Hospital, Mid-Lothian, 1784.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This drawing of the remains of Soutra Hospital (or Holy Trinity Hospital of Soutra), now known as Soutra Aisle. is dated 1784 but is unsigned by the artist. This is the only drawing of Soutra Hospital in the Hutton Collection. The remains of the twelfth-century hospital at Soutra are located on a high plain about 12 miles south of Dalkeith in Midlothian. The hospital, which was inhabited by Augustinian monks, provided shelter and assistance for the poor and for people travelling between Edinburgh and the borders, as well as medical care for the sick. Soutra may have been the largest medieval hospital in Scotland. Archaeological excavations of the site in the late twentieth century yielded important information on the types of natural remedies used by the monks..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Perth from the North, 1783.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Smeaton, John, 1724-1792
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This drawing, dated 1783, depicts the Old Bridge over the River Tay at Perth, as viewed from the east bank and looking south. Although the name of the artist has not been included on the drawing, it is quite likely to have been George Hutton himself. The artist who made this drawing would have been standing upriver, looking down towards the bridge, with the city of Perth clearly visible on the right side of the drawing. Indeed, the spire of St John's Church is quite visible to the right of the bridge. Also known as Smeaton's Bridge, the Old Bridge, was built in 1771. It replaced the ferry that had been operating for 150 years - the original bridge having been destroyed in a flood in 1621. The bridge was named after the engineer who built it, John Smeaton, and took four years to construct at a cost of £26,631 - about £2,129,000 in today's terms..

rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This untitled drawing shows the ruins of Sciennes Convent in Edinburgh. The page is undated and the drawing is unsigned by the artist. This is one of two views of Sciennes Convent in the Hutton Collection. As the capital and largest city in medieval Scotland, Edinburgh contained many religious foundations. Sciennes Convent appears to have been one of the less prominent ecclesiastical buildings. Located to the south-east of Edinburgh city centre, it housed an order of Dominican nuns. The name Sciennes may derive from St Catherine of Sienna, after whom the convent took its name..

rdf:Description.dc:title: South door of the Cross Church at Peebles.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This drawing, which is dated 1796, does not carry the name of the artist, and may be one of George Henry Hutton's own works. This is one of eight views of Peebles Cross Church in the Hutton Collection. Many of the images in the Hutton Collection are quite rough sketches, but the fine detail of this suggests the high level of artisanship that was involved in carving the stones for this arched doorway. Arched doorways and windows were particularly popular features of important medieval buildings. The pointed arch, like the type shown here, was the most identifiable feature of the Gothic period of medieval architecture, and began to replace rounded Romanesque arches in Britain in the twelfth century. Peebles Cross Church, founded in 1261, dates from a little later in the Gothic period..

This drawing is one of several different studies of St Duthac's Collegiate Church by James Shand in the Hutton Collection, and is dated September 20th 1815. Tain is thought to be one of the oldest continuous human settlements in Scotland, its name signifying that it may have been the site of a Norse council or parliament. St Duthac, or St Duthus, is reputed to have been born in the town about 1000, and although he died in Ireland, his relics were returned to Tain in 1253, and a small chapel was built near the seashore to house them. Another church dedicated to St Duthac was built in 1360 in the centre of Tain, and became St Duthac's Collegiate Church in 1487..

rdf:Description.dc:title: South-east view of St Magnus’ Cathedral, Kirkwall, Orkney.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This drawing, although unsigned, is dated 1818 and it is one of seven views of the Cathedral held in the Hutton Drawings. The ruins of the Earl's Palace are on the left. Today the modern town centre surrounds both these buildings and the panorama is very different. Rognvald the Earl of Norway founded St Magnus’ Cathedral, the most northern in Great Britain, in 1137. It commemorates the Earl's uncle, Magnus, who had died a martyr in 1117. It stood on a prime piece of shore land, just as much of Kirkwall now sits on reclaimed land, and was an expression of the new Earl’s power. Rognvald, a usurper to his title, attempted to use the building to win support amongst Orkney’s aristocracy..

rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

It is likely that this detailed pencil drawing was made by George Henry Hutton, although it is unsigned. The Hutton Collection contains several drawings of this abbey. The thirteenth-century ruins of Inchaffray Abbey are situated six miles east of Crieff, in what is now the region of Perth and Kinross. The name is derived from the Gaelic, 'Innisabh-reidh', which means 'island of the smooth water'. This is because originally the abbey stood on an island in the centre of a lake which was famous for its eels. The lake has long-since dried up..

rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827

rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This drawing shows the Tron Church, which is located on the Royal Mile, at the junction with North and South Bridges. The name of the artist is not included. It may depict the rebuilding work after both side aisles were removed between 1785 and 1787 during the building of the South Bridge. Named after a salt-tron, which was a public weighing beam, King Charles I founded the Tron Kirk in 1637. The original wooden spire burnt down in 1824, and the church itself closed in 1952, though the building remains open as tourist attraction..

rdf:Description.dc:title: West end of the Cathedral Church of Ross.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

Fortrose Cathedral, Ross-shire. This drawing is dated 19th October 1815, and is one of at least nine images relating to Fortrose Cathedral in the Hutton Collection, most of which date from 1815. It is likely that this is one of George Henry Hutton's own drawings, as no artist is credited on the page. This drawing of the west end of Fortrose Cathedral shows a largely intact western façade containing a gothic-arched double window, and an ornate door. It is likely that this was the main entrance to the cathedral. It was customary in medieval British ecclesiastical buildings for the entrance to be at the opposite end from the altar, which Mosaic law dictated should be in the east. The gothic arch is a distinctive marker of medieval Christian religious buildings from the start of the twelfth century onwards..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Collegiate Church and Castle of Tullibardine, south aspect, 1789.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This drawing is dated 1789, but is not attributed to any artist, and may be one of George Henry Hutton's own drawings. This is the only image relating to Tullibardine in the Hutton Collection, and shows the medieval church among trees in the middle ground, while the tower house of Tullibardine Castle is to the right of the church in the distance. Tullibardine Collegiate Church lies just outside the village of Tullibardine, approximately six miles south-east of Crieff. It was founded in 1446 by Sir David Murray of Tullibardine, an ancestor of the Dukes of Atholl. In the year of its foundation the church also became the last resting place of Sir David, who died shortly after building had begun. The ruins of the Castle were demolished around 1833..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Elevations of the Old Church of Tain.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Shand, James
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This sheet contains detailed drawings of the east and west elevations of St Duthac's Collegiate Church, which were drawn by James Shand. Shand was responsible for two ground-plans and a number of architectural drawings of this site in the Hutton Collection. The drawings on this page were made on September 20th, 1815. Shand's drawings appear to show two doors in each of the two facades, leading to different levels in the church. Quite unusually for a medieval foundation, the main entrance to St Duthac's is towards the south. St Duthac's was built in 1360, and in ecclesiastical buildings of that age it was more common for the entrance to be at the west end of the church or chapel, opposite the altar, which Mosaic law dictated should be built in the east..
rdf:Description.dc:isVersionOf: Electronic reproduction of: Elevations of the Old Church of Tain. 1 item ; 24.00 x 24.50 cm.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Plan of the Abbey Church of Fearn.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Shand, James
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This ground-plan is by Mr James Shand, and dated 1815. Shand was responsible for two plans of Fearn Abbey in the Hutton Collection, both originating in the same year. This is the less heavily annotated of the two, and appears to be more concerned with a general description of the abbey and its surroundings than with the dimensions and locations of individual details in the building. George Henry Hutton appears to have been very interested in Fearn Abbey, accumulating at least nine different items relating to the site in his antiquarian researches. Although today it is not one of the better known monastic sites in Scotland, Fearn has a fascinating and sometimes macabre history, which includes a strong association with Patrick Hamilton, Scotland's first Protestant martyr, and a structural collapse in 1742, which caused many fatalities and was apparently prophesied by the Brahan Seer..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Ground-plan of the Parish Church of Tain, and buildings therewith connected.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Shand, James
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This plan was made by James Shand and is one of two plans of the church by this draughtsman in the Hutton Collection. This plan, dated 1815, is the earlier of the two, the other having been made in 1819. Shand's plans of St Duthac's Collegiate Church are just two of quite a number of items relating to Tain in the Hutton Collection. This ground-plan is produced in finer detail than some of the plans of other sites in the Hutton Collection, which comprise little more than a rough outline and some approximate dimensions. Shand's work, by contrast, is annotated with a list of references, which identify and describe highlighted features on the ground plan, such as doors, windows, sets of stairs and the pulpit..

This page starts 'Comd. In Mr Stirling's letter of the 23 Novr, 1826'. Mr Stirling is probably William M. Stirling, who was the parish minister at Port of Menteith, on the shore of the Lake of Menteith. Stirling is responsible for several drawings and sketches of Inchmahome Priory in the Hutton Collection. The note beneath the drawing, which was probably written by Stirling, reads: 'Transverse Section of the Three Pillars supporting the Four Arches in Priory of Inchmahome. There is, of course, half the above figure at either extremity of the Row of Arches'..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Elevations of St Magnus’ Cathedral, Kirkwall, Orkney.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

These elevations are depictions of the cathedral of St Magnus on Orkney. Although they have no draughtsman’s name attached, James Stewart communicated them to Hutton in 1789. There are a further seven views of the Abbey held in the Hutton Drawings. Work on the Cathedral started in 1137, the project being an attempt to win the islanders over. Earl Rognvald the patron had usurped the title from Earl Paul and had him killed on the mainland in Caithness. Rognvald's had already spent most of his finances on his campaign and so the building work progressed slowly. Eventually he had to yield some of his rights to Orkney's tenant farmers, in return for payment. This allowed the work to be completed..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Elevations of the Carmelite Church, South Queensferry.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Morton, Alexander, of Dunfermline, active 1813-1817
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

There is no general title included on this sheet. The first drawing says, 'Elevation of Old Carmelite Church - South Queensferry by Mr Alex. Morton'. The second reads, 'Perspective view of the Carmelite Church / South-Queensferry from S.E'. This is one of two architectural drawings made of this building by Alexander Morton, the other being dated 1813. Morton was a prolific recorder of ecclesiastical monuments in this area. George Dundas established this Carmelite house in 1330. It was not until his descendant James Dundas, in 1440, gifted this site and the surrounding lands to the house, however, that they gained a permanent home and source of wealth. The Dundas family dedicated the House to the Virgin Mary, the order's patron, in order to pray for the family. It would have formed a vital and important stage of the pilgrimage to St Andrews and Dunfermline Abbey..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Plan of Edinburgh and Leith with the roads adjacent.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Bonnar, Thomas, cartographer
Craig, J. (John), engraver in Edinburgh
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

Made in 1811, this engraved plan of Edinburgh provides a glimpse of the city's layout during the late-Georgian era. The well-structured layout of the Georgian New Town, north of Princes Street, contrasts notably with the relative chaos of the Old Town in the area to the east of the castle. The fact that Leith and Portobello are separate places also stands out. Thomas Bonnar drew, and J. Craig engraved, the plan..

A note under the left hand side of the engraving reads, 'Drawn by Genl. Hutton for the Portfolio, & Engd. by J. & H.S. Storer'. On the right hand side a note reads, 'Pubd. By Sherwood & Co, Augt. 1, 1823'. The Collection also includes another Hutton drawing of Gowrie House, which dates from 1783, one of a series of studies Hutton made of the building. The house, which overlooked the Tay in the centre of Perth, disappeared in 1809. It had been the town residence of the Earls of Gowrie until the early seventeenth century..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Gowry House, Perthshire (looking east).
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Storer, James, 1771-1853
Sherwood & Co
Storer, Henry Sargant, 1795-1837
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827

rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

A note under the left hand side of the engraving reads, 'Drawn by Genl. Hutton for the Portfolio, & Engd. by J. & H. Storer'. On the right hand side a note reads, 'Pubd. by Sherwood & Co, Augt. 1, 1823'. The engravers, James Sargant Storer and Henry Sargant Storer, father and son, were leaders in their field, and appear to have produced a great deal of work for a publication by Sherwood called 'The Portfolio' around this time. The Hutton Collection contains several images of Gowrie House, mostly unsigned drawings dated about 1783. It is likely that Hutton drew these and the original drawing from which this engraving came at the same time. Gowrie House was demolished in 1809, which means that the drawing must have predated the 1823 publication of the portfolio, and the soldiers and artillery depicted here suggest a 1783 origin, as Gowrie House served as a military barracks at this time..

rdf:Description.dc:title: South east prospect of the town of Perth taken from Wood End.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Murray, Charlotte, Lady, 1754-1808
Robertson, Alexander
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This engraving shows a view of Perth, as viewed from Wood End. A note on the lower left-hand side names the engraver as A. Robertson. It is also inscribed to Lady Charlotte Murray by Alexander Murray. No date has been included. This engraving certainly represents Perth as a busy place, with a number of small merchant ships visible on the River Tay, and men working in the field in the foreground. The Old Bridge, also known as Smeaton's Bridge, can be seen on the right of the engraving, while the spire of St John's Kirk dominates the city's skyline. In short, the engraving is very much a mixture of urban and rural landscapes - an accurate reflection of Perth's hybrid identity..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Ground plan of the Parish Church of Fearn.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Shand, James
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This plan is dated 1815, and is attributed to James Shand, who was also responsible for another plan of the building in the Hutton Collection. In his note under the title, Shand goes on to explain that the parish church incorporates the remains of the medieval Abbey of Fearn This is the more detailed of Shand's two ground-plans of Fearn Abbey. A scale of feet is included, and individual details in the construction of the building, such as gothic windows, are tagged with letters and explained in an extensive key at the foot of the page. Shand has also developed a system of different shadings to indicate which parts of the drawn outline represent complete walls, incomplete walls or foundations..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Ground plan of the Priory of Inchmahome in Perthshire.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Stirling, William MacGregor
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This plan was 'drawn 8th June 1826'. It is signed by William MacGregor Stirling, Parish minister at Port of Menteith, who made several drawings of Inchmahome Priory for Hutton. A note by Stirling above his signature reads: 'To Lieutenant General Henry Hutton This sketch of the present state of the priory of Inchmahome (drawn from pacing only, but with a minute attention to existing phenomena)'. The details and 'existing phenomena' noted by Stirling include the approximate dimensions of the building in paces, the state of repair of walls, windows, doors and arches, the locations of the different rooms in the priory complex, and the locations of tombs and identities of those interred within them..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Fortrose, 1815.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This incomplete sketch is of the interior of Fortrose Cathedral, Ross-shire. As it does not carry the name of the artist, it is likely that this was one of George Henry Hutton's own drawings. There are at least nine images relating to Fortrose Cathedral in the Hutton Collection, and most, like this example, date from 1815. The interior part of Fortrose Cathedral shown by this sketch appears to contain an arched monument. There are three such monuments in the ruins of Fortrose Cathedral. All that remains of the building today is part of the south aisle, part of the chapter house and its vaulted undercroft, and the chapel, although the foundations of the rest of the complex are clearly visible in the cathedral grounds. It is likely that the cathedral was in a similar state of disrepair in Hutton's time, as it had fallen into disuse by the seventeenth century, and was largely dismantled by Cromwellian soldiers and locals seeking building stone..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Cross about 3 miles from Perth in the road to Hunting Tower.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Grose, Francis, 1731?-1791
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This drawing is dated June 1790, and may be the work of Francis Grose, an author, antiquary and artist who was responsible for a number of drawings in the Hutton Collection. There are no annotations on the page to suggest what the monument might represent, or whom it might commemorate. 'Hunting Tower', or Huntingtower Castle, is the modern name for Ruthven Castle, the country seat of the Ruthven family, who held the Earldom of Gowrie until their titles and lands were forfeited by James VI in the early seventeenth century. The castle passed to the ownership of the crown and was renamed Huntingtower. The restored castle is today a well-known landmark on the western outskirts of Perth..

rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

Notes relating to the remains of a monastery or priory on Loch Tay, dated October 7th 1820. Although the page is unsigned, the notes appear to be in George Henry Hutton's handwriting. Hutton collected a number of images and other pieces of information relating to the ruined ecclesiastical foundation on Priory Island in Loch Tay. The notes shown here begin: 'The Ruins, consisting of four Apartments, are extremely plain and do not appear to be very old. The largest apartment (the second from the East) has been lighted by windows on both the North & South sides, & is supposed to have been the Chapel, in the N.W. angle of which human bones have been found.' The author continues by explaining that Priory Island is reputed to have been the last resting place of Queen Sybilla, the wife of Alexander I of Scotland..

Notes to annotated ground-plan of Fortrose Cathedral, Ross-shire. It is the second page of a plan of Fortrose Cathedral in the Hutton Collection drawn by John McQueen. The page is a continuation of a list of references begun on the previous page. The numbers and letters to which the different paragraphs refer denote parts of the cathedral marked on the ground-plans on the previous page. The top section of this page, consisting of six sets of figures, numbered one to six, gives the measurements of the different windows in Fortrose Cathedral. The bottom section, which is numbered 'f' to 'n' in the margin, describes some of the subtler physical features of the cathedral, such as carved niches and hollows in the walls, and stonework of different ages..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Present and old Church of Crichton.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Morton, Alexander, of Dunfermline, active 1813-1817
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

Alexander Morton, who drew many plans of Scottish church buildings during the early 1800s, made this plan of Crichton Collegiate Church, Gorebridge, Midlothian, in May 1817. The Roman numerals included on the plan correspond with the numbered list on the left side of the drawing, and indicate the rooms and main areas of the building. The exact dimensions of each room and area are also included on the drawing. William Crichton, Lord Chancellor of Scotland, founded Crichton Collegiate Church in 1449. Located near the ruins of Crichton Castle, by the village of Crichton, the church is in the memory of St Mary, St Mungo and St Kentigern. Unusually, the church had no nave. The church returned to its former splendour in 1898..

rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This sheet is a copy of a sketch of St Mary's Church, Banff, by the Reverend J. Cordiner. It is not dated but from the appearance of the church, Cordiner probably drew the original before 1797. In this year, large parts of the church in Cordiner's sketch were considered dangerous and so pulled down. The south aisle remained intact. The Hutton Collection contains three other views of St Mary's Church in Banff, one of which, by William Hay from 1815, shows the church after demolition. St Mary's Church dates from 1471. It stood close to the mouth of the River Deveron, to the south-east of the old castle of Banff and east of the town's medieval market-place. Structurally, the main body of the church was a simple rectangle, but a short vaulted aisle extended from the south wall of the church, and was the burial place of the Ogilvie family of Banff, a local branch of a prominent Scots noble family..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Priory of the Isle of Oronsay from Pennant's Tour.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Pennant, Thomas, 1726-1798
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This drawing and a description of Oronsay Priory, Argyllshire, is a copy of a description and illustration of the priory of Oronsay in Thomas Pennant's 'A Tour in Scotland and Voyage to the Hebrides', published in 1774-6. The description begins on the reverse of the sheet, The first priory on Oronsay is believed to have been founded in AD 563 by the Celtic saint Oran, after whom the island is named. The priory re-established, in about 1340, for an order of Augustinian monks, by one of the Lords of the Isles. Although abandoned after the Reformation of 1560, substantial parts of the priory and its grounds remain almost intact. The most remarkable relic of the priory is the fifteenth-century Oronsay Cross, which stands within the grounds, engraved with Romano-Celtic designs and an image of Christ. Other stones carved with Celtic designs are also in the priory grounds..
