Detail from Seton Collegiate Church, East Lothian. This rubbing was taken from a stone in Seton Collegiate Church, East Lothian. A note at the bottom left-hand corner reads, 'Inscription at the West end of the Col. Ch. Of Seton - 29 Sept 1802. Ave Maria?' Whilst it is very difficult to see any inscription in this particular rubbing, the artist has suggested it reads 'Ave Maria'. The Hutton Collection includes a number of other drawings and plans relating to Seton Collegiate Church. These range from an external view of the church to sketches of armorial bearings, decorative details and tombstones. Unlike many of the other churches and abbeys, Seton Collegiate Church has survived the ravages of time and remains largely intact..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Bell from Holywood Abbey, Dumfriesshire.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

Untitled drawing showing a large bell that belonged to Holywood Abbey, three miles north of Dumfries, in Dumfriesshire. Although the identity of the artist is unknown, it is likely that it was Hutton himself. The drawing dates from around 1811. There were two surviving bells from the abbey, and they are still in the local parish church. The Hutton Collection also contains a drawing of this other bell. Built in an English Gothic style, Holywood Abbey dates back to around 1180. Before the abbey, however, the site appears to have been the home of a monk called Congall. Indeed, 'the oak wood of Congall' is one of the early names for the site where the abbey is located. Premonstratensians inhabited the now ruined Abbey. This Order, which was a mixture of the monastic and canonical, originally came from Laon in France..

This plan was drawn by Alexander Morton in 1817; It shows a detailed plan of the interior of Dunbar Collegiate Church. Morton has included a numerical key highlighting the different areas of the church, along with individual measurements and a scale. Two years after Alexander Morton drew these plans, the construction of Dunbar Parish Church commenced on the site of the old Collegiate Church. Morton's plan, therefore, offers an insight into the interior of an important ecclesiastical building that no longer exists. Founded in the early fourteenth century, Dunbar Collegiate Church was the first Collegiate Church in the Lothians, if not in the whole of Scotland..

Hutton, George Henry, -1827

John Gilleson made this plan of Dunglass Collegiate Church in 1822. Each room and area of the church has a detailed description of its history and general layout. Although there is some argument over the founder of the Collegiate Church at Dunglass, most historians now consider that it was due to the generosity of Sir Alexander Hume of Hume or Home. It is likely that the tower and choir date from 1450, with the nave being added a short time later. Although the Pope gave permission to convert Dunglass into a collegiate church, this never happened..

rdf:Description.dc:creator: Duff, Patrick, of Elgin
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This is a sketched plan of Elgin Cathedral, Moray 'by Mr P. Duff, Dec 1815'. This is probably Patrick Duff, who published 'Sketch of the Geology of Moray', in 1842. He has included a table at the bottom that gives the areas of different parts of the cathedral in square links. The Hutton Collection contains a number of other drawings of Elgin Cathedral. Elgin Cathedral, dating from 1244, was the seat of the Bishops of Moray. It stands on a site dedicated to the Holy Trinity. It had a turbulent history, including torching by the 'Wolf of Badenoch', Alexander Stewart, in 1390, as retribution for the then bishop's excommunication of him. It was restored but fell into disrepair after the Reformation and was only saved from total ruin when, eventually, the Government began maintaining it as a monument..

Allan, Mr., draftsman

This plan is signed 'Mr ___ Allan' and is dated 1805. There is a similar plan, dating from 1789, by W. Whyte. The reference key to the right of the drawing gives a good idea of the original uses the Cistercian monks made of the buildings at Deer Abbey, which they would have long since abandoned at the time this plan was drawn. As well as the usual ecclesiastical buildings such as 'The Kirk', and the 'Monk's Cells', there was a kiln, offices, a mill and a lodge for the porter, or caretaker..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Cross in the cemetery at Kilkerran Church, Campbeltown, Argyllshire.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This drawing shows an inscription that appears on a cross or headstone in the graveyard at Kilkerran Church in Campbeltown, Argyllshire. A note at the top of the page dates the drawing from August 1802, and says that, 'Two small fragments only remain of the church'. At the foot of the page, the artist adds that the names 'McEacherne' and 'McEachern' appear frequently. The old Kilkerran Cemetery is located just outside of Campbeltown, on the foot of the Mull of Kintyre peninsula. The church and graveyard commemorates St Ciaran, an Irish missionary and a friend of St Columba, who came to Kintyre during the sixth century. The cemetery was a royal burial ground, with many of the Kings of Dalriada interred here. The ruins of the church were still visible until around 1870..

rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827

Detail from Ardchattan Priory, Argyllshire, again dated September 1820, and including measurements for the width and length. It has six carved figures, male and female, in decorative niches, and a Latin inscription around the edge. The artist has also included the note 'The inscription communicated by Gen. Campbell in 1803'. Founded in the thirteenth century by Duncan MacDougall, Ardchattan Priory was one of three houses in Scotland belonging to the Valliscaulian Order; the other two being Pluscarden and Beauly. Whilst King Alexander II founded Pluscarden, laymen founded Beauly and Ardchattan. Monks remained at Ardchattan until the mid-sixteenth century, after which the priory and its lands belonged to the Campbell family..

Drawing from Luffness Friary, East Lothian. This drawing shows the remains of a damaged tombstone in the ruins of Luffness Friary, near Aberlady. The artist has included inscriptions and much of the decorative detail on the stone. Although a date has not been included, it was probably drawn in 1802 - the same year 'Bickerton's Tomb' was sketched. The Hutton Collection includes the rough sketch and drawing of 'Bickerton's Tomb', which lies close to the remains of the high altar in the north-east corner of the monastery. It is said to be the resting place of the monastery's founder, Sir David de Lindsay, who presented the land to the Carmelites in the thirteenth century..

rdf:Description.dc:creator: Columbine, Edward Henry, 1762-1811

Colour wash drawing of a ‘church’ at Iona, 'from a sketch by Capt. Columbine'. The ‘church’ may be unnamed but it looks like the Abbey tower. Captain Columbine worked in the area and drew other Iona monuments in 1792. There are nine views of Iona in the Hutton Collection. Edward Henry Columbine (c.1760-1811), worked in the Royal Navy between 1790 and 1803, mainly as a hydrographer, eventually attaining the ranks of Lieutenant and then Captain. During his career, he was involved in official Board of Admiralty investigations. Although charged with the loss of the ship the Soleby, he won an acquittal and went on to complete major surveys along the west coast of Africa. He died travelling home from Africa, of a fever, in June 1811..

Colour drawing of Beauly panorama, Ross-shire. A note explains that the view of the priory is largely obscured by Fraser of Lovat's new store house and that the drawing was completed looking out of the window. Beauly Priory is visible in the distance, across the bay. Beauly Priory sits at the heart of Beauly town. This sheet alludes to the new building work by Mr Fraser of Lovat and thirty-eight years later, the Baron of Lovat laid out a new town square around the priory. So for its importance to the local community, time has not stood still in this flourishing northern town..

This plan was drawn by Alexander Morton in 1817, and shows Yester Church. Morton has included a compass and scale, along with individual measurements and a brief reference highlighting significant areas of the interior. Morton's plan is most likely of Yester Chapel, which is in the grounds of Yester House, near Gifford, East Lothian. Previously known as the Collegiate Church of St Cuthbert, Yester Chapel was the local place of worship until a new parish church was built in Gifford in the early-eighteenth century. Following this move, the Hay family had the Adam brothers remodel the chapel's exterior and used it as a family chapel and mausoleum..

A note below this coloured sketch reads, 'This view shows the North Aisle of the church, Aug 1802'. There is no name attached to this sheet. Saddell Abbey covers a wide area, up to Saddell Water, represented by the blue in the picture. Somerled, King of the Isles, and St Malachy of Mellifont, Ireland, who was on his way to Rome founded Saddell Abbey in 1148. Somerled’s son, Reginald, completed the establishment of this Cistercian house when he came to power. The Irish influence of the original monks is visible in the Celtic symbolism present in the stone carvings..

This is a drawing of a stone from Ardchattan Priory, Argyllshire, dated September 1820, and including measurements. The stone has inscriptions and a carved figure in an attitude of prayer. A note underneath the titles suggests that the stone is not in its original location. Duncan MacDougall founded Ardchattan in 1231. Dedicated to St Mary and John the Baptist, it was one of three houses in Scotland belonging to the Valliscaulian Order: the other two being Beauly and Pluscarden. Located in a sheltered spot on the banks of Loch Etive, near Oban, Argyllshire, the monks famously cultivated a beautiful garden in the grounds of the priory..

This painting shows the ruins of the thirteenth-century Abbey of St Mary of Deer and is one of a series of drawings in the Hutton Collection that show different views of the abbey. An unknown artist dates it 7th March 1796. There is another similar drawing in the Hutton Collection, likely by the same artist, of the same view, dated 1819. Deer Abbey is in Aberdeenshire, about one mile from the village of Old Deer and one and a half miles from Mintlaw in the north-east of Scotland. The monks at Deer were Cistercians, called 'white monks' because of the long white robes they wore. The abbey fell into disrepair when it was abandoned in the seventeenth century..

A scale, in chains and links, has been included below the title in this plan, and there is a key at the bottom left, denoting the uses for various buildings. W. Whyte, author of the plan, has signed his name in the bottom right corner. The Hutton Collection contains a similar plan, dating from 1805, by 'Mr ___ Allan'. At the time of this survey, the monks would have abandoned the abbey. It is clear from this plan that the community was well-organised. As well as the usual ecclesiastical buildings, there was a school, a mill, and note 'f' reads, 'a lead pipe was found in this Direction', which suggests they had some form of water supply in place..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Sculpted heraldic symbols from Coupar Angus Abbey, Perthshire.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Mitchell, William, mason
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This sheet does not carry a title, but contains sketches of two heraldic symbols, each accompanied by explanatory notes. Beneath the drawings, Hutton has added a note, which reads: 'Recd. (2d Decr. 1820) from Mr William Mitchell, Mason, Coupar Angus, with his plan of the abbey'. In another drawing in his collection, Hutton has referred to the same man as Mr John Mitchell, so doubt remains over which was his name. The notes that accompany these sketches are not clear, but the top sketch appears to be a coat of arms that belonged to the Campbell family, who were Dukes of Greenock. It says that the Campbell's title and coats of arms have subsequently altered. The engravings may have been included in the abbey's masonry as dedications to people and families that had been benefactors of the Coupar Cistercians..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Old Abbey of North Berwick.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Morton, Alexander, of Dunfermline, active 1813-1817
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This plan, of St Mary's Priory, North Berwick, was drawn by Alexander Morton in 1817. It details the interior of St Mary's Priory. Morton has not only recorded individual measurements on his plan, but has also included a compass and scale. A handwritten note above the title is difficult to decipher. St Mary's Priory has had a long and colourful history dating back to its foundation in the twelfth century. Pillaged during the turbulent reign of King James III (1452-88), order was restored for a number of years before the nunnery was again pillaged and burnt in 1529. It is interesting to note that the devastation in 1529 occurred around thirty years before the Reformation had reached Scotland..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Dimensions of the Coll. Church of Beaulieu.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

Annotated ground plan of Beauly Priory, Inverness-shire. The title of this plan appears to be 'Dimensions of the Coll. Church of Beaulieu', although there was no collegiate church in Beauly. It is likely that the plan is of Beauly Priory, which features in a number of other drawings and sketches in the Hutton Collection. Someone appears to have written the annotations slightly later, in a firmer hand and obscuring parts of the plan of the priory. The artist's surname is given as Hogg, and the plan is dated 1815. Today most of the thirteenth-century Beauly Priory is in an advanced state of ruin. The priory originally housed Valliscaulian monks, but in 1510 changed its adherence and adopted Cistercian principles. After the Reformation of 1560, it fell into disuse, and became merely a source of materials for other buildings in the village of Beauly. The north transept, rebuilt in 1901 as a mausoleum for the Mackenzie family, remains intact today..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Aberdeen Cathedral. W. View.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This is a sketch of the west façade of St Machar's Cathedral, Aberdeen, from a sketch by the Rev. J. Cordiner. It is not dated. The Hutton Collection also contains another sketch of the west façade of St Machar's Cathedral, by Mr G. Smith. These are two of a number of different perspectives of the interior and exterior of the cathedral collected by George Henry Hutton. Cordiner's sketch reveals more of the detail of the cathedral's west façade than Smith’s does, where cottages and trees in the foreground obscure much of the building. As was traditional in medieval church foundations, the main entrance to the cathedral is in the west wall, and above the doors, instead of one large window, the stonemason has constructed seven narrow, candle-shaped windows known as 'lights'..

Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827

The plan of Gullane Church was drawn in 1817. The plan of Dunbar Friary is entitled 'Remains of the Monastery of Friars at Dunbar' and is dated 1816. Both are by Alexander Morton and include compasses, scales and various measurements. A large number of the plans that form part of the Hutton Collection were drawn by Alexander Morton in the 1810s. Little appears to be known about him. It is possible he lived or had offices in Dunfermline as he often wrote the name of the town alongside his signature. A number of the other plans he was responsible for in this area include St Mary's Priory and St Andrew's Church in North Berwick, Dirleton Collegiate Church and Dunbar Collegiate Church..

This is a sketch of the south-east aspect of Kilmun Collegiate Church, Argyllshire, dated August 1802, but unsigned. It is likely to be one of Hutton's own sketches. This is one of several drawings and sketches of Kilmun contained in the Hutton Collection and, beneath the title, there is a note that reads 'See the more finished sketch'. This is a reference to another sketch in the collection, also from the south-east, but that shows the church, tower and surrounding countryside in more detail..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Beauly Priory - north.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hog, Mr., of Beauly
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

Sketched ground-plan of Beauly Priory, Inverness-shire, entitled 'Beauly Priory - North'. It dates from August 1815, and the artist is 'Mr ______ Hog of Beauly'. This is one of several sketches and drawings from Beauly contained in the Hutton Collection, and describe the church at Beauly Priory, whose ruins are the only substantial remains of what was once a large priory complex. The dimensions of the building and of each individual window and door are on the plan. The locations of gardens and orchards in the priory grounds are also given. Beauly Priory is located at the east end of the main square of Beauly in Easter Ross. The village grew up around the priory, founded in the 1230s by Valliscaulian Monks from the French region of Burgundy. In the early sixteenth century, the adherence of the priory changed to the Cistercian order, but after the Reformation of 1560, it fell into disuse, and became a source of stone for other buildings in the village..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Ruin at North Berwick.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Morton, Alexander, of Dunfermline, active 1813-1817
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827

This plan, drawn by Alexander Morton in 1816, shows the remains of St Andrew's Church, North Berwick. Morton has included North Berwick Harbour and the Firth of Forth, and a scale and compass. Located to the east of the harbour, St Andrew's Church stood on an area of land that was once a small island; cut off from the mainland at high tide, it could be reached on foot at low tide. The church itself is thought to date from the twelfth century, although an even earlier date is possible. Another drawing in the Hutton Collection shows an imaginary reconstruction of the church..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Oblique view of the remains of the Collegiate Church of Kilmun.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

These are sketches of the remains of Kilmun Collegiate Church, Argyllshire, with notes. The sheet is undated and unsigned. The sketches include views and dimensions of the west and south sides of the square tower, and of the choir of the original collegiate church, which later became a new parish church. The west wall of the square tower measures 44½ feet at its highest point. The remains of the south wall are 32 feet in height, and the breadth of each wall is 20 feet. The thickness of the walls is 4½ feet. The ruined part of the old church was 40½ feet in length, and the remaining portion, which became the new church, was 40 feet in length..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Rough plan of Saddell Abbey.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This rough plan of Saddell Abbey, dated 18th August 1802, includes measurements and extensive notes regarding the abbey and the people buried in its grounds. According to the information provided, the building existed more or less in its entirety until 1766, when the proprietor 'took down a great part of it'. There are further drawings of Saddell Abbey and its interior in the Hutton Collection. Saddell Abbey stands close to the 'Alt nan Manach', or the 'Stream of the Monks', in Saddell Glen, Kintyre. Founded in the twelfth century by Somerled, Lord of the Isles, and completed by his son Reginald, Saddell Abbey was home to members of the Cistercian Order. Also known as 'white monks', the Cistercians lived a very austere and isolated existence, largely devoting their time to prayer and hard physical labour..

Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

Plan of Seton Collegiate Church, East Lothian. A note in the top left-hand corner reads, 'See Morton's Plan'. This refers to a plan of Seton Collegiate Church by Alexander Morton that also forms part of the Hutton Collection. Measurements have been recorded in paces and the different areas of the church have been identified. As the note in the top-right corner of the plan confirms, the proprietor at this time was the Earl of Wemyss. Originally, the property of the Seton family, the church along with the Seton estates was eventually acquired by the Earl of Wemyss, who partially restored the church and used it as the family mausoleum. Seton Collegiate Church is now cared for by Historic Scotland and is open to the public..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Cloister gate of the Church of St Mary, Dryburgh Abbey.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Buchan, David Stewart Erskine, Earl of, 1742-1829
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

A note beneath the title of this watercolour reads, 'This rude sketch done from memory to show the effect is presented to Lieut. Hutton by his obliged humble servant, Buchan. Dryburgh Abbey Jan 1. 1789'. It is one of four views of Dryburgh Abbey contained in the Hutton Collection, two of which are the work of David Stewart Erskine, 11th Earl of Buchan, who acquired the remains of the abbey in 1786. Dryburgh Abbey sits in a loop of the River Tweed a few hundred yards to the north of the village of St Boswells in Berwickshire. Hugh de Moreville, the Constable of Scotland, who invited the Premonstratensians, or Order of White Canons, to build and inhabit the abbey, founded it in 1150. Although the abbey was never particularly influential in Scottish religious or political life, English forces attacked it on several occasions, and it eventually fell into disuse after the Reformation of 1560..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Cowey Church near Stoneharbour, Kincardineshire.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

Watercolour sketch of Cowie Church, near Stonehaven, Kincardineshire. The writing below this watercolour sketchreads, 'Reduced, Cowey Church near Stoneharbour, Kincardineshire'. The painting is unsigned by the artist (possibly Hutton himself), but is dated June 15th, 1790. This is the only image relating to Cowie or Stonehaven in the Hutton Collection. The name 'Stoneharbour' in the picture's title was probably a mistake, as Stonehaven does not appear to ever been that. Cowie, a village roughly a kilometre north-east of Stonehaven town centre, was, until the sixteenth century, a more significant settlement than Stonehaven, and was chartered as a burgh of barony. Cowie Church may date from at least the thirteenth century, and its remains, and its graveyard, are still there today..

A watercolour sketch of Elgin Cathedral, Moray; no other information is given. The Hutton Collection contains four other drawings pertaining to Elgin Cathedral, by various artists. In its heyday, Elgin Cathedral was the largest and most impressive building of its kind after St Andrews. Founded in 1224, it is now a magnificent ruin, managed by Historic Scotland. It boasts a fine octagonal vaulted chapter house, a Pictish cross slab, a large stone statue of a bishop, and table tombs in its burial ground..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Aberbrothick Abbey, Angusshire.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

A watercolour of Arbroath Abbey, Angus, this painting shows the remnants of the main building. It says ‘5 July 1790’, and is identified as number 11. The red sandstone used in the construction of the abbey is quite distinct in this drawing. It came from the cliffs located in the north-east area of the town The ruined towers probably formed the west end of the abbey's nave. King William the Lion founded Arbroath Abbey in 1178. Initially set up for a group of monks of the Order of Tiron (an offshoot of the Benedictine Order), the abbey is famous as the location where the Scottish nobles signed the Declaration of Arbroath in 1320, which proclaimed Scotland's right to self-determination..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Ruin at Gullan E. Lothian.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Cocking, Thomas, active approximately 1783-1791
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This watercolour drawing of St Andrew's Church, Gullane, East Lothian, was painted around 1791 by Thomas Cocking, 'Captain Grose's assistant'. Captain Grose was most likely Captain Francis Grose, the celebrated antiquarian and author of 'The Antiquities of Scotland', which was published in 1791. The artist has chosen to show the interior of the church, including the remains of a decorative archway. This watercolour is very likely of the twelfth-century parish church of St Andrew's, Gullane. In 1612, St Andrew's was abandoned and the parish church moved to the village of Dirleton. This was partly in response to the heavy sandstorms that plagued Gullane at this time. With its isolated and exposed location, the church was particularly vulnerable to the storms..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Ruins of the monastery of Failfurd from the west.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827

R. Taylor painted this watercolour of Fail Monastery, Ayrshire in 1800. This is one of three views of Fail Monastery in the Hutton Collection. Taylor's painting shows a ruined section of the Monastery of Fail in the foreground, and the background, the rolling wooded hills north of the valley of the River Ayr. The monastery was founded in 1252 by Trinitarian or Red Friars, on a site where the Water of Fail meets the Ayr, about two miles south-east of Tarbolton. The monastery was not one of the more prominent in Scotland, but a satirical rhyme implying that the monks are hypocrites has survived, and reads: 'The Friars of Fail made gude kail / On Fridays when they fasted; / And they never wanted gear enough / As long as their neighbour's lasted'..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Collegiate Church near Hamilton Palace.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Cocking, Thomas, active approximately 1783-1791
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This watercolour painting is by 'Capt. Grose's assistant', i.e. Thomas Cocking. It is dated '1747 or 1748', and is one of four views of Hamilton Collegiate Church contained in the Hutton Collection. 'Capt. Grose', who’s assistant is credited, as the artist of the painting, is a reference to Francis Grose (c.1731-91), like Hutton an English soldier and antiquary, and the author of books on the antiquities of Scotland, England and Wales. Hamilton Palace was the seat of the Dukes of Hamilton, and was begun in the late-eighteenth century in the grounds of Cadzow Castle, family home of the Barons of Cadzow who were ancestors of the Hamiltons. The collegiate church had been founded on an adjoining site in 1450-1, but apart from the transept shown in this painting, was demolished in the eighteenth century as Hamilton Palace was extended to become one of the grandest stately homes in Britain. The Palace was itself demolished in 1922 after subsidence caused by mine workings had rendered it unsafe..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Rothesay Castle in Bute.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Columbine, Edward Henry, 1762-1811
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

A note following the title of this watercolour reads, ' From a drawing made by Capt. Columbine in 1792'. Captain Columbine (c.1760-1811) was first a hydrographer, although as demonstrated here he was also an artist. This watercolour copies one of his drawings and shows Rothesay Castle within its natural surroundings. Rothesay Castle stands in the centre of the town of Rothesay, on the island of Bute. Whilst the present ruin dates from the early-thirteenth century, it is probable that a castle has stood on this site since the late-eleventh century. Famous for its water-filled moat and rather unusual circular wall, the castle is also well-known for its long association with the Stewart family..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Two drawings of the Boatsford Stone, Nithsdale, Dumfriesshire.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Grose, Francis, 1731?-1791
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This page contains two drawing of the Boatsford Stone, which is located in Nithsdale, Dumfriesshire. A note at the foot of the drawing states that it was 'presented to me by the late Capt. [Francis] Grose', who wrote the book, 'The Antiquities of Scotland', which was published in 1791. Grose probably made this drawing in or around 1790. Both drawings are rich in detail and perfectly capture the ornate decorations of the stone. The fact that there are two drawings suggests that these are front and rear elevation illustrations of the stone. Sadly, there does not seem to be much general information available concerning the Boatsford Stone..

rdf:Description.dc:creator: Gilleson, John
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This sketch depicts the remains of the original stone arch of the Church of St Mary, in Dumbarton. A note at the foot of the page states that the sketch was from a Mr John Gilleson on the 26th of March 1822. It adds that, 'the Leven is seen through the arch, & on the left, Smollett’s monument'. The arch, built in 1450, is the College Bow. The arch was originally part of the church of St Mary, which has long since vanished. Located in Church Street in Dumbarton town centre, houses and shops now flank the arch. This sketch is one of a pair of drawings of the College Bow Arch that appear in the Hutton Collection..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Dundrennan Abbey.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hooper, S. (Samuel)
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Grose, Francis, 1731?-1791
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

Print of Dundrennan Abbey, Kirkcudbrightshire. This print is entitled 'DUNDRENNAN ABBEY PL. 1', and was a plate from Captain Francis Grose's book 'The Antiquities of Scotland Vol. II', which was published in London. The engraver's initials are 'J.N,' and a note at the bottom left hand side of the page reads ‘Publish’d Augst 29th 1789, by S. Hooper.’ Dundrennan Abbey, about 5 miles south-east of Kirkcudbright and 2 miles distant from the Solway coast, was founded in 1142 by Fergus, Lord of Galloway, and housed a community of Cistercian monks. The abbey became one of the richest in Scotland, and by the sixteenth century had its own representative in Parliament. However, like many of Scotland’s finest ecclesiastical buildings, its decline was rapid after the Reformation of the 1560, and it fell into ruin in the seventeenth century..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Gordon Castle.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This print shows the front view of Gordon Castle, which is located near Fochabers, in Moray. In the foreground of the picture is a kilt-wearing Scottish soldier - most likely a Gordon Highlander - courting his sweetheart. While the print is dated 1819, the identity of the artist is unknown - however, it is quite likely to have been Hutton himself. Designed by John Baxter, he built the modern castle - or rather palace - in 1769 for the 4th Duke of Gordon. Baxter's design replaced the original castle, built during the 1470s for George Gordon, the 2nd Earl of Huntly. The port and songwriter, Robert Burns, visited the castle during his Highland tour, and immortalised it in his song, 'Castle Gordon'..

rdf:Description.dc:title: South-west view of Beauly Priory, Ross-shire.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This light pencil sketch shows the south-west view of Beauly Priory, which lies close to where the Beauly River enters the Beauly Firth. The date reads 25th August 1815 and it includes a note of the location in the bottom left-hand corner. The artist has sketched much of the surrounding area, including Beauly River, nearby buildings, trees and fields. The Hutton Collection also includes drawings of the south view and north-east view. Local landowner, John Bisset founded Beauly Priory around 1230. Dedicated to the Virgin Mary and John the Baptist, it was one of three houses established in Scotland by the Valliscaulian Order: the other two being Ardchattan and Pluscarden. The Valliscaulian remained at Beauly until 1510, at which time the priory became a Cistercian House..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Hamilton.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This sketched ground-plan of Hamilton Collegiate Church, Lanarkshire is not dated. Neither is the sketch signed by the artist. A note beneath the plan measures the width of the church from west to east at 'About fifteen paces'. It is not specified whether the smaller measurements, of walls, windows, doors and buttresses, have been made in feet or paces, although paces would appear more likely. This is one of four views of Hamilton Collegiate Church contained in the Hutton Collection. The sketch displayed here is probably a plan of only one transept of the original collegiate church. The transept housing the burial vault of the Barons of Cadzow and Dukes of Hamilton was all that was left intact of the church when it was demolished by James, 5th Duke of Hamilton, in the early-eighteenth century. In the mid-nineteenth century, the remains of the previous Dukes were moved to the nearby Hamilton Mausoleum, built between 1842 and 1857, is believed to be the biggest mausoleum in the world, apart from the pyramids at Giza in Egypt..

rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This watercolour drawing dates from August 1802 and shows the north-west view of the village of Saddell. A note underneath the drawing reads, 'The ruins of the abbey are among the trees to the right of the fine old elm tree and are shaded dark'. Much of the surrounding countryside has been included, and Saddell Bay forms an impressive backdrop to the whole scene. The village of Saddell is located around eight miles north of Campbeltown, on the eastern edge of the Kintyre Peninsula, Argyllshire, close to where the Saddell Water meets the Kilbrannan Sound. The remains of the abbey lie to the west of the village and Saddell Castle lies to the South. A large amount of the stonework from the twelfth-century abbey went into the construction of Saddell Castle in the early-sixteenth century..

rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827

This pencil drawing, of the north-west aspect of Elgin Cathedral, Moray, bears the words 'Pan Port, the gate on the left', after the title. Hutton himself probably drew it. The manses of the secular canons grouped around the cathedral, within the precinct, enclosed by a stone wall, which had four gates. Between 1820 and 1840, Elgin expanded and the authorities demolished the other three ports, or gates. The only gate that still survives is the Pans Port, 'the gate on the left'..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Restennet Priory - S.W. view. 17th Sept, 1814.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

Although this picture is unsigned, it is likely that George Henry Hutton drew the picture himself. The south-west view of the church is very similar to that in a sketch made six years later, also apparently by Hutton. However, this earlier sketch seems to be from a more elevated and slightly more distant position, revealing clearly that the priority sits in a valley, surrounded by low, rolling hills. The area of Scotland now known as Angus was once the Pictish province of Circenn, and at the heart of this province was Restenneth. The missionary Boniface, who allegedly brought Christianity to the Picts of Circenn, may have founded church in Restenneth in the seventh or eighth century. After the subsequent demise of the Picts, the site retained its ecclesiastical connotations, and Augustinian canons built a priory here in the twelfth century; the parts of the priory that survive date mainly from this period..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Monymusk from the south east, 22nd Augt, 1820.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

The name of the artist is not given, and it is probable that this is one of Hutton's own sketches. A note beneath the title reads, 'This sketch shows the steeple and part of the roof of the Parish Church. The Priory sat about 80 yards to the North-East of the church, but not a vestige remains. The exterior of the church is uncommonly plain, but the inside exhibits marks of considerable antiquity, particularly a circular arch near the East end'. Monymusk is a village on the River Don, seven or eight miles south-west of Inverurie. There is evidence of early human settlement in the area, in the form of standing stones and the remains of a seventh-century Culdee priory church. This may not have been the priory in Hutton's notes, as there are also records of an Augustinian priory having been set up in Monymusk in 1170..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Luffness House monastic ruins.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This sketch shows 'Bickerton's Cenotaph' in the ruins of Luffness Friary, near Aberlady. The tomb is protected by the figure of a thirteenth-century knight, with a sword in his right hand and a shield protecting his heart. He lies on top of a stone coffin in an arched recess, near the remains of the high altar. A more detailed drawing of the tomb can also be found in the Hutton Collection. The tomb is said to be that of Sir David de Lindsay who granted the land for the monastery to the Carmelites in the thirteenth century. During the Crusades, Sir David fell ill and he was cared for by members of the order. Although he died soon after, he repaid the Carmelites' kindness with this gift of land..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Chancel of St Mary's at Icolumkill.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Columbine, Edward Henry, 1762-1811
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

Watercolour of the chancel of St Mary's Chapel, St Ronan's Nunnery, Iona, Argyllshire, 'from a drawing made on the spot by Capt. E.H. Columbine, R.N., 1792'. This view of the ruined interior of St Mary's Church is facing to the north-west. The chancel was the area of the church, where the clergy and choir sat during services. It is located between the high altar and the nave, where the rest of the congregation sit. The community, when founded in the thirteenth century, was dedicated to the Virgin Mary, and the first generation of Canonesses was mainly of Irish origin. The ruins, depicted here before a minor clean up operation managed by the Duke of Argyll in 1849, are the best-preserved remains in Europe of a female Augustinian community.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Kilmund, E. view.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This sketch dates from August 1802, but is unsigned. It shows the church and tower of Kilmun nestling on the shores of the Holy Loch, and features people strolling by the loch and boats close to shore. It is one of several drawings and sketches of Kilmun in the Hutton Collection. The distinctive square tower in Kilmun is the remaining part of a collegiate church founded in 1442 by Sir Duncan Campbell of Lochawe, chief of the Clan Campbell and an ancestor of the Dukes of Argyll. The churchyard in Kilmun has been the burial place of the Campbells of Argyll since then. Although the village became a ‘burgh of barony’ in 1490, it did not develop significantly because of the limitations on land-space imposed by the steep hills behind the village..

rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This rough sketch shows Innerwick Castle viewed from below. Whilst it is difficult to distinguish the castle from the surrounding scenery, another drawing in the Hutton Collection shows a similar scene in much more detail. It is possible they are both by the same artist and that this example was merely a preliminary sketch. Innerwick Castle is situated on a rocky eminence close to the Thornton Burn, near the village of Innerwick. The ruins that can be seen today are thought to date from the fifteenth century, although a castle is said to have stood on this site since the fourteenth century. Originally built for the Stewart family, it eventually passed to the Hamiltons before being destroyed by the Duke of Somerset in the mid-sixteenth century..

This sketch of Fyvie Castle, Aberdeenshire is by a 'Mr Cordiner'. The sketch shows the south front of the castle. 'Mr Cordiner' may be a reference to Charles Cordiner (1746-94), Episcopalian minister of Banff, who produced two books of drawings of buildings and landscapes of the north of Scotland in the late eighteenth century. Alternatively, it could be a reference to the lesser known Reverend James Cordiner, who was responsible for some sketches in the Hutton Collection. This sketch has no date, which makes identifying the artist more difficult..

rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This sketch shows Carnwath Collegiate Church. It is one of three drawings in the Hutton Collection showing the exterior of the church. The artist's name has not been included. The inn referred to in the artist's note is most probably the Wee Bush Inn. It dates from the 1750s; and was a popular resting place for travellers. Thomas, Lord Somerville founded the collegiate church in the 1420s. It was home to a provost and six prebendaries, and served as the Somerville's family mausoleum for many years..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Sketch of the interior of Dumfries Friary, Dumfriesshire.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827

This rough drawing, made in 1811, shows the interior of the Franciscan Friary at Dumfries. A note at the bottom right corner of the drawing reads, 'Grey Friar Dumfries 1811'. Although the name of the artist has not been included, it is quite likely to have been Hutton himself. Lady Devorgilla, daughter of the last Lord of Galloway, founded Dumfries Friary, also known as Greyfriars Convent, in or around 1262. Set in a beautiful location overlooking the River Nith, legend has it that the friary is where Robert the Bruce killed the Red Comyn, thus sparking off the Scottish Wars of Independence..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Elgin Cathedral.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This is a sketch of the exterior of the west end of Elgin Cathedral, Moray, 'from a slight sketch by the Reverend J. Cordiner’. Hutton himself probably copied the sketch from James Cordiner’s original. There are another four drawings of Elgin Cathedral in the Hutton Collection. During its prime, the cathedral at Elgin was the second largest in Scotland, after St Andrews. Its nickname is the 'Lantern of the North'. The cathedral's west front is a fine example of sixteenth-century ecclesiastical architecture, and Hutton's collection of ecclesiastical drawings would not be complete without it. Elgin Cathedral fell into disuse after the Reformation..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Lincluden.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

Plan of Lincluden Collegiate Church. This plan reads, 'Lincluden given me by Capt. Grose 1790'. Captain Grose was most likely Francis Grose, the celebrated antiquarian and author of 'The Antiquities of Scotland', published in 1791. The plan shows the different areas of the church, including the high altar, great court, choir, cloister and the Countess of Galloway's [i.e. Douglas's] tomb. The Countess of Galloway's tomb is located in the south-east of the church close to the sacristy. It is the final resting place of Margaret, wife of the 4th Earl of Douglas and daughter of King Robert III. The tomb includes a stone effigy and is located in a small recess. Today, the ruins belong to Historic Scotland and are open to the public..

rdf:Description.dc:title: At Rowadil in Harris.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Daniell, William, 1769-1837
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

Undated sketch of an engraving from a tombstone, in St Clement's Church, Harris, Inverness-shire. Hutton’s note names the artist as Mr Daniell. Hutton does not describe exactly what the sketch contains, but the words of the sketched inscription, mainly in Latin, indicate that it is an engraving on the tombstone of Alexander Macleod. Harris and Dunvegan, in North Skye, are historically seats of the Clan Macleod, and St Clement’s is the family’s traditional burial place. The tomb of Alexander Macleod of Dunvegan and Harris, also known as Alasdair Crotach or Humpback, is located in the south-east part of St Clement's church, and dates from 1528. The church, in Rodel, South Harris, is believed to have been built on the site of an earlier ecclesiastical building, and historical sources are divided over whether the present St Clement's dates from the fifteenth or early sixteenth century..

rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827

This is one of various drawings and sketches made at the Augustinian Priory at Restenneth, near Forfar. This unsigned sketch may be the work of Hutton himself. The detail on this sketch suggests that although the roof was completely gone from most of Restenneth Priory by 1814, the walls were still largely intact, and held large and elaborate sculpted stones. This ornamentation is particularly evident on the north wall, to the left of the picture. The remains of Restenneth Priory date mainly from the twelfth century, but may also include seventh- or eighth-century stones from a Pictish foundation on the same site..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Elgin Cathedral, inside the west end.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This pencil drawing is 'from a sketch by the Reverend Cordiner'. Cordiner, of St Paul's Chapel, Aberdeen, was, between 1799 and 1804, chaplain to the garrison of Colombo in Sri Lanka and principal of all schools on the island. His book 'A Description of Ceylon’ was published in 1807. It is probable that Hutton copied this sketch from Cordiner's original. Elgin Cathedral began as a chapter-house (a meeting place for the governing body of the cathedral) in 1244, and reached its full size by the end of the thirteenth century. The cathedral suffered badly in the Reformation, and was a quarry and a rubbish dump in the nineteenth century. Eventually, the Government took over the site and it is now a popular tourist attraction..

This faint sketch shows the interior of what are probably the remains of the old parish church of St Andrews, in Gullane. Whilst extremely faint, it is possible to make out two large archways. This sketch is one of several drawings in the Hutton Collection that detail the remains of the church. One of the other drawings in the collection, also dated 1785, shows the interior from the same angle but in much more detail. It includes some of the decoration above the archway on the right. Built in the twelfth century, the parish church of St Andrews was eventually abandoned in 1612 and replaced by a parish church established in Dirleton..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Plan of the ruins of the Abbey of Kinloss.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Nisbet, Andrew, painter at Forres
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

A note at the bottom of the page, in Hutton's hand, reads, 'By ____ Nisbet, Painter at Forres, 1816'. This may have been Andrew Nisbet. A scale and key have been included below the title. Hutton has made other notes on the plan, which seem to criticise Mr Nisbet's draughtsmanship! King David I founded Kinloss Abbey around 1150. Situated beside Kinloss Burn, north of Forres, monks of the Cistercian Order from Melrose settled the Abbey. Its central tower collapsed in 1574, but it was included in Pont's 1600 map and the abbey was still obviously an impressive structure. In 1601, Edward Bruce, Lord Kinloss bought it. In 1650, the structure received its final blow when Cromwell took the stone to build a fort at Inverness. Today it is a popular visitor attraction although only two of the original arches remain..

Sketch of a monumental stone found by grave-diggers in Coupar Angus, Perthshire. The monument carries an engraving of a sword, resembling a claymore, running the length of the stone, and around the blade are words which appear to read 'HIC: IACET WILL DE: MONGE: HIPO'. The notes beneath the drawing do not offer a translation of this. Although there are drawings from Coupar Angus in the Hutton Collection that appear to be the work of other artists, Hutton seems to have made this sketch personally. Beneath the title, he has added a note, which reads: 'It was found (26 Aug. 1820) in digging a grave in the church Yard. Placed erect when drawn'..

rdf:Description.dc:title: From the Lord of Kyntayl's Mont, at Beaulieu.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

Faint sketch of a feature on a monument in Beauly Priory, Inverness-shire. The sheet is undated and is unsigned, but it is likely that George Henry Hutton himself was the artist. The sketch appears to be of the skull or head of an animal, perhaps a reindeer that is on a monument in the priory. It is one of number of drawings and sketches from Beauly in the Hutton Collection. Beauly Priory, in Inverness-shire, was one of three priories founded in the thirteenth century by Valliscaulian monks from the French region of Burgundy. They originally named it 'Prioratus de Bello Loco', which is Latin for 'Priory of the Lovely Spot'. When Mary, Queen of Scots visited the priory in 1564, she is reputed to have described the priory in French as 'un beau lieu', or 'a beautiful place', which may have given the name of the priory and village its modern pronunciation. In the title of his sketch, Hutton has retained the French spelling..

This is a sketch of a south-west view of Restenneth Priory, Angus. The artist's name is missing, but it is likely that Hutton made it himself. This is one of several sketches of Restenneth Priory in the Collection, and gives an impression of the setting of the priory, among trees and with rolling hills to the north-east. This sketch suggests that Restenneth Priory, when the artist visited it, looked much the same as it does today. The steeple is nearly intact, but the adjoining buildings are partial ruins. Most of the buildings date from the Augustinian priory founded in the twelfth century, but some stones from a seventh- or eighth-century Pictish church on the same site form part of the walls..

A sketch of a south-east view of Guthrie Collegiate Church, Angus, dated September 1814 and probably one of Hutton's own sketches. It shows a modest, single-storey L-shaped church building surrounded by a graveyard filled with ancient-looking, irregularly-positioned tombstones. The village of Guthrie lies approximately eleven kilometres east of Forfar and had a church by 1150 that became collegiate in the late fifteenth century. People founded and dedicated Collegiate churches in Scotland to securing salvation and the favour of God for their families. The churches often later came to have schools attached to them..

rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

Here, the artist has sketched a sculptured stone found above the doorway of Tongland Mill. It shows a figure holding what is possibly a coat of arms. The artist has not included background information regarding the stone and its location. The Hutton Collection also includes a drawing of the north-west view of Tongland Church and another sketch detailing a stone carving. The village of Tongland is on the River Dee, around two miles north of Kirkcudbright, in Dumfriesshire. It has a long history and houses an abbey founded in the twelfth century. Part of this - a doorway - built into an early parish church, is still in the present-day kirkyard..

rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This sketch shows a stone carving found in a house in Tongland. Whilst the detail on the stone is very faint, there is the suggestion of a face. The Hutton Collection also includes a drawing of the north-west view of Tongland Church and another sketch detailing a sculptured stone. The ancient hamlet of Tongland is located in the parish of the same name, in Dumfriesshire. Situated on the River Dee, it lies approximately two miles north-east of Kirkcudbright and was once home to an abbey founded by Fergus, Lord of Galloway. Francis Groome relayed an interesting story regarding the last Abbot of the abbey, an Italian alchemist named Damian, in the 'Ordnance Gazetteer' (1894). Allegedly, Damian attempted to fly from the parapet of Stirling Castle to France in the presence of James IV. He apparently landed in a nearby midden and fractured his thigh bone!.

George Hutton made this pencil sketch, of a stone coffin, Kinloss Abbey, Moray. He drew several sketches of the abbey, and the Hutton Collection contains a plan of the grounds, by Andrew Nisbet. King David I of Scotland founded Kinloss Abbey in 1150. It was colonised by monks from the Cistercian Order who came from Melrose. It was a large and impressive structure that stood, in various states of repair, for 500 years before finally being torn down to be used by Oliver Cromwell in building a fort at Inverness..

rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This is a sketch of a sculpted stone in Coupar Angus, Perthshire. The sculpture on the stone appears to be of a royal or heraldic shield, displaying the lion rampant and a crown. It is likely that Hutton was the artist, as well as the author of a note below the title that reads 'It is built into the wall of a house opposite the church Yard gate'. Although the stone depicted in the drawing does not carry a date, it is quite likely that it was originally part of the eleventh century Cistercian Abbey at Coupar Angus. After Protestant reformers burnt the Abbey buildings in 1559, locals dismantled the remains for building materials. This could explain why an ornamental stone ended up in the wall of an ordinary house..

rdf:Description.dc:title: In the priory at Rowadill, Isle of Harris.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Daniell, William, 1769-1837
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This was drawn by William Daniell, in July 1818, and shows the tomb of Alexander MacLeod of Dunvegan and Harris, in St Clement's Church, Rodel. The Hutton Collection contains further drawings and plans detailing St Clement's, including another drawing of Alexander's tomb by Daniell. Whilst the one seen here is possibly Daniell's preliminary sketch, it is very difficult to distinguish between the two drawings. Alexander Macleod of Dunvegan and Harris, who was also known as Alexander Crotach or Humpback, is believed to have built St Clement's Church in the late-fifteenth or early-sixteenth century. His tomb is located in the south-eastern part of the church and is dated 1528. The detailed carving around his tomb, which includes biblical references, may be the finest example of medieval sculpture in the whole of the Western Isles..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Rubbing of part of the inscription on Holywood Abbey’s small bell, Dumfriesshire.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827

rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

There is no title on this sheet but it is likely that the rubbing was from the smaller bell at Holywood Abbey. This is mainly due to the rubbing’s position in the collection and the references made to this rubbing in accompanying notes. It is also likely that this image dates from 1811. A series of six rubbings together transcribe the bell's inscription. The inscription totals a length of thirty-one and half inches, with the mouth of the bell having a circumference of 54 inches. These six rubbings are only part of a series of images taken of Holywood Abbey. The other four all record both bells too - they seem to have been a source of curiosity amongst nineteenth century antiquaries..

There is no title carried on this sheet but it is likely that the rubbing was from the smaller bell at Holywood Abbey. This is mainly due to the rubbing’s position in the collection and the references made to this rubbing in accompanying notes. It is also likely that this image dates from 1811. The monk Congall probably founded the Abbey as a Premonstratensian House. The order, originating in Laon, France, was monastic, partly canonical and, in practice, the monks divided their time between prayer and working the land. There routine was based on the Rule of St Augustine but had been amended to reflect their mixed purpose. This house was not only one of a network of religious establishments spread across southern Scotland but was also one of two houses, the other at Dryburgh, who lived a Premonstratensian lifestyle..

There is no title on this sheet but it is likely that the rubbing is from the smaller bell at Holywood Abbey. This is mainly due to the rubbing’s position in the collection and the references made to this rubbing in accompanying notes. It is likely, because of the facts that it dates from 1811. There are six rubbings of the decoration on the smaller bell at Holywood, contained in the Hutton Drawings and a further four of the bells themselves. There were two bells at the Abbey, still extant during Hutton’s lifetime. They seem to have caused some interest amongst antiquarians. They eventually ended up in the nearby parish church..

There is no title carried on this sheet but the rubbing likely came from the smaller bell at Holywood Abbey. This is mainly due to the rubbing’s position in the collection and the references made to this rubbing in accompanying notes. It is also likely dated 1811. This rubbing is relatively unusual amongst those held in the Collection, as it does not depict Latin script. It shows the initials 'V.H.’ and a coat of arms depicting three crosses and two diagonals. Premonstratensian Monks inhabited the Abbey at Holywell. It is likely that the monk Congall founded this house, and certainly, his name appears in local topographical names. After the Reformation, the Abbey bells moved to the local parish church. It was from here that these rubbings came..

There is no title on this sheet but it is likely that the rubbing is from the smaller bell at Holywood Abbey. This is mainly due to the rubbing’s position in the collection and the references made to this rubbing in accompanying notes. It is also likely that the image dates from 1811. This is one of five rubbings, which transcribe the inscription: the sixth rubbing depicting the coat of arms on the bell. There were two bells at the Abbey, large and small, which later ended up in the local parish church. The smaller of the two carried this inscription which measures about thirty-one and a half inches all the way round. Although a cheap and effective method of exact reproduction, it has now been realised the creating rubbings of monuments actually defaces them and increases their rate of deterioration. As a result, the practise is now discouraged..

There is no title on this sheet but it is likely that the rubbing was from the smaller bell at Holywood Abbey. This is mainly due to the rubbing’s position in the collection and the references made to this rubbing in accompanying notes. It is also likely that this image dates from 1811. The rim of the bell is clearly visible. This is also one of four images showing the inscription round the bell. There were two bells at Holywood Abbey that ended up in the local parish church. The small bell was nineteen inches high, with a circumference of fifty–four inches at its mouth. The circumference of the actual inscription was thirty-one and a half inches. The larger of the bells was only another inch higher and wider though..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Kilwinning 1789.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Pollock, William, Rev.
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

Annotated drawing of Kilwinning Abbey, Ayrshire. A note at the top, under the title, continues 'communicated by the Revd. Wm. Pollock'. It is one of three images of Kilwinning Abbey contained in the Hutton Collection, each by a different artist. The numbered annotations on the sheet indicate the Steeple, a building that is 'supposed to be Hall of the Abbot's House', and the churchyard. The ruins of the medieval abbey dominate the centre of the Ayrshire town of Kilwinning. The abbey was a Tironesian foundation, built in 1162, and apparently, when still intact, was very similar in structure to Glasgow Cathedral, which dated from between the 1130s and the 1190s. While Glasgow Cathedral was one of the few significant Scottish monastic buildings to survive the Reformation of 1560 relatively undamaged, Kilwinning was less fortunate..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Sweetheart Abbey, New Abbey, Dumfries and Galloway.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This page shows a heavily annotated, untitled, ground plan of Sweetheart Abbey, in the village of New Abbey, Dumfries and Galloway. George Henry Hutton obtained the plan from a Mr William Wright in 1789, and it is one of three drawings or sketches relating to New Abbey in the Hutton Collection. The annotations identify the locations of the different parts of the abbey complex, and in some cases provide dimensions. They also give extensive descriptions of the abbey's ornamented doorways, walls and tombs. Today Sweetheart Abbey is a ruin, but substantial enough parts of it remain to show that it was once a beautiful and elaborate building. Its romantic name came from its community of Cistercian monks, who named it in tribute to its founder Devorgilla, Lady of Galloway. Devorgilla founded the abbey in 1273 in memory of her husband John Balliol, the father of the Scottish King of the same name..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Franciscan Church at Haddington, 1802.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This page includes a rough sketch of what is, probably, the Royal Burgh of Haddington coat of arms, and a description of the interior of the church. The note begins 'Arms on one of buttresses of the Franciscan Church at Haddington. It is the buttress on the East side of the great window in the South transept'. Although reference is made to the 'Franciscan Church', it is perhaps more familiarly known as St Mary's Collegiate Church. The east wall of St Mary's features a stone carving of a goat and vine, which is a symbol that has been associated with Haddington since the Middle Ages and is still in evidence in the town today. It is claimed by some of the townspeople that, prior to the nineteenth century, a stone goat adorned the top of the mercat cross..

This is a drawing of a monument at Ardchattan Priory, Argyllshire. It shows three pointed archways within a larger round archway set within a stone wall. A large stone slab covers the ground underneath the main arch. The artist has included a note regarding its location and history. Located in a secluded spot on the banks of Loch Etive, near Oban, Argyllshire, Duncan MacDougall founded Ardchattan in the mid-thirteenth century. Dedicated to the Virgin Mary and John the Baptist, it was one of only three houses in Scotland belonging to the Valliscaulian Order, the other two being Beauly and Pluscarden..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Monument in the interior of Ardchattan Priory.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This drawing shows a monument located in the interior of Ardchattan Priory, which lies on the banks of Loch Etive, near Oban, Argyllshire. The monument comprises six carved figures, both male and female, located in highly decorative niches, with inscription around the periphery. There are several other drawings in the Hutton Collection, mostly dating from 1820, detailing the interior and exterior of Ardchattan Priory. Founded in the thirteenth century by Duncan MacDougall, Ardchattan Priory was home to members of the Valliscaulian Order. Whilst the monks only remained at Ardchattan until the mid-sixteenth century, religious services continued there until the mid-eighteenth century. Today, Historic Scotland cares for the ruins and they are open to the public..

rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827

This drawing of a bell from Holywood Abbey, one of a pair in the Hutton Collection, dates from around 1811. A transcript of the Latin inscription that appears at the top of the bell is at the bottom of the drawing. The name of the artist is missing; it is likely that it was Hutton himself. These two bells from the abbey are in the local parish church at Holywood. Although little now remains of Holyrood Abbey, it was a famous religious centre during the Middle Ages. The abbey constructed in the English Gothic style, in 1180, housed Premonstratensians, monks who came to Scotland from Laon, in France..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Statue of Johannes de Sacro Bosco, Friars' Carse, Dumfriesshire.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Claperton, Robert
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This drawing shows a fragment of a statue of Johannes de Sacro Bosco, who was a famous mathematician and astronomer during the thirteenth century. A note says that it was, 'From a sketch by the late Dr [Robert] Claperton, Annan, 23d. Oct. 1811.' The Hutton Collection contains another drawing that depicts an adjoining section of this statue. It appears that the fragments of the statue which this drawing is based on was originally housed in Holyrood Abbey, but was later kept in Terragles, near Dumfries. The '1232 Visit' note underneath the drawing suggests that Johannes de Sacro Bosco, also known as John of Holywood or Halifax, possibly visited Scotland in that year. Sacro Bosco is most famous for writing the tract, 'Tractatus de Sphera' (c. 1233), which is a fundamental medieval text on astronomy, based on Ptolemy's theories..

This is another drawing of a statue of Johannes de Sacro Bosco, Friars' Carse, Dumfriesshire. It is one of a pair the Hutton Collection. It is a portrayal of the lower part of a statue of Johannes de Sacro Bosco, who was a famous astronomer and mathematician during the early thirteenth century; a note at the foot states that this fragment, 'was removed from Holywood to Terragles at the Reformation, and is now to be seen at Friars Carse', Nithsdale. It also says that the drawing, dated October 1811, was based on a sketch by Dr Robert Claperton of Annan. 'Tractatus de Sphera' (c. 1233), which is a fundamental medieval text on astronomy, based on Ptolemy's theories, is probably the most famous of Sacro Bosco's tracts..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Franciscan Church at Haddington sketched on the spot 1782.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Grose, Francis, 1731?-1791
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This drawing of the south-east view of St Mary's Collegiate Church, Haddington, East Lothian appeared in volume two of 'The Antiquities of Scotland' (1792), by Captain Francis Grose. It shows St Mary's Collegiate Church from the south-east. The artist has also chosen to detail much of the surrounding area in this sketch, including the River Tyne, the sixteenth-century Nungate Bridge and part of the town. The first Franciscan friary in Scotland was founded in the early-thirteenth century. Others soon followed and by the end of the century there were several throughout Scotland, including one in Haddington. Although the artist has chosen to title the sketch 'Franciscan Church', this ecclesiastical building is more familiarly known as St Mary's Collegiate Church. Built in the fourteenth century, St Mary's is not only the largest parish church in Scotland but is also considered one of the three great pre-Reformation churches of the Lothians: St Giles in Edinburgh and St Michael's in Linlithgow are the other two..

rdf:Description.dc:title: View of the church of Haddington from the south east.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This print of a drawing by George Henry Hutton, of the south-east view of St Mary's Collegiate Church, Haddington, appeared in the 'Archaeologia Scotica or, Transactions of the Society of Antiquaries of Scotland', published in 1792. The detail shown by Hutton extends to include the sixteenth-century Nungate Bridge and much of the surrounding area. Known as the 'Lamp of Lothian', possibly due to the red sandstone used in its construction, St Mary's Collegiate Church dates from the fourteenth century and is the largest parish church in Scotland. Along with St Giles in Edinburgh and St Michael's in Linlithgow, St Mary's is also considered one of the great pre-Reformation churches of the Lothians. Badly damaged in 1548, the church underwent partial restoration at the behest of John Knox (1505-72). It was not fully restored until the 1970s. Hutton's drawing clearly shows that the main body of St Mary's at this time was still open to the elements..

rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This sketch shows Carnwath Collegiate Church, Lanarkshire, and a number of adjacent buildings. A note in the bottom right-hand corner reads, 'Carnwath from the West 17 Oct. 1800'. It is one of three drawings in the Hutton Collection showing the exterior of the church. The artist's name has not been included. Carnwath is located in the Clyde Valley, on the edge of the Lang Whang Moor, thirty miles from Edinburgh and Glasgow. The village is home to a number of interesting historical landmarks, including a twelfth-century motte, a market cross, and the collegiate church, founded in the 1420s..

Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This drawing shows the north-east view of Carnwath Collegiate Church, Lanarkshire, and is one of three drawings contained in the Hutton Collection that detail the exterior of the church. The artist's name has not been included. Thomas, Lord Somerville, founded Carnwath Collegiate Church in the 1420s on the site of a pre-existing church. The only part of the original collegiate church that remains today is St Mary's Aisle - the entrance to which is in this drawing. For many years, St Mary's served as the family mausoleum for the Somervilles..
