This drawing of a monument at Saddell Abbey, Argyllshire, shows a large stone slab decorated with a carved sword, and includes the length and breadth in feet and inches. A note under the title reads, 'It lies within the church near Macdonald'. Saddell Abbey is located in the Saddell Glen, on the eastern coastline of the Kintyre peninsula, Argyllshire. Somerled, Lord of the Isles, founded the Cistercian Abbey at Saddell in the twelfth century. The 'MacDonald' referred to in the note at the bottom of this drawing was most likely one of Somerled's descendants: Somerled's grandson, Donald, gave his name to the clan MacDonald..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Monument at Sadael Abbey, 19 Aug 1802.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This is a drawing of a partially obliterated carving at Saddell Abbey, Argyllshire. The title below this pencil sketch reads, 'Monument at Sadael Abbey / 19 Aug 1802 / The sculpture is nearly obliterated'. There is a further note, which identifies this as a bird's-eye view. There is no name attached to this sheet, but as implied by the numbering at the top this is one of series of monument sketches contained in the Hutton Collection. This picture, captured 200 years ago now, is a hardcopy record of information that was disappearing then and is still deteriorating. There were many carved stones left at Saddell and together they provide a window into this complex, early medieval, period in Scotland's history. The melting pot of Celtic, Norse and Native cultures come together on remains such as this..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Inverness.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

Drawing of a pillar in a churchyard, Inverness, Inverness-shire. This drawing reads simply, 'Inverness'. A note beneath the title explains 'The fragment here represented stands in the Burial Ground a few yards north-west of the church, and is said to be a remnant of the Grey Friars Monastery. Aug 11. 1815. The height of the Pillar to the top of the Capital is about 9 feet'. The name of the artist is not given, and it may be that this is one of Hutton's own drawings. The steeple in the background of the drawing is that of the Old High Parish Church. King Alexander II established a monastery in Inverness in 1233. As Hutton's note and the name of the site suggest, it was thought for a long time that the monastery had housed Franciscan or Grey Friars, but it is now known that the Order of monks in Inverness were in fact Dominican or Black Friars. After the monastery fell into decline, its stones were used by Oliver Cromwell's troops to build a fort to the north of the town, and only the pillar depicted in this drawing was left standing..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Monument on the east end of the church of Crossraguel Abbey, on the south side of the Great Altar, 11th April 1813.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This pencil sketch, of a feature at Crossraguel, is difficult to make out but appears to resemble the abbey's 'sedilia'. 'Sedilia' is the plural of the Latin ‘sedile’, meaning chair, and denotes the places used by the clergy whilst officiating during the liturgy. This style of stone seat is peculiar to Great Britain where they usually have three seats - one each for celebrant, deacon, and sub-deacon. The 'sedilia' at Crossraguel dates from the 1400s..

Funerary monument from Beauly Priory, Ross-shire. The note along the bottom of the sheet goes on to record the Latin inscription around the base of the slab and the details of figure, which surmounts it. The whole sculpture nestles in an arched and decorated niche. Funerary monuments for members of the upper classes and aristocracy were popular through the middle ages in northern Scotland as a demonstration of power and status. These free-standing, three-dimensional sculptures were the descendants of much earlier and two-dimensional carved slabs. Examples of these antecedents are also included in the Hutton Collection, along with another eleven views of Beauly Priory..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Gate in Dumbarton Castle.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Columbine, Edward Henry, 1762-1811
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This drawing shows a gate to Dumbarton Castle, with the rocky cliffs on either side acting as a natural frame for the picture. It is likely that this gate is the fourteenth century Portcullis Arch, which is the oldest part of the existing castle. A note below the drawing reads 'a gate in Dumbarton Castle - copied from a drawing made on the spot by Capt. [Edward] Columbine, R.R'. There is no date included on the drawing. The National Maritime Museum in Greenwich, London owns the original of this drawing. Located at an important strategic position on the River Clyde, Dumbarton Castle boasts a rich history dating back to at least AD 450. William Wallace, Robert the Bruce and Mary, Queen of Scots are just some of the famous figures in Scottish history who were involved in famous events at the castle..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Gate at New Abbey.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Cocking, Thomas, active approximately 1783-1791
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This undated drawing is by 'Capt. Grose's assistant'. Captain Francis Grose (1731-91), was an antiquary and author whose work features prominently in the Hutton Collection. His assistant, Thomas Cocking, was also responsible for a few drawings in the collection. This is one of three pictures relating to New Abbey in the collection, but apparently the only one drawn by Cocking. The village of New Abbey in Kirkcudbrightshire takes its name from the Cistercian abbey founded there in 1273 by Devorgilla, Lady of Galloway, in memory of her husband John Balliol (father of the Scottish King of the same name). She called it 'New Abbey' to distinguish it from Dundrennan Abbey, which is also in Kirkcudbrightshire. Although the village has retained the name New Abbey, the abbey itself is now 'Sweetheart Abbey', a name coined by the monks as a tribute to Devorgilla 's kindness and charity..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Gravestone, Beauly Priory, Ross-shire.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This drawing, which dates from August 1815, shows one of several gravestones from Beauly Priory, Ross-shire. The decoration is well preserved and the stone appears to have suffered minimal damage. The notes underneath the drawing suggest that a number of gravestones in the grounds of the priory now appear on modern graves with new inscriptions. Founded by John Bisset as a Valliscaulian House in the 1230s, work on Beauly Priory finally ended around 1272. It underwent an extensive restoration and rebuilding programme in the 1430s, but eventually fell in to disuse and disrepair during the Reformation despite improvements carried out by Prior Robert Reid in 1541. Whilst much of the priory now lies in ruins, or has completely disappeared, the architect Alexander Ross successfully rebuilt the north transept in 1901..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Monument from Saddell Abbey, Argyllshire, 21st Aug. 1802.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This drawing shows a large stone slab with detailed carvings of two swords and a ship. It is one of around a dozen carved stones on view today in the grounds of the Abbey. Originally thought carved on Iona, it is now more likely that someone made the stones in a workshop at Saddell. The monuments and grave slabs at Saddell commemorate the Lordship of the Isles and the warrior class to which it belonged. Stone portraits immortalise some of the great warriors and represented in the carvings are symbols of power and domination, including ships, swords and suits of armour..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Monument at Kilmund.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This drawing, of a monument in Kilmun Collegiate Church, Argyllshire, dates from August 1802, but is unsigned. The significance of this monument is not on the sheet, but it is probably the tomb of the Black Knight of Loch Awe and his consort, which is in the vault of the church. The Black Knight of Loch Awe was a name given to Sir Duncan Campbell, chief of the Clan Campbell and an ancestor of the ducal family of Argyll. Campbell founded Kilmun Collegiate Church in 1442 on the burial place of his son Celestine, who had died about 1440. Thereafter the churchyard at Kilmun became the last resting place of the Campbell chiefs and the Dukes of Argyll..

This was drawn by William Daniell, in 1818, and shows a funerary monument located in the south aisle of St Clement's Church, Rodel, Harris. The note regarding a plan could be referring to a drawing of the interior by John Macleod, which also forms part of the Hutton Collection. St Clement's Church is believed to have been built in the late-fifteenth or early-sixteenth century, on the site of a much earlier church, by Alexander MacLeod of Dunvegan and Harris. The funerary monument detailed here is possibly that of Alexander's son, William, who succeeded as clan leader following his father's death. Drawings of Alexander's elaborate tomb are also contained in the Hutton Collection..

rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

The title underneath this pencil drawing reads, 'Monument at Sadael Abbey 21 Aug. 1802'. The width and length of the monument have been included and a note records its location: 'It lies near the East end of the Burial ground'. A carved sword surrounded by a decorative pattern adorns the stone. This drawing is one of many in the Hutton Collection that detail the extraordinary stone carvings found at Saddell. The stone carvings at Saddell were the work of expert craftsmen. These show five portraits of those they commemorate and as six grave covers. Swords, armour and ships are common symbols found on the Saddell stones and are linked to the abbey's founder, the twelfth-century warrior-king of the Isles known as Somerled, and his followers..

This south-east view of Abbey St Bathans Church, Berwickshire is dated 1788 but is unsigned by the artist. Although the title describes the building as a nunnery, it is in fact the church at Abbey St Bathans. This incorporates parts of the twelfth century Cistercian nunnery burnt by Henry VIII's troops in 1544. Abbey St Bathans is located in the Whiteadder Valley north of Duns in Berwickshire. It takes its name from St Bathan, a friend or cousin of St Columba, and perhaps his successor at Iona, who reputedly founded a cell there in the sixth century..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Remains of the Collegiate Church of Hamilton, S.E. View.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

The title of this south-east view of Hamilton Collegiate Church, Lanarkshire is, 'Remains of (I suppose) the Collegiate Church of Hamilton, S.E. View'. The artist has dated it October 15th, 1800, but has not signed it. This is one of four views of the church contained in the Hutton Collection. Hutton's note under the title reads, 'The situation is close to the palace, and has been long the Family Burial Place'. Hamilton Collegiate Church was founded in 1450-1 by Sir James Hamilton, 6th Lord Cadzow, 1st Lord Hamilton, and ancestor of the Dukes of Hamilton. The church was the burial place for the Barons and Dukes of Hamilton until the building of the Hamilton Mausoleum in the mid-nineteenth century, and when the 5th Duke of Hamilton demolished the Collegiate Church in the early eighteenth century, the transept housing the Hamilton burial vault was left intact..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Dryburgh Abbey. S.W. view, 1788.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Grose, Francis, 1731?-1791
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This south-west view of Dryburgh Abbey, Berwickshire is one of four views of Dryburgh Abbey contained in the Hutton Collection. The remains of Dryburgh Abbey differ in an important respect from those of the other major border abbeys at Jedburgh, Kelso and Melrose. In each of those places, the most substantial remains are of the abbey church. At Dryburgh, the church has largely disappeared, but more substantial sections of the domestic areas of the abbey complex remain than at any of the other sites. This has allowed historians and archaeologists to find out a great deal, about how the monks lived from day to day. The abbey, founded for the Premonstratensians, or Order of White Canons, in 1150, fell into disuse after the Reformation of 1560..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Monastery of Fail, Airshire, South-West View.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This drawing is a south-west view of Fail Monastery, Ayrshire. It dates from 10th October 1800, but is unsigned. This is one of three drawings or sketches of Fail Monastery contained in the Hutton Collection. Fail, or Failford, is a hamlet about two miles south-east of Tarbolton, in Ayrshire, at the point where the Water of Fail meets the River Ayr. Trinitarian or Red Friars founded the monastery at Fail in about 1252. Like many Scottish monastic foundations, the Reformation of 1560 partially destroyed it, and the buildings passed into the ownership of the Wallace family..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Lesmahago Priory, 1785, S.W. View.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

A fainter note directly after the title of this drawing reads, 'Since removed'. The artist is not named, although it is likely that it was Hutton himself. This is the only drawing or sketch of Lesmahagow Priory contained in the Hutton Collection. Hutton's note can be dated to after 1803, as this is when the priory was demolished. Lesmahagow Priory was founded around AD 1140 by King David I of Scotland and John, Bishop of Glasgow. The priory was affiliated to Kelso Abbey, and as such was inhabited by monks of the Tironesian Order. Despite being burned by English troops in 1335, the abbey continued to thrive until the Reformation of 1560, when it was largely demolished. The nave and tower were retained and used as a parish church until 1803..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Stone lying at the west door of the Church of Holywood, Oct. 27, 1811.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This drawing shows a stone cross that was located at the west door of Holywood Abbey, near Dumfries. This sketch forms part of a sequence of drawings in the Hutton Collection that relate to Holywood Abbey. A scribbled note to the right of the drawing states the stone's dimensions, and the artist describes the ruins surrounding the stone. The artist is unknown. Monks of the Premonstratensian Order from Laon, in France, most likely built Holywood Abbey in 1180. The cruciform-shaped Abbey is in an English Gothic style, with a Norman arch and an oak roof. The surviving section of the abbey lasted until 1778 with the stones reconstructed into the village's parish church. Only a few remains are now left of the abbey..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Figure clutching a shield.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This pencil drawing details a monument from Saddell Abbey, on the eastern edge of the Kintyre peninsula, Argyllshire. The monument is one of several stone carvings at Saddell and shows a figure clutching a shield. Further decorative detail and an inscription appear underneath. A note at the bottom of this drawing reads, 'It lies a few yards to the East of the church in the Burial place of Dugald Campbell Esqr. [?] of Glen Carradell [?]. 1802. It was removed by Mr Macalastair [?] from within the church'. Founded in the twelfth century by Somerled, Lord of the Isles, and completed by his son Reginald, Saddell Abbey was home to monks of the Cistercian Order. Also called 'white monks', due to the simple white robes they wore, the Cistercians chose an austere existence, dividing their time between prayer and hard work. The location of the abbey, in the Saddell Glen, was ideal for the monks, providing them with the necessary peace and isolation..

Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This drawing details one of several tombs in Seton Collegiate Church. Located in an arched recess in the interior of the church, the figure of a knight clutching a shield against his breast lies along the length of a stone coffin. A number of other drawings highlighting important features of the church can also be found in the Hutton Collection. Built in the fifteenth century upon the site of an earlier parish church, Seton Collegiate Church was founded by Lord Seton as a place of perpetual prayer for the Seton family. It remained in the family until the early-eighteenth century when, along with the rest of the Seton estates, it was forfeited as punishment for supporting the failed Jacobite Rebellion of 1715..

Tombstone at Beauly Priory, Inverness-shire. This drawing is one of several from Beauly contained in the Hutton Collection. The sheet does not appear to be signed, and may be George Henry Hutton's own work. The engraving on the tombstone shows a human figure, possibly armoured, lying with arms folded over its chest, and a sword or lance to its side. The faint notes on the right hand side of the drawing read 'On the north side of the church, near the east end, but not its original situation - Length 7 feet - Breadth 3 ft. 7inch'. A note on the left hand side of the drawing reveals that the subject of the monument is 'said to be Fraser of Aigas'. Aigas, to the south-west of Beauly, is in the heart of an area traditionally owned by the Clan Fraser..

This drawing shows the remains of a tombstone in Seton Collegiate Church, East Lothian. A note underneath the sketch reads, 'Stone in the Col. Ch. of Seton, 29 Sept 29 1802. It lies near the East end'. The artist has included measurements and the cruciform design on the stone. A number of other drawings detailing parts of the interior and exterior of the church are also contained in the Hutton Collection. Seton Collegiate Church has an interesting history. Built on the site of a thirteenth-century parish church, it was founded in the late-fifteenth century by the Seton family. Whilst the apse and chancel both date from its foundation, throughout the sixteenth century the church was gradually extended by subsequent generations of the family. Following the death of the fourth Lord Seton at the Battle of Flodden in 1513, his widow, Lady Seton, added the transepts and steeple in memory of her husband..

Unusually for the stones at Saddell, the carved relief of a fully clad warrior dominates this one..

rdf:Description.dc:creator: Daniell, William, 1769-1837
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This was drawn by William Daniell, in 1818, and shows the tomb of Alexander MacLeod of Dunvegan and Harris, in St Clement's Church, Rodel, Harris. The Hutton Collection contains a number of other drawings and plans’ detailing St Clement’s, including another sketch of Alexander's tomb by Daniell. Alexander Macleod may have built St Clement's Church for the MacLeods of Harris in the late-fifteenth or early-sixteenth century. His nickname was Alexander Crotach, or 'humpback', in recognition of a disfiguring sword wound he received. As Daniell has beautifully illustrated here, Alexander's exquisitely sculpted tomb in St Clement's includes an effigy of a knight, biblical carvings and an inscription..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Architectural feature at Crossraguel Abbey, Ayrshire.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

There is no text or title with this drawing of an architectural feature at Crossraguel Abbey, Ayrshire but it may be a feature to the north side of the abbey and may even be the gatehouse arch. It is one of two sketches of Crossraguel Abbey in the Hutton Collection and the other is dated 1813. Crossraguel Abbey was a Cluniac house established, in the early 1200s, by the priory at Paisley. It did not receive its charter of confirmation, however, until 1404, from King Robert II. This was a reflection of the abbey's increasing landholdings, power and wealth. Relatively untouched by the Reformation, the abbey eventually fell to the Earl of Cassilis, who tortured the Abbot into signing the abbey and its possessions over to him..

The date of this drawing is October 1800. It is unsigned by the artist, but may be one of Hutton's own drawings. This is one of three views of Fail Monastery in the Hutton Collection. The Monastery is located near the confluence of The Water of Fail and the River Ayr, two miles south-east of Tarbolton. The east view of Fail Monastery shows it in an advanced state of ruin. Trinitarian or Red Friars founded the monastery in 1252 and the Reformation of 1560 partially destroyed it. The Wallace family repaired the buildings after it passed into its ownership, and renamed it, for a time, Fail Castle. It later fell derelict again..

Effigy in Dundrennan Abbey, Kirkcudbrightshire. The drawing, which is one of four relating to Dundrennan abbey in the Hutton Collection, reads '7th November 1811' and is unsigned. This effigy appears to be of a robed man lying down. There are two notes relating to it on either side of the title. One reads 'Length abt 5½ Feet'. The other, which appears to identify the subject of the effigy, reads 'Allan Lord of Galloway?' Allan Macdonald, Lord of Galloway (c.1170-1233) was the great-grandson of Fergus, Lord of Galloway (c.1078-1166), who founded Dundrennan Abbey in 1142 for an order of Cistercian monks..

Engraved slab from Saddell Abbey, Argyllshire. A note beneath the title on this pencil sketch reads, 'It is near Macdonald's within the ruins of the church'. There is no name attached to this drawing. Unusually there is also no name attached to this, what appears to be, grave marker. The slab shows a large, flat-hilted sword, which is impaling a rabbit. The top quarter of the stone features unspecified designs. Unidentified tombstones marked by plain swords usually denote Knights Templar graves. It is known that the Knights Templar were gifted land in this area during the fourteenth century..

rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This sketch, made in October 1811, shows a Latin inscription that appeared on a stone in Annan, Dumfriesshire. A note below the inscription reads, 'Stone in the garden of a house belonging to Mr Haliday [?] at Annan'. The artist is unknown, although it is quite likely to have been Hutton himself. On the right side, and underneath the drawing, are the exact measurements of the inscription on the stone. Although it is difficult to decipher the writing, the top line does appear to contain the name of Robert Bruce. Moreover, the date at the end of the inscription is 1300. Given Robert the Bruce's association with Dumfries and the surrounding area, it seems likely that this stone connects to Scotland's ancient king and hero of the Wars of Independence..

This drawing shows two armorial arms located in the interior of St Andrews Parish Church, Gullane. The artist has also chosen to include an example of the decorative detail from the circular arch. Two further drawings in the Hutton Collection clearly show the two interior arches. St Andrew's Parish Church was built in the twelfth century and abandoned during the early-seventeenth century. The parish church moved to Dirleton in 1612, partly in response to the sandstorms that swept around St Andrews in its exposed and isolated location. Interestingly, the last vicar of St Andrews was apparently removed from his post by King James VI for smoking tobacco!.

rdf:Description.dc:creator: Gilbert, Miss
Hutton, George Henry, -1827

rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

Armour on a tombstone at Ardchattan Priory, Argyllshire, 'by Miss Gilbert'. Alex the 6th probably refers to Alexander Campbell, the 6th Laird of Lochinell or Lochnell. This is one of three drawings completed by Miss Gilbert of the area and one ten views of Ardchattan. Ardchattan, still a substantial ruin, houses an impressive collection of craved stones. The earliest of these dates from the 900s and depicts a Celtic cross. Someone later cut it up to serve as a grave cover. Most of the rest of the stones are grave markers from the fifteenth and sixteenth centuries. After the Reformation, the priory became a parish church with further secular grave stones installed..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Blantyre Priory with Bothwell Castle on the opposite side of the River Clyde, October 13. 1800.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827

rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

In this drawing of Blantyre Priory and Bothwell Castle, Lanarkshire, the Priory is on the left and the Castle is on top of the hill. This drawing is one of four, which are contained in the Hutton Collection. It conveys the priory's surroundings better than the others do. Although the site of Bothwell Castle was originally in the possession of the Olifard's, it was Walter de Moravia (Moray), who began building work here in 1242. The castle is most famous for its 65 foot diameter Donjon and 15 foot thick walls, dating from the 1270s. Archibald, 3rd Earl of Douglas, acquired the castle and, true to form, invested in further fortifications. The castle finally disappeared in 1926, after losing stone for most of the previous century..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Blantyre priory.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

There is no title, artist or date attached to this sheet, but it belongs with another three drawings that depict Blantyre Priory and the River Clyde. The other three all date from the turn of the eighteenth century. The priory is just visible in the copse of trees, and the brickwork was red and so would have been visible. Rather than highlighting this beautiful contrast, the artist has chosen to stylise and blend the priory into its surroundings. Patrick, Earl of Dunbar established the Priory at Blantyre between 1238 and 1249; he was also responsible for founding the Trinitarian complex at Dunbar in 1218. Blantyre was a daughter house of Jedburgh Abbey and was of the Augustinian Order. Patrick's foundation of ecclesiastical houses not only adhered to royal policy, but also directly mimicked royal power and behaviour. His actions represented a sign of loyalty and obedience..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Blantyre Castle.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Gilbert, Miss
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This is a drawing of Blantyre Priory, Lanarkshire by Miss Gilbert, dated 1798. A note is largely illegible, but it appears to talk about the smaller priory remains and the red colour of the bricks. Although labelled the 'Castle', the building in this sketch is the priory, the Castle being a round structure perched on the top of the hill opposite. Drawings of this layout are also contained in the Hutton Collection. Pope Innocent IV officially inaugurated the Augustinian Order in 1244. Although formed of hermits, the main purpose of the order was to live in communal harmony, intent upon the worship and word of God. One of the great four medieval mendicant orders, Augustinians also worked among the lay community. This was often in direct contrast to many of the reclusive and contemplative medieval orders. Blantyre, founded in the mid-thirteenth century, was a daughter house of the abbey at Jedburgh..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Collegiate Church of Bothwell.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Grose, Francis, 1731?-1791
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

Captain Francis Grose made this drawing of the Collegiate Church at Bothwell around 1790. Grose was famous for his drawings of Scottish churches, many of which appeared in his book, 'The Antiquities of Scotland' published in 1791. The first Earl of Douglas founded Bothwell Collegiate Church in October 1398, during the reign of King Robert II of Scotland. The church is one of only two Scottish collegiate churches which were founded before 1400 - the other exception being Dunbar Collegiate Church. Dedicated to St Bride, the church started with a provost and eight prebendaries, and came richly endowed..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Brechin Cathedral and Round Tower, Angus.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This drawing shows a south-east view of Brechin Cathedral and its round tower. Drawn in October 1820, this is one of several drawings of the Cathedral in the Hutton Collection. A note below the drawing reads, 'The Maison Dieu is on the north side of the town, in the [lane?] or street called the Vennel, or Maison Dieu Street'. They built Brechin Cathedral in a gothic style with pink sandstone during the thirteenth century, although the building's two surviving round towers date back to the eleventh century. The Pictish round tower is about 1,000 years old and Irish in style. It is the oldest part of the cathedral, probably built by Irish masons. The surrounding graveyard has many interesting gravestones and tombs, many of which commemorate the victims of the plague that decimated the town during the seventeenth century..

This drawing shows the ruins of Coldingham Priory, Berwickshire, which is located in the Scottish Borders, very close to the North Sea coast. The name of the artist has not been included. Edgar, King of Scots, probably founded the church at Coldingham in or around 1098. The church quickly evolved into a priory, inhabited by monks of St Cuthbert from Durham, Northumbria. As with so many of Scotland's church buildings, Coldingham Priory suffered during the Scottish Reformation..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Remains of the Abbey of Coupar in Angus, looking west. Aug 28. 1820.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

A note under the title explains that 'These small remains are on the Dundee Road adjoining the South West angle of the church yard, and are supposed to have been the Porter's Lodge'. The name of the artist has not been included. King Malcolm IV founded Coupar Abbey in the mid-twelfth century. Established as a Cistercian House, dedicated to the Virgin Mary, Protestant reformers burnt the building in 1559. All that remains of the original abbey are a few carved and moulded stones and the gatehouse. As was often the case with such ruins, for years the abbey was a quarry for local buildings..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Collegiate Church & Cross at Cullen, east view.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

Cullen Collegiate Church and Mercat Cross, Banffshire. This drawing dates from August 1st 1815, but is unsigned, and may be one of Hutton's own works. A note beneath the title reads, 'The Cross is a hexagon. On one of the sides is the Virgin & Babe, on another one the Royal Arms. The other sides are plain. The Cross has been removed since this sketch was made'. Cullen Mercat Cross now stands in the town's main square. The cross has changed location several times, and may date back almost as far as the burgh's original foundation in the twelfth century. Edward I of England may have burnt the first burgh of Cullen, of which no trace now remains, in about 1303. A small community then grew up around Cullen House, seat of the Earl of Findlater, but the modern town centre was developed in the eighteenth century with the growth of the textile industry, and the planned community of Seatown, on the coast, was added when the fishing industry began to boom in the nineteenth century..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Seton Church.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

The sketches show decorative detail from Seton Collegiate Church, East Lothian. A note at the top of the paper reads, 'Seton Church Communicated by Captain Grose'. In this instance Captain Grose was most likely Francis Grose, the celebrated antiquarian and author of 'The Antiquities of Scotland' (1791). There are several other drawings relating to Seton Church contained in the Hutton Collection. Whilst Seton Collegiate Church was established in the late-fifteenth century, it actually stands on the site of a much earlier parish church dating back to the mid-thirteenth century. Founded by the Seton family, the Collegiate Church was extended by subsequent generations, including the widow of the fourth Lord Seton who was killed during the Battle of Flodden in 1513. Following his death, Lady Seton commissioned the construction of the transepts and steeple..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Dirleton Castle, Mid Lothian, 1782.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

Although the artist has written ‘Midlothian’ on this drawing, Dirleton Castle is in fact in East Lothian. The drawing shows the castle and its environs, including part of the coastline. In the area to the right of the castle, two people, a dog and a small flock of sheep have all been sketched in very faintly. Built in the thirteenth century, the original stone castle consisted of two square towers and four round towers. Throughout the centuries, the castle underwent many changes and alterations, often because of invasion. It was finally abandoned as a residence in the seventeenth century. For many years, stones were gathered from the ruin to build cottages and walls in the local area..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Carvings on the doors of the abbey of Dundrennan.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This drawing is neither dated nor signed by the artist, and may be the work of George Henry Hutton himself. The fine detail of the carvings shows in the drawings, but there are no notes on the sheet to suggest whether the designs have any particular significance or symbolism. The substantial ruins of Dundrennan Abbey lie among hills several miles south-east of Kirkcudbright. Fergus, Lord of Galloway founded the Abbey in 1142 for an order of Cistercian monks. It became one of the wealthiest in Scotland, owning over 3000 sheep by the late thirteenth century and boasting a booming wool trade. The Reformation in 1560 marked the start of the abbey's decline, and although it appears to have been still thriving when Mary, Queen of Scots stayed there in 1568, by the late seventeenth century the buildings had begun to fall into ruin..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Duff House.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Adam, William, 1689-1748
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This drawing is entitled simply, 'Duff House'. The artist has neither signed nor dated it. It is a drawing of Duff House made from the south-east, and looking north-west towards the grand, south-facing front of the house and the church towers and houses of the town of Banff beyond. This is the only image of Duff House contained in the Hutton Collection. Duff House sits in parkland to the south-east of Banff. William Adam designed it for William Duff of Braco, later Earl of Fife, and began building it in 1735, with stone brought by sea from the Firth of Forth. Duff rejected the house, however, and since the eighteenth century, it has served variously as a home, a hotel, a sanatorium, and a prisoner-of-war camp. The National Galleries of Scotland now owns it..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Part of Dunbar Castle 1782.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This drawing shows a significant portion of the castle ruins. The remains of a large archway are clearly defined, as are a number of stone carvings. The artist has also chosen to include significant landmarks located on the horizon, including (from left to right) North Berwick Law, Tantallon Castle and the Bass Rock. Built in the twelfth century and situated on a rocky headland, Dunbar Castle was originally the seat of the Gospatrick family. Due to its coastal location, with the only main route into the castle from the mainland heavily fortified, Dunbar Castle was considered impenetrable. Throughout the centuries, it was the scene of many clashes between the English and the Scots. It is perhaps best remembered as the chosen refuge of Mary, Queen of Scots following the deaths of David Rizzio (1566) and Lord Darnley (1567)..

rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This drawing, dated September 1816, shows the east end of Dunbar Collegiate Church. Although the drawing is faint, it offers a valuable record of an important ecclesiastical building that has since disappeared. Founded in the early-fourteenth century by Patrick, 9th Earl of Dunbar, Dunbar Collegiate Church was the first collegiate church to be established in the Lothians, if not in the whole of Scotland - some claim that title for Abernethy Collegiate Church. The building no longer exists and Dunbar Parish Church now stands on the original site. The construction of the parish church commenced around three years after this sketch was completed..

rdf:Description.dc:title: At Inveraray, Oct 1820, drawn from the Inn.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This drawing shows Duniquaich Hill and its watchtower, which overlooks the Argyllshire town of Inveraray. The hill’s name derives from its physical resemblance to a drinking cup, or goblet. Dun means 'hill', while quaich is derived from the Gaelic word 'Cuach', which means 'shallow cup' or in modern terms, a 'drinking cup'. The artist of this drawing is unknown. The town of Inveraray is traditionally the headquarters of the Campbell Clan. The watchtower on the summit of Duniquaich Hill is 700 feet above sea level, and provides an eagle's view of Inveraray, the surrounding countryside and Loch Fyne. Given the history of clan warfare in Scotland and the reputation of the Campbell Clan, a lookout tower would have been an essential requirement for the town..

Hutton, George Henry, -1827

The titles on these drawings explain that the first two came from the Bishop's Palace in Elgin, and the third from Pluscarden Abbey. All three features come from paintings and depict human figures in various poses. The images may date from 1790. This is one of six images of Pluscarden Priory, founded in 1230 by Alexander II, which together form a comprehensive view of the site in the eighteenth and nineteenth centuries. There are two sheets, which carry depictions of the priory's decorative architecture. This is the only sheet, however, which represents the Bishop's Palace in Elgin..

Hutton, George Henry, -1827

A note reads 'From the original drawings made on the spot by Capt. E.H. Columbine, R. Navy, who favoured me with the loan of them, 1801'. Of the five drawings, two are of free-standing, and still standing, Celtic crosses. The other three are of tombstone and interior decorations. These drawings illustrate the unique blend of Celtic and Norse cultures that characterises the history of the western sea board of Scotland..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Hailes Castle on the Tyne between Haddington and Linton, 1782.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Seaton family
Dalrymple family
Hepburn family
Stuart family
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

Due to its exposed location and style, the castle was never defendable. This meant that it rarely played a leading role in the politics of power in Scotland. It comprises a fourteenth-century keep, surrounded by a thirteenth-century curtain wall, with fifteenth- and sixteenth-century extensions. Hailes Castle was originally one of the manor houses of the Hepburn family, although after the family's fall at Flodden, it passed through the hands of the Stewarts, Setons and Dalrymples. It also regularly changed hands between English and Scottish administrators. Hailes was transferred to state ownership by the Earl of Balfour in 1924, and the building is now administered by Historic Scotland..

rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This drawing shows the ruins of Innerwick Castle, as viewed from below. The castle, which is strategically positioned on a high rocky outcrop, clearly dominates the surrounding landscape. Also included in the Hutton Collection is a very simplistic drawing of the castle from the same angle: possibly a preliminary sketch by the same artist. Originally built for the Stewart family, Innerwick Castle passed to the Hamiltons before being captured and destroyed by the Duke of Somerset in the mid-sixteenth century. Although the remains of Innerwick Castle are still visible today, in the seventeenth century the ruins suffered a common fate; after being destroyed and abandoned, it was used as a quarry to provide building materials for the local area..

rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This drawing, of an inscription in Cullen Collegiate Church, Banffshire, has neither date nor artist’s name. Above the title a transcription of the words that appear on the inscribed arch, probably made by Hutton, is included. The arch appears to be part of a monument in memory of an important local family called Hay. Alexander Ogilvie of Deskford founded Cullen Collegiate Church in 1543 and dedicated it to St Mary, the patron saint of Cullen, whose image also appears on the Mercat Cross. It was one of the latest collegiate foundations in Scotland, coming just two years before the opening of Biggar Collegiate Church, which was the last such establishment in the country. Collegiate churches housed a 'college' of clergy dedicated to Christian learning but also devoted to securing salvation for the church's founders through special masses and prayers..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Lincluden - window on the South side, next the West end.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

Interior detail, Lincluden Collegiate Church, Dumfriesshire. This sketch shows a detail from 'a window in Lincluden Collegiate Church, near Dumfries. A note following the title reads, The inscription perhaps legible with a glass - 27th Oct. 1811'. There are a number of other drawings detailing Lincluden Collegiate Church contained in the Hutton Collection. Archibald the Grim, 3rd Earl of Douglas, founded Lincluden Collegiate Church, which stands on the site of a Benedictine nunnery, in 1389. It continued, as a college into the late-sixteenth century and after its dissolution became the local quarry. Although much of the stone work disappeared, large parts of the church remain, including much of the chancel and south transept. Importantly, and uniquely in Scotland, the priests' accommodation has survived..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Icolmkill.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Daniell, William, 1769-1837
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

Iona Abbey ruins, Argyllshire. 'From an original sketch made on the spot by W[illia]m Daniell, Esq., A.R.A., July 1st 1815'. More writing reads: ' The little detached ruin is the nunnery'. It would now appear that the building was a chapel and not a nunnery. It is St Oran's Chapel, named for St Columba's cousin and companion. William Daniell (1769-1837) is more famous for his aquatint publication, of the Indian landscape. Between 1786 and 1793, he toured India with his uncle, Tomas, also an artist. Together they travelled further into India than any previous artists. Inspired by the style of William Hodges (1744-97) and the breathtaking scenery, they went on to capture unparalleled images of India's monuments, architecture and landscape. This copy of his abbey painting, however, stands as a testament to a transfer of inspiration and the work he went on to complete in Great Britain..

rdf:Description.dc:creator: Daniell, William, 1769-1837
Hutton, George Henry, -1827

Iona Abbey, Argyllshire, by W. Daniell, Esq., A.R.A., July 1. 1815'. This item is one of nine, which together form a unique record of the many of Iona's monuments. The artist, William Daniell, is more famous for his images of Indian landscape, but his British work covered a longer time span and is of the same quality. The restoration of the abbey ruins began in 1901when funding for a new roof came from public appeal. This had taken two years to organise after the Duke of Argyll gave the site to the Iona Cathedral Trust. This was because of the adverse financial effects of the Boar Wars. It was not until 1938, however, and the establishment of Rev. George F. MacLeod's Iona Community, that further work was completed. Rev. McLeod instigated a cohesive, long-term building plan, eventually completed in 1965..

rdf:Description.dc:creator: Grose, Francis, 1731?-1791

Kilwinning Abbey, Ayrshire. This drawing is simply entitled 'Kilwinning'. It was drawn about 1789 by Captain Francis Grose, and reproduced in his book 'The Antiquities of Scotland', which was published by Samuel Hooper of London in 1791.This is one of three views of Kilwinning Abbey contained in the Hutton Collection, each by a different artist. St Winning reputedly founded the first church at Kilwinning in Ayrshire in AD 715. The Tironesian Abbey, built in 1162, was an offshoot of Kelso Abbey, but quickly became a highly important ecclesiastical centre in its own right. Like many Scottish abbeys, Kilwinning suffered great structural damage at the hands of Reformers in 1560, although a small part of it became a parish church..

This drawing shows the extensive ruins of Lincluden Collegiate Church, near Dumfries. The artist's name and the date have not been included. Archibald Grim, 3rd Earl of Douglas, established Lincluden Collegiate Church in the late-fourteenth century. It stood on the site of a Benedictine nunnery and included accommodation for its canons. Archibald’s son, the 4th Earl of Douglas, may have added the impressive chancel. It houses the tomb of Margaret, who was the daughter of King Robert III and wife to the 4th Earl..

This drawing of Lismore Parish Church, Argyll, from the south-west, dates from September 1820 but is unsigned. The drawing shows a south-west view of the parish church of Lismore, set among trees and graves, with the hills of the island of Lismore rising behind it. This is the only drawing of Lismore in the Hutton Collection. The origins of the parish church of Lismore are among the earliest of any church in Scotland..

This drawing shows 'Bickerton's Tomb' in the ruins of Luffness Friary, near Aberlady; dated September 1802, it includes descriptive notes at the bottom of the sheet. According to the description, the length of the figure below the arch is around six feet. A shield covers the heart and the remains of a sword are held in the right hand. There is also mention of a stone coffin underneath the figure. The Carmelite monastery at Luffness was founded in the thirteenth century. The land was apparently gifted to the Carmelites by Sir David de Lindsay, who prior to his death was cared for by the members of the order. The tomb in this drawing is said to be that of Sir David, and the stone beneath the figure his coffin..

This drawing shows one of a number of monuments from Saddell Abbey. The Hutton Collection includes further drawings detailing the famous grave slabs and other monuments found at Saddell. Saddell Abbey is famous for its impressive sculpted stones commemorating the wealthy and powerful lords who were its patrons. For years, people thought of these large stones as coming from Iona and shipped over to Saddell. This has changed, and a carving school probably existed at Saddell Abbey itself..

Part of a memorial inscription in Kilmun Collegiate Church, Argyllshire. George Henry Hutton's note with this drawing reads, 'It is said to have been part of the inscription of the Monument of Sir Duncan Campbell & his wife'. The drawing dates from 5th August 1802, but is unsigned. It is likely, however, that this was one of Hutton's own works. The monument to Sir Duncan Campbell, or the Black Knight of Loch Awe, lay in the vault of Kilmun Collegiate Church, although the fragment drawn here appears to have become separated from the monument and been built into the new parish church of Kilmun. The memorial to Campbell, who founded Kilmun Collegiate Church in 1442, depicts him in full armour lying by the side of his wife..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Pluscarden Priory, Moray.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Graham, James Gillespie, 1776-1855
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This sketch shows Pluscarden Priory from the north-east. It has been copied from a drawing by the Edinburgh-based architect, James Gillespie [Graham], and is dated 1815. According to the note underneath the drawing, the original was in the possession of the Earl of Fife. Sketches of the south-east and north-west views are also contained in the Hutton Collection. Situated around six miles from Elgin, King Alexander II founded Pluscarden Priory in 1230. It was the first of three houses established in Scotland by the Valliscaulian Order, and the only one to receive royal patronage: the other houses were located at Beauly and Ardchattan. As with all Valliscaulian houses, Pluscarden was dedicated to the Virgin Mary and John the Baptist - and uniquely, St Andrew - and had strong links to the mother house at Val des Chouz in Burgundy..

The artist's name is not included anywhere on the picture. This is a clearer illustration than most of the other half-dozen pictures of Restenneth in the Hutton Collection, and gives a better idea of the extent of the ruins. Trees and shrubs to the south partially obscure the building. In this sketch, Restenneth Priory looks much as it does today. The steeple is largely intact, but the roof is missing from the rest of the building, and some walls have crumbled away. Within the main body of the priory, some of the elaborate sculpture and ornamentation on the church walls has survived. The priory is of considerable antiquity. Most of it dates from a twelfth-century Augustinian building, but some parts of the walls are the remains of a Pictish foundation from four or five centuries earlier..

Ruined arch at Ardchattan Priory, Argyllshire, by Miss Gilbert. It remains today on the south side of the choir. It is quite unusual to see such soaring and pointed arch tops buried into the ground. Three other pencil sketches of Ardchattan Priory are included in the Hutton Collection..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Remains of the Mathurine Monastery of Scotland-Well, drawn from the south with the Bishop's Hill.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

Scotlandwell Friary, Kinross-shire. The drawing reads, 'October 17th, 1789', but is unsigned. It is the only drawing or sketch relating to Scotlandwell in the Hutton Collection. Scotlandwell, to the east of Loch Leven in Kinross-shire, takes its name from the well or spring around which it was built. Trinitarians (also known as Mathurines, or Red Friars) were gifted a hospital, on the site of an earlier Celtic religious foundation, in the thirteenth century. The friars used the spring water to cure various diseases, and Robert the Bruce is reputed to have visited the friary seeking a cure for his leprosy. Today, only the foundations and a few gravestones remain of the friary..

rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827

A note in the bottom left-hand corner of this drawing reads, 'Collegiate Church of Seton, Haddingtonshire 1781'. It was reproduced in volume I of Captain Francis Grose's famous book, 'The Antiquities of Scotland', published in 1791. Built in the late-fifteenth century and dedicated to St Mary and the Holy Cross, Seton Collegiate Church was founded by the Seton family. It was built on the site of a much earlier parish church, which was incorporated into the present building. It dated from the thirteenth century. Throughout the remainder of fifteenth century and the sixteenth century, subsequent members of the family continued to extend the church..

This is a drawing of St Andrew's Church, North Berwick, by James S Richardson, L.L.D. It shows a reconstruction of the church in its heyday. No date is given. Originally built in the twelfth century, the building suffered extensive erosion and was little more than a ruin by the mid-seventeenth century. However, a new site for St Andrew's Church was soon identified close to the town's High Street..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Rowadil Priory in Harris.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Grose, Francis, 1731?-1791
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This drawing is 'by Capt. Grose from a sketch . . . to me 1789'. It shows the exterior of St Clement's Church at Rodel, Harris, also known as the Church of Rodel. The artist, Captain Grose, is most likely Francis Grose, the celebrated antiquarian and author of 'The Antiquities of Scotland', published in 1791. St Clement's Church was built in the late-fifteenth or early-sixteenth century for the MacLeods of Harris, by Alexander MacLeod of Dunvegan and Harris. It probably stands on the site of a much earlier church, and may be one of the most impressive buildings in whole of the Western Isles. Although it fell into disuse and disrepair following the Reformation, subsequent years have seen extensive programmes of repair and restoration..

rdf:Description.dc:creator: Columbine, Edward Henry, 1762-1811
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827

This watercolour copy is from a drawing made on the spot by Captain E. H. Columbine in 1792. It shows the north, now outside, wall of the chapel. The copy is unsigned. The cloisters and administration buildings are behind the chapel, to the south of this view. Reginald, Lord of the Isles, who installed his sister Bethoc as its prioress, founded this nunnery in 1203. The house was of the Augustinian Order. The only other practising Augustinian nunnery in Scotland was in Perth. The nunnery slipped into gradual decline and closed at the Reformation..

Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This drawing shows St Mary's Collegiate Church and the sixteenth-century Nungate Bridge. It is possibly a copy of an engraving that also forms part of the Hutton Collection. St Mary's Collegiate Church and the Nungate Bridge are two of Haddington's most important landmarks, and both are instantly recognisable to those familiar with the town. The largest parish church in Scotland, St Mary's dates from the fourteenth century and is considered one of the three great pre-Reformation churches of the Lothians: the other two are St Giles in Edinburgh and St Michael's in Linlithgow. The existing Nungate Bridge was built in the sixteenth century, although a bridge has stood in this area since the 1200s..

rdf:Description.dc:title: St Mary's Priory and Berwick Law, North Berwick, East Lothian.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This drawing shows the town of North Berwick from a distance, with St Mary's Priory on the left, and the impressive form of Berwick Law as a backdrop. Although no date has been attached, it was likely sketched in the early 1780s. The Hutton Collection includes further drawings of St Mary's and of St Andrew's Church in North Berwick. The oldest building in North Berwick, the twelfth-century Cistercian nunnery or priory devoted to the Virgin Mary was one of three Cistercian houses in the Lothians: the other two were Newbattle Abbey, near Dalkeith, and the priory at Haddington. Interestingly, between the twelfth and sixteenth centuries, Berwick Law was the property of the nunnery, during which time a beacon was maintained at the summit..

rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

A note in the bottom left-hand corner of this drawing reads, 'North Berwick Nunnery 1782'. It shows the remains of St Mary's Priory and part of the coastline around North Berwick, including the Bass Rock. A cow grazing in a nearby field has also been sketched in. There are at least two other drawings or plans relating to St Mary's contained in the Hutton Collection. St Mary's Priory is thought to date from the twelfth century, when it was founded by Duncan, Earl of Fife. It was one of three Cistercian houses in the Lothians: the other two were the priory at Haddington and Newbattle Abbey, near Dalkeith. The Cistercians were also known as 'white monks' due to the white robes they wore. Established in 1098 by St Robert, they were devoted to prayer and physical toil..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Tantallon Castle, with the Bass and the Isle of May 1782.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

Tantallon Castle ruins, East Lothian. This view is painted from the interior courtyard of the castle and captures the stunning view the inhabitants would have enjoyed. Most of the building remains date from the fourteenth century, with the overall appearance based on French chateau architecture. Originally, in the possession of the Earls of Fife, Tantallon is now better known as a stronghold of the Douglas family. In 1389, the castle passed to the Earl of Angus, a Red Douglas, but after the tenth Earl died in 1588, the castle fell into disuse. The castle was attacked by both the English and Scottish crowns as the Douglas family changed allegiances and whilst asserting their independence. It was eventually inherited by the Dalrymple family, who gifted it to the state in 1924..

This sketch depicts Terregles Church (alternative name, Terregles Queir) and its graveyard, which is located two miles north-west of Dumfries. Although the name of the artist has not been included on the drawing, it is quite likely to have been George Hutton himself. The parish church at Terregles is especially associated with Lady Agnes Herries, whose burial aisle became part of the church building itself in 1588. The churchyard at Terregles contains many monuments from the seventeenth and eighteenth centuries, and has links with a famous statue of John of Holywood, who was a famous mathematician, astronomer and theologian during the early-thirteenth century. The Hutton Collection contains two drawings of this statue..

This undated drawing shows the Boatsford Stone, which is located in Nithsdale. On the left side of the page can be seen large-sized, magnified drawings, which appear to depict the intricate features that appear on the stone. There does not appear to be much information regarding the Boatsford Stone. The bridge in the background of the drawing, however, suggests that it is located somewhere near the River Nith. The Hutton Collection contains another fine drawing of the stone by Captain Francis Grose dated around 1790, so it could be that this drawing is part of a pair..

The arch is located in Church Street, which is right in the centre of Dumbarton, and is a popular meeting place for local people..

Detail of a monument from Saddell Abbey, Argyllshire. A note reads, ' /Mr Macalaster of [?] thinks it is a monument of one of the Mackays of [?]'. A further observation on the perspective of the carving is down the other side. It would appear that when viewed from above the figure looks much larger. There is no further information attached to this drawing. This slab is one of many carved stones which are to be found amongst the ruins of Saddell Abbey, and which are now considered to be a treasure-trove of early Scottish art. They are a fantastic pictorial record of the blending of Norse, Celtic and Native cultures along Scotland's west coast..

This sketch shows Pluscarden Priory from the south-east. It has been copied from a drawing by the Edinburgh-based architect, James Gillespie [Graham], and is dated 1815. According to the note underneath the drawing, the original was in the possession of the Earl of Fife. Founded in 1230 by King Alexander II, Pluscarden Priory is the only medieval monastery in Scotland that still houses monks. Built for members of the Valliscaulian order, they dedicated it to the Virgin Mary, John the Baptist and St Andrew. Pluscarden was the first of three priories established by the order in Scotland: the other two were at Beauly and Ardchattan..

This drawing, made in 1789 and part of a pair in the Hutton Collection, depicts the ornate stone font of Canonbie Priory. A note below the drawing reads, 'Font once belonging to Canonbie Priory 1789'. Hutton may have made this drawing himself. David I of Scotland founded the Priory at Canonbie during the twelfth century. As can be guessed from the etymology of its name, 'The Town of Canons', Canonbie was a well-known religious centre in the Scottish Borders. Reputedly, Lord Wharton destroyed the priory following the Battle of Solway Moss in 1542, during the 'rough wooing' prelude to the Scottish Reformation..

Showing a Franciscan friary in Elgin, Morayshire, from the north-west, this sheet is unsigned, but the drawing appears to be by the same hand as another study of Elgin's Franciscan friary, made from the south-east, that is contained in the Hutton Collection. Both drawings read 'August 1819'. The Franciscan friary, now church, in this drawing still stands intact in Elgin, on a site on Greyfriars Street a little south-east of the High Street and south of the ruins of the medieval cathedral. This was the second Franciscan friary in the town by 1479. The first grew up two centuries earlier on a site a little to the north on South College Street, but it appears to have declined in the late-fourteenth or early-fifteenth century..

One of a number of drawings and sketches from Elgin contained in the Hutton Collection, this view of the former Franciscan friary in Elgin, Morayshire from the south-west, Is dated August 1819, but the name of the artist is not supplied. A Franciscan or 'Grey' friary first appeared in Elgin in the thirteenth century, but despite receiving a grant from David II of Scotland in 1357, it appears to have gone into decline. A second community of Franciscans arrived in 1479 and they erected the friary church depicted in this drawing, which still stands in Elgin today. The church, restored in the nineteenth century, is one of Scotland's best-preserved friary churches..

rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827

rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

Made in 1811, this drawing shows the interior of the Franciscan Friary at Dumfries. Central to the drawing is the fireplace and boiling pot, with cooking and fire-starting utensils hanging on the wall at the top of the sketch. The name of the artist has not been included. Lady Devorgilla, daughter of the Lord of Galloway, founded Dumfries Friary in or around 1262. Also known as, Greyfriars, the Convent stands in a beautiful spot in Dumfries, overlooking the River Nith. Rumour has it that the friary is the location where Robert the Bruce killed Red Comyn, thus causing the start of the Scottish Wars of Independence..

rdf:Description.dc:title: King's Cave, near Ayr.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This sketch shows the King's Cave, which is located on the shoreline close to the seaside town of Ayr. The date given is October 1811. The artist is unknown, although it is quite likely to have been Hutton himself. This cave is commonly confused with the King's Cave on the Isle of Arran, which is where Robert the Bruce is reputed to have watched the indefatigable spider. Another famous cave in the sandstone cliffs near Ayr is Peden's Cave, where the Covenanter, Alexander Peden, gave sermons to his congregation. Local legend has it that this cave is where Robert Burns parted from Mary Campbell, after pledging his love for her..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Town Hall and Ch. at Lauder, Berwickshire.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This drawing, of Main square, Lauder, Berwickshire, is undated, and unsigned by the artist. This is the only image of Lauder in the Hutton Collection. In this drawing, the Town Hall or Tollbooth of Lauder is in the foreground, to the left. The artist has given a strong impression of the manner in which the distinctive building, with its steeple and entrance at the top of a flight of broad steps, dominates the square at the centre of Lauder. The church, built in 1673, is behind the Tollbooth, slightly left of centre, and is a very distinctive building. Its design has the body of the church laid out in a Greek Cross shape around a central pulpit, and the bell-tower octagonal in form and built above the centre point of the church, and is unique in Scotland..

rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

Of the Maison Dieu Chapel in Brechin, Angus, this faint drawing, made in 1814, shows its south-west view. A note at the bottom of the drawing provides the audience with some historical information about the ruined chapel. The term, Maison Dieu, is French for 'The House of God'. The Maison Dieu Chapel originally belonged to a medieval hospital, founded in 1267 by Lord William de Brechin. Little now remains of this alms house, although an ambry (a recess in a church wall for holding e.g. sacramental vessels), some finely-detailed doors and a few Gothic window frames are in the drawing..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Pillar at Deadrig, Berwickshire.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

Drawing of North and east sides of a pillar at Deadrig, Berwickshire. It is dated 1785 but is unsigned by the artist. A later hand has added a note, which reads 'AND E Sides'. This is one of two views of the pillar at Deadrig, both apparently by the same hand. The designs carved on this pillar suggest that it is a memorial to someone. On the side most clearly drawn, directly beneath the cross at the head of the pillar, there is an image of a man, with arms crossed over his chest in the manner of someone who at rest. Beneath this, there is a picture of an animal, perhaps a hunting dog, maybe buried with its master..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Kinloss Abbey looking south.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This drawing, probably by George Hutton, is dated August 8th 1815. There are a number of drawings of the abbey in Hutton's collection, as well as a plan by Andrew Nisbet. Kinloss Abbey lies 3 miles north-east of Forres. Dedicated to the Blessed Virgin Mary, King David I founded the Abbey in 1150 when the monks of the Cistercian Order inhabited it. It received its Papal Bull from Pope Alexander III in 1174 and came under the protection of the Bishop of Moray in 1187. It ceased to be an active monastery in the mid-seventeenth century..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Northern section of a ground-plan of Coupar Angus Abbey.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Mitchell, John, artist in Coupar Angus
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This drawing does not carry a title, but it depicts the smaller, northern section of a ground-plan of Coupar Angus Abbey, Perthshire. It was drawn over two pages by a mason from Coupar Angus named as John Mitchell here, but as William Mitchell on another drawing in the Hutton Collection. The date on the page containing the southern section is December 1820. We do not know whether Mitchell drew the plan by copying an earlier existing plan, or whether he made an archaeological study of the foundations of the abbey. The plan shows many features of the abbey that did not exist by the time Hutton was building up his collection. The abbey appears surrounded by a wall named 'Agricola's Wall', probably after the Roman Governor who led an invasion of Scotland about AD 80. As well as providing the outlines of the walls of the various buildings in the abbey complex, the plan also suggests that there were castellated gate-houses on each of the walls. One of these is all that was left standing after Protestant reformers burnt the Abbey in 1559. Locals then dismantled it for building materials..

rdf:Description.dc:creator: Graham, James Gillespie, 1776-1855
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827

This is a drawing of the north-west view of Pluscarden Priory, Moray. A note explains how the original drawing was the work of James Gilliespie and the Earl of Fife was the keeper. The note, however, does not clarify who completed this copy, but it is dated 1815. We know more about Pluscarden Priory's garden than the establishment itself. Monastic houses, as medieval centres of learning, were closely associated with medicine and horticulture. As such, they kept wide-ranging and often exotic herb and pleasure gardens. All three of the Valliscaulian establishments founded in Scotland enjoyed an impressive reputation for the quality of their garden enclosures..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Haddington Nunnery 1784.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

The artist has sketched the remains of a nunnery at Haddington, which by 1784 appears to have been little more than a stone vault. A general impression of the surrounding area, including two buildings, has also been provided. The nunnery was founded in 1178 and was one of three Cistercian houses in the Lothians: the other two being Newbattle Abbey, near Dalkeith, and the nunnery at North Berwick. The Cistercians were also known as the 'white monks' because of the simple white robes they wore. Strictly vegetarian, they divided their days between prayer and physical work that included tending their gardens and orchards..

rdf:Description.dc:title: In the Old Church, Banff.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

The artist, of this undated drawing of the Ogilvie Monument in St. Mary’s Church, Banff, was 'W. Hay', and was probably William Hay, who drew other works in the Hutton Collection. The drawing gives a detailed impression of a monument, consisting of two decorative inscribed panels sculpted from the stone wall under a window in the church. It is one of four images relating to St Mary's Church in the collection. The inscription on the monument reveals that it is in memory of Walter Ogilvy of Dunlugus, Lord Banff, who died in 1558, and his wife Alison Hume, who died in 1557. The lower panel, which dates from 1580, commemorates George Ogilvy, who was probably Walter Ogilvy's son. The Ogilvie family of Banff were a branch of one of Scotland's most prominent noble families, headed by the Earl of Airlie, and later acquired the Earldoms of Findlater and Seafield..
