rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827

rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This drawing shows the famous Auld Brig that crosses over the River Ayr in the town of Ayr. The drawing is unsigned. Reputedly built in 1236, the Auld Brig of Ayr is the main subject of Robert Burns’ poem, 'The Brigs of Ayr'. Simpson's was the name of a noted tavern at one end of the bridge, and Burns mentions this locally famous pub in his poem. Local legend has it that two maiden sisters provided the money to build the bridge. A number of people had drowned at this point of the river and so they resolved to have a bridge constructed..

rdf:Description.dc:creator: Stirling, William, Reverend
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

Beneath the title, of this drawing of the old tower of Kilwinning Abbey, Ayrshire, a note, probably by Hutton, reads, 'Comd. by the Revd. Mr Stirling, Minr. Of Port Monteath'. This is one of three images of Kilwinning Abbey contained in the Hutton Collection, each by a different artist. The Reformation of 1560 destroyed much of the medieval abbey at Kilwinning, but the central tower, similar in appearance to that of Glasgow Cathedral, stood until 1814, when it collapsed after a lightning strike had weakened its structure. The phrase 'as it stood' in Hutton's title indicates that he received, or at least titled, before a new tower appeared in 1816..

This is a panoramic view of Kinloss Abbey, Moray and the surrounding area. A note goes on to explain that the Abbot's Lodging, the dormitory and the north wall of the Chapter House are all visible. The highest tower in the image is the south transept of this cruciform plan church: very little else of the complex remains, however, as Alexander Brodie stripped it for profit in 1650, who then sold the stone to Oliver Cromwell. David I originally founded the abbey in 1150 as a Cistercian house. David I pursued a vigorous and well-rounded religious policy, which resulted in the appearance of many monastic houses in Scotland..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Remains of the Old Church of Banff, 1815.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This drawing shows the remains of St Mary's Church, Banff, from the south-west. The artist was William Hay, who contributed two other drawings of St Mary's Church to the Hutton Collection. The ruins of St Mary's Church lie close to the mouth of the River Deveron, south-east of the sea-town but close to the heart of the medieval town of Banff. The church dates from 1471, and became the burial place for the Ogilvie family of Banff, a branch of a prominent Scottish noble family. Much of the church was demolished in 1797 apart from the south aisle, above the Ogilvy burial vault. The churchyard is remarkable for its unusual sculpted gravestones..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Hospital of St Magnus at Spittal in Caithness - S.E. view.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This sheet, dated September 6th 1815, is unsigned by the artist, but it is quite likely that this is one of Hutton's own drawings. A note below the title gives approximate dimensions of the remains: 'External length about 30 paces - Breadth, 9'. This is the only drawing or sketch from Spittal contained in the Hutton Collection. The ruined hospital and chapel of St Magnus lies on the western slopes of Spittal Hill, about 3 miles south-south-east of the town of Halkirk in Caithness. The building is reputed to date from the twelfth century, and its grounds were the burial place of the Clan Gunn until the early twentieth century. St Magnus was the Earl of half of Orkney, killed by his cousin, and fellow earl, Haakon Paulson, in about AD 1116 or 1117. Magnus is the patron saint of Caithness, Orkney and Shetland..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Ardchattan Priory ... Augst.1798.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Gilbert, Miss
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This is the second drawing by Miss Gilbert, with a note down one side of the sheet. This tells of the remodelling of the Priory for secular use in both in 1620 and in 1713. Duncan MacDougall founded Ardchattan in 1230 as a house of the Valliscaulian Order. He was also responsible for establishing the stronghold and power centre at Dunstaffinage Castle. Ardchattan was only one of three Valliscaulian monasteries in Scotland, the other two being Pluscarden and Beauly. Pluscarden was the only establishment to enjoy royal patronage, the other two being associated with lay-lords. After the Reformation, the buildings became the property of the Lords of Lochniell or Lochnell..

Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This is a drawing of the ruins of Coupar Angus Abbey, Perthshire and much of the surrounding area. The artist has written 'tollbooth' in the foreground, suggesting that this view is from outside the tollbooth. A number of other drawings and plans in the Hutton Collection also detail the Abbey and its environs. Founded in the mid-twelfth century by King Malcolm IV, Coupar Angus Abbey was home to members of the Cistercian Order. Also known as, 'white monks', due to their simple robes, the Cistercians chose an austere existence, dividing their time between prayers and working the land. The monks at Coupar Angus Abbey successfully traded wool with continental Europe..

This is one of several unsigned studies of the remains of Coupar Angus Abbey contained in the Hutton Collection. The abbey is located just to the south-east of the town centre, off the main road to Dundee. The only surviving part of Coupar Angus Abbey is a gate-house, and the drawings in the Hutton Collection suggest that this has been the case since at least the late-eighteenth century..

rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827

This is one of several drawings of the Abbey contained in the Hutton Collection, but the artist's name is not given. Here the artist is looking south-west towards the entrance of a gate-house, which is the only surviving part of the abbey. Coupar Angus Abbey, built between 1161 and 1164, stands on land gifted by King Malcolm IV to a group of Cistercian monks from Melrose. By the mid-sixteenth century, it was the wealthiest Cistercian monastery in Scotland but, in 1559, a Reformist mob burnt its buildings. Over the years, the remains were broken up for building material, until only one gate-house remained..

The text underneath reads, 'The sketch shows the ruins of the Conventual Church'. It records deteriorated walls, with arches and niches cut into them - all covered with lush under growth and ivy. Both the archaeological and documentary history of the Ardchattan site remains quite fragmented and inconclusive. The Priory came into being in 1230 as a house of the Valliscaulian Order but over the next 500 years the monastery, private housing and the parish church all existed here..

rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

Although there is no date attached to this sheet, it is one of a series of twelve others, labelled 1815. This image shows two decorated, arched and recessed niches in the interior south wall. The north transept is now the only part of the extant building remains which is intact. This, however, is due to the redesigning and rebuilding work completed by Alexander Ross in 1901. At this time, this area became the private burial space of the Mackenzie family. It is useful therefore to have this much earlier image as it preserves how the original ruins would once have looked..

rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827

No title appears underneath this picture, of the south and east sides of a pillar at Deadrig, Berwickshire. Instead, it is on the base of the pillar, as if it was one of the inscriptions. At the bottom of the sheet, a note explains that the drawing shows the south and west sides of the pillar. Another drawing by the same hand in the Hutton Collection shows the north and east sides. This pillar probably commemorates a warrior from near Deadrig. On one of the sides of the pillar, obscured in this drawing, there is an engraving of a man, apparently laid to rest. The sword in this drawing suggests that this was a man accustomed to fighting in battle. It is not possible from this picture to estimate the age or origins of the cross..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Restennote Priory - south view, 1785.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This is a view of the south side of Restenneth Priory, Angus. The name of the artist is missing but it is likely that it was one of Hutton's own drawings. It is one of a number of drawings of Restenneth Priory, from different perspectives in the collection. In this view, trees and shrubs in the foreground obscure the building, but it is clear that while much of the priory is ruined, the steeple remains largely intact. Restenneth Priory lies about two miles east of Forfar, on the main road to Montrose. No one knows its exact origins, but the first ecclesiastical building on the site might have been a foundation by Picts in the seventh or early eighth century, and some Pictish stonework still exists in the remains of the priory. In the twelfth century, it was a cell of Augustinian canons..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Blantyre Priory, from the South, 13 Oct. 1800.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

In this drawing of the south view of Blantyre Priory, Lanarkshire, The priory is in the centre of a thicket, which conveys the beauty of the setting. This is one of four drawings of Blantyre. Together they make a comprehensive record of the buildings and landscape at the turn of the eighteenth century. There are very little structural remains of the priory now left and so it is difficult to reconstruct the architecture of the site. However, it would have been extensive, incorporating both enclosed ecclesiastical buildings and space for lay interaction. The buildings were of fine-grained red sandstone and there were herbal and contemplative gardens. Although difficult to prove, perhaps Marie de Coucy brought masons from her home chateau in France to work on the priory and the castle..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Pluscarden Priory, S.E. view, Aug. 1815.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This light pencil drawing, dated August 1815, shows the south-east view of Pluscarden Priory. The artist has drawn it from a considerable distance and provided an impression of the surrounding countryside, including fields, trees and, in the background, what is very possibly Heldon Hill. Founded by King Alexander II in 1230, Pluscarden Priory was one of three houses established by the Valliscaulian Order in Scotland: the other two being Beauly and Ardchattan. As with many ecclesiastical buildings, Pluscarden Priory fell into disrepair following the Reformation. At the end of the nineteenth century, a programme of restoration and rebuilding took place and, in 1943, Benedictine monks of Prinknash Abbey took ownership. Monastic life recommenced in the priory in 1948, and in 1974 Pluscarden was elevated to the status of an abbey..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Ground plan of the Abbey of Cupar in Angus.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Mitchell, John, artist in Coupar Angus
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This is the southern section of a ground-plan of Coupar Angus Abbey, Perthshire. A note by Hutton at the bottom of the sheet reads 'Copied from a Plan [comd.] by Mr John Mitchell, Cupar in Angus, Decr. 1820'. Mitchell is referred to by Hutton as 'William' on another drawing in the collection, so doubt remains over which was his real name. The plan is over two pages and this, the southern section, is the larger of the two parts. By the time, Hutton visited Coupar Angus, all that remained standing of the abbey was a gate-house: Protestant reformers burnt the rest in 1559 and locals plundered its ruins for building stone. However, the floor plans shown here contain details of the entire abbey. Hutton's note does not make clear whether Mitchell's drew his plan from older existing plans or from an archaeological study of the abbey's foundations..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Stone font of Canonbie or Canonby Priory, Dumfriesshire.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

One of a pair included in the Hutton Collection, this drawing shows the elaborate stone font of Canonbie Priory. A note below the drawing reads, 'Font which belonged to Canonbie Priory in Eskdale, Drawn 1789'. Again, Hutton may have drawn this. Fonts became commonplace in Scottish churches during the sixth century, and were generally used for baptising purposes, as the word means 'spring'. Inhabited by monks of the Augustinian Order, David I of Scotland founded the Priory during the twelfth century. Canonbie's name means 'The Town of Canons', and the priory was a famous religious centre in the Scottish Borders during the medieval era. Lord Wharton may have destroyed the priory in 1542, after the Battle of Solway Moss..

Tower of Kilmun Collegiate Church, Argyllshire. This drawing dates from August 1802, but is unsigned. The drawing depicts the square tower at Kilmun, which is the only remaining part of a collegiate church founded in 1442 by Sir Duncan Campbell of Lochawe, Chief of the Clan Campbell and ancestor of the Dukes of Argyll. The body of water in the background is the Holy Loch. Collegiate churches in Scotland were largely a phenomenon of the fifteenth century. Usually they sit on the sites of existing churches that had been under the patronage of a particular family or individual. Although the collegiate churches were places of Christian learning for a 'college' of clergy, they were also dedicated to holding masses and prayers for the salvation of their patrons' souls..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Three decorative slabs from Saddell Abbey, Argyllshire.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

The title under these pencil sketches reads, 'Part of a Cross at Sadael Abbey'. The note goes on to clarify the fragments, position to the north-east of the church. The three sketches incorporate armour, ships and decorative motifs. Latin script is also in evidence around the frame of the slivers. The stones at Saddell are a treasure-trove of early Scottish artistry and hold much social and political information in their symbolism. We now believe that there was a school of carving based here, who were responsible for many of these stones. There is only one cross-stone represented amongst the stones, details of which you can see here. The Romano-Celtic interlacing especially demonstrates the intermingling of Irish, Norse and Southern cultures, prevalent in west Scotland at this time.

Three features from Pluscarden Priory, Moray. Part of the writing above these pencil sketches reads, 'From a drawing in Captain Grose's possession'. As indicated, this is a copy of an original drawing although there are no artists' names or original dates attached to the sheet. Of the three drawings, two are of human figures and the third is a sun, moon and stars motif. King Alexander II founded Pluscarden Priory in 1230, as a house of the Valliscaulian Order. That same year, lay-lords established two other Valliscaulian houses at Ardchattan and Beauly..

A note beneath the drawings reads, ' Three stones are represented here, each of which has been given a number relating to a plan of the priory'. The plan is not contained in the Hutton Collection. Another note at the bottom of the drawing suggests that the stones are not in their original location. Founded in the thirteenth century by Duncan MacDougall, Ardchattan Priory was home to members of the Valliscaulian Order: other Valliscaulian houses were Beauly and Pluscarden. Monks remained at Ardchattan until the mid-sixteenth century, after which the priory and its grounds belonged to the Campbell family..

A note reveals the location of the second stone and the information it relates about the death of the Prior around 1500. This stone has Latin script and a beautiful decorative panel. The first stone on the sheet is a representation of a mail-clad warrior. Early medieval carved stones are common in the western Scottish landscape and were a popular method of denoting power and status. There were four or five master schools of carving dotted around the west of Scotland; examples from the school at Saddell are also in the Hutton Collection. Decorative motifs, displaying Celtic, Norse and Romanesque influences, life-size warrior representations, armour and ships are all popular as themes for carvings..

The abbey stood in a copse of trees to the east of Saddell village and is framed by Saddell Water. This Cistercian house was founded in 1148 as part of the power politics of Somerled, Lord of the Isles' reign..

rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827

This picture, of windows and an inscribed arch in Cullen Collegiate Church, Banffshire, is undated and unsigned. A transcription of the text on the inscribed arch, probably made by Hutton, is included in a note above the title. The words appear to be in Scots. The exact meaning of the inscription is hard to decipher, but may refer to a croft of 35 acres, and someone who is a good singer of holy songs. It advises the reader to pray for Ellen Hay. This church, founded in 1543, was one of the last collegiate churches in Scotland. One of the primary functions of collegiate churches was to offer special prayers and masses for the souls of the founders of the church, and those close to them. Alexander Ogilvie of Deskford founded Cullen Collegiate Church, but Ellen Hay and John Hay, whose names appear on more than one inscription in the church, may have been associated in some way with Ogilvie or with the church, and might therefore have been among those prayed for by the college of resident clergy..

This drawing shows the exterior of the church and part of the surrounding area. Two figures are standing in front of the building. The Hutton Collection also includes two further drawings relating to Tongland, both of which detail early sculptured stones. The village of Tongland lies within the parish of the same name, in Dumfriesshire, and is near the River Dee, two miles north of Kirkcudbright. Interestingly, it erected a new parish church in 1813, approximately one year after this drawing. The drawing appears to be of the earlier church, the remains of which stand in the present-day kirkyard..

Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This drawing, dated 7th August 1815, shows a rural view of Kinloss Abbey. In the foreground, a rider allows his horse to graze beside a stone bridge, which arches gracefully over a small river. It also shows Nelson's Pillar near Forres. King David I of Scotland founded Kinloss Abbey in 1150. For 500 years, the monks of the Cistercian Order occupied it, until 1650 when Alexander Brodie systematically demolished it and sold the stone to Oliver Cromwell. Still regarded as an important part of their culture and history by the residents of Kinloss, they marked the 850th anniversary of the monastery's founding in 2001. Nelson's Tower, on the top of Cluny Hill, Forres, was built as a memorial to Vice-Admiral Horatio Nelson in 1806..

rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This drawing, dating from 1802, shows three armorial bearings located in the interior of Seton Collegiate Church, East Lothian. The artist has also provided descriptive notes detailing some of the key features of the church, including monumental arches and several coats of arms. Interestingly, it has been recorded that the west part of the church was never completed. A note under one of the armorial bearings suggests that it is 'Probably emblematic of the grief of the Lady Seton, whose Lord was slain at Flodden'. The fifth Lord Seton, whose family was responsible for the construction of Seton Collegiate Church in the late-fifteenth century, was indeed killed on the battlefield at Flodden in 1513..

There is no artist or date attached to this sheet of six drawings of individual features found in Crossraguel Abbey, Ayrshire but two other pencil sketches from this abbey date from 1813. The first three sketches at the top of the sheet depict human heads: the remaining three are of stylised animals. All of these carvings come from the tops of pillars. Duncan, Earl of Carrick established Crossraguel Abbey in 1216, as a Cluniac house, It now boasts some of the best preserved Cluniac architectural remains, with the Chapter House and Chapel especially standing almost intact..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Drawn ground-plan and north elevation of St Clement's Church, Harris, 1790.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

The upper drawing on this page is entitled 'Elevation', and shows the north side of the church. The height of the tower measures 60 feet and the length of the building from east to west, 83 feet. The lower drawing is entitled 'The ground Plan with the Tombs'. The measurements of individual walls, doors and windows are missing but, at the foot of the page, the artist has included a scale in feet 'from which the Dimensions and Proportions may be known'. These drawings are two of several relating to St Clement's Church in the Hutton Collection. The artist's identity is unknown. St Clement's Church dates from the late-fifteenth or early-sixteenth century, and is one of the oldest surviving cruciform churches in Scotland. It was only in use for a short period before the Reformation, after which it was derelict for long periods, and even served as a cow byre. Other restoration projects have happened since..

rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827

Drawn ground-plan of St Clement's Church, Harris, Inverness-shire. It dates from July 4th 1818, has the initials 'H.D'. As well as giving the measurements of the church's walls and floor space, the plan also notes the positioning of windows, monuments and the pulpit. This one of a number of drawings made of St Clement's Church that is contained in the Hutton Collection. St Clement's Church in Rodel, South Harris, may date from the fifteenth or early sixteenth century, and stands on the site of an earlier ecclesiastical building. It is one of the oldest cruciform churches in Scotland, and one of the grandest buildings in the Hebrides, but fell into disuse after the Reformation of 1560. The church, restored by Captain Alexander Macleod of Berneray in 1784, had again fallen into disrepair by the mid-nineteenth century and was in use as a cow byre. The Countess of Dunmore began the modern restoration of the building in 1873..

A plan of the route of a Roman road in Angus and Aberdeenshire, the artist was 'Joan' Jamieson and the date of the engraving 1785. A handwritten note at the top of the sheet reads 'Gough's Camden, Vol. 3 Pl. 30'. This gives the source of the plate as Richard Gough's 1789 translation of 'Britannia', written by the historian and antiquary William Camden and first published in 1586. The road shown here was probably the main Roman route north, although the artist's geography does not correspond with modern thinking on Roman Scotland. The camp of Battledykes was slightly north of Forfar, while 'Haerfauds' was probably Hallforest, near Kintore on the south bank of the River Don..

rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This detailed engraving shows Brechin Cathedral with its round tower. The surrounding shrubbery provides a natural frame for the Cathedral. This is one of several drawings of the Cathedral, with its round tower, that appear in the Hutton Collection. The engraving has neither date nor signature, although it is likely that the artist was Hutton himself. Originally a stand-alone building, the round tower was incorporated into the cathedral when the church was built during the thirteenth century. Built in an Irish style, Irish masons probably constructed the Pictish Round Tower in about 1150. The Cathedral's interior boasts some fine Pictish carvings and excellent stained-glass windows, while the ancient graveyard contains many of the victims who died in the terrible plague of the mid-seventeenth century..

Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This is an undated engraving of Dunglass Castle, Dunbartonshire. A note below the title, says the artist is a 'Mr Woodyer', and that he based the engraving on a drawing by 'Mr Sandby'. This is probably a reference to Paul Sandby (1731-1809). He was an English topographical draughtsman whose work remains highly collectable. Dunglass Castle stands on a craggy promontory overlooking the River Clyde, near its confluence with the Leven in Dunbartonshire; the original castle, of which little remains, dated from around 1380, and was owned by the Colquhoun family. A later castle, built on the same site, was, for a time, owned by the family of Margaret Macdonald, the artist wife of Glasgow architect Charles Rennie Mackintosh. Another Dunglass Castle also once existed in Scotland, near the hamlet of the same name in East Lothian, but disappeared around 1640..

rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827

This engraving, one of a pair in the Hutton Collection relating to the Hebridean island of Staffa, shows the approach to Fingal's Cave. While the other engraving records the strange volcanic patterns of the island's hexagonal rock formations in close-up, this engraving shows the front of Fingal's Cave, and the vertical basalt columns that dominate Staffa's profile. At the foot of the pillars are the hexagonal stones that form a path of natural, honeycomb-like stepping-stones into the cave's entrance. There is no date for this engraving and the artist is unknown. Fingals' Cave uncanny resemblance to a large cathedral would have appealed to Hutton, as he gathered artwork and writings relating to the history of Scotland's ecclesiastical buildings. Hutton was not the only early nineteenth century artist who was greatly inspired by the amazing rock formations on Staffa. In addition to the composer, Felix Mendelssohn, and the painter, William Turner, Sir Walter Scott also visited the island and used Fingal's Cave as an inspirational muse, as did the Romantic poets, Keats and Wordsworth. Fingal is a famous character from Celtic mythology..

This is another mounted engraving by J.B., the artist, and R. Scott, the engraver. There is no date. The image contains representations of contemporary islanders and island life. St Columba, fleeing political problems in Ireland, landed on Iona in 563 and established a monastic community. The island still has many historically significant buildings, many of which were monastic dwellings. The Hutton Collection features nine views of these monuments..

Hutton, George Henry, -1827

This engraving shows St Mary's Collegiate Church and the Nungate Bridge. The artist has also chosen to detail much of the surrounding area, and has included part of the town and two men fishing on the banks of the River Tyne. The artist's name and the date have not been included. Several other drawings of St Mary's also form part of the Hutton Collection, including one that has very possibly been copied from this engraving. Situated in the south-east of Haddington, St Mary's Collegiate Church stands on the west bank of the River Tyne. A medieval cruciform church, it was built in the fourteenth century - completed in the fifteenth - and is decorated with typical medieval stone carvings, including green men and scallops. Almost 100 years after completion, St Mary's suffered extensive damage during the Siege of Haddington (1548-9). Although partial restoration work was carried out in the decades that immediately followed, it was not until the 1970s that the building was fully restored..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Cave of Fingal, in Staffa one of the Hebridean islands.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This engraving shows the cathedral-like entrance and inner sanctum of Fingal's Cave, on the Hebridean island of Staffa. The archway entrance to Fingal's Cave has vertical columns of basalt, while inside the cave is luminous floor of water. The 'Pillar Island' was popular with artists, writers and musicians during the nineteenth century, and was the inspiration for Felix Mendelssohn's overture, 'The Hebrides', as well as some of William Turner's most famous paintings. There is no date for this engraving and the artist is unknown. The entrance to Fingal's Cave is composed of a network of hexagonal-shaped rocks - just like a honeycomb, formed during volcanic activity. These hexagonal rocks are very similar to stepping-stones, which is why the Giant's Causeway, near Coleraine in Northern Ireland, might be the other half of Fingal's Cave - hence Staffa's place in Celtic mythology..

There are two names contained inside the mounting frame of this engraving – ‘J.B., Esq, del.’, i.e. drew it, and ‘R. Scott, sculpt.’, i.e. engraved it. There is no date. This drawing illustrates the view to the south-west. The island of Iona, a long, relatively flat lying outcrop, is dominated by the now rebuilt, Iona Abbey. One of the few intact pieces of masonry seems to have been the bell tower. From the eight other images found in the Hutton Collection this feature always seems to have been the focal point of the island's skyline. There are at least three other monastic buildings still standing today which are associated with pre-Reformation religion on the island..

Exterior and interior annotated drawings of St Clement's Church, Harris, Inverness-shire. On the top half of this page is 'A View in Perspective from the North East side of St Clement's Church at Rowadill in Harris. Communicated by the Revd. Mr Macleod, March 1790'. The drawing on the bottom half of the page is entitled 'A Section of the South Side and both ends'. These are two of a number of drawings relating to St Clement's Church in the Hutton Collection. Both drawings on this page include annotations. In the top drawing, the features near the church are modern tombs, a monumental cross, and the churchyard gate. In the lower drawing, the annotations identify the monument of Alexander MacLeod of MacLeod and a tomb, which is 'said to be the Builder's tomb'. Alexander MacLeod commissioned the building of St Clement's Church. His tomb is dated 1528..

Formal ground-plan of Beauly Priory, Inverness-shire. A very faint note at the bottom of the plan reads 'Recd. from L .Col Marr, 9 July 1825'. The creator of the plan is not noted, but it was clearly someone with some formal training as a draughtsman. This is one of a number of drawings and sketches from Beauly contained in the Hutton Collection. The note beneath the title reads, 'On the South side of the church between the West end and the front door to the east appear the vestiges of a building which had been attached to the wall of the church. It had probably been only a small dwelling house erected there after the destruction of the priory. All the buttresses have fallen from the walls. Their situations are dotted. The South Aisle said to have been the Burial Place of the Family of Bain of Tulloch'. Other notes on the plan describe the locations of windows and monuments in the priory, and the dimensions of the building..

rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hay, William, draftsman
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This formal ground-plan of St Mary's Church, Banff, Banffshire, is one of four views of this church contained in the Hutton Collection. The sheet is not dated, but the artist, from the name in the bottom right corner, appears to have been William Hay. The plan has a very professional appearance, and it seems likely that Hay had some formal training as a draughtsman. St Mary's Church in Banff dates from 1471 and was simple in form. The main church was a rectangle, with a short aisle and an entrance porch extending from the south wall. The details of Hay's plan are quite sparse, and do not include the locations of windows, pulpit or choir. However, he does mark the existence of three monuments within the church. These are in memory of Sir Walter Ogilvy, the Rev. Alexander Seaton, and Provost Baird..

Inscription from a tomb in Lincluden Collegiate Church. This sketch shows the simple outline of a monument located in Lincluden Collegiate Church, near Dumfries. The artist has transcribed the inscription that appears on the tomb and has provided useful notes: 'Lincluden 5 July 1807. At the East end, on the right of the great window, is an angel with an inscription, but the little that remains of it is not now legible. Prof. Stuart thinks the letters at the top are probably contractions for [...]'.. '. The words indicate that the tomb is that of Margaret, wife of Archibald, 4th Earl of Douglas, and daughter of King Robert III. Her husband, Archibald may have added the chancel, in which Margaret's tomb is located. Archibald the Grim, 3rd Earl of Douglas, Margaret's father-in-law, founded the Church in 1389. He chose to build it on a site previously occupied by a Benedictine nunnery..

Inscription from Alexander MacLeod's tomb, St Clement's Church, Harris, Inverness-shire. This inscription comes from the tomb of Alexander MacLeod, which is located in the south-eastern part of St Clement's Church, Rodel, Harris. William Daniell, who also sketched the tomb itself, transcribed it in 1818, Daniell's two drawings of the monument, and the transcription seen here, are contained in the Hutton Collection, along with a number of other drawings and plans relating to St Clement's Church. William Daniell's drawings of Alexander MacLeod's tomb beautifully illustrate the impressive biblical carvings that adorn it. A ship, a castle and a hunting scene are on the stone and the effigy of a medieval knight protects MacLeod’s stone coffin. Alexander MacLeod of Dunvegan and Harris is believed to have built St Clement's in the late-fifteenth or early-sixteenth century on the site of a much earlier church..

Inscription from monument, St Clement's Church, Harris, Western Isles. This inscription comes from a funerary monument located in the south aisle of St Clement's Church, Rodel, Harris. William Daniell, who also sketched the tomb itself, transcribed it, in 1818. Both the drawing of the monument and the transcription are contained in the Hutton Collection, along with a number of other drawings and plans relating to St Clement's Church. It is believed that Alexander MacLeod of Dunvegan and Harris built St Clement's in the late-fifteenth or early-sixteenth century on the site of a much earlier church. The funerary monument that this inscription appears on possibly belongs to William MacLeod, Alexander's son. William succeeded as clan leader following his father's death, and both men have graves in the church. Alexander's tomb in particular has exquisite examples of medieval sculpture..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Priory Church of Beaulieu in Rosshire - drawn from the East end looking West. Aug 1815.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

Interior view of Beauly Priory, Ross-shire [Subtitle:]. The title of this drawing reads, 'The Priory Church of Beaulieu in Rosshire - drawn from the East end looking West. Aug 1815'. It shows the interior of the ruined priory at Beauly, with a solitary figure seated on a central stone slab. The artist has included notes beneath the drawing detailing some of the deterioration. Also contained in the Hutton Collection are exterior views of the south, south-west and north-east. John Bisset founded Beauly Priory in 1230 as a house for the Valliscaulian Order. It was one of three houses established in Scotland by the order at this time; the others were located at Pluscarden and Ardchattan. Beauly Priory remained a Valliscaulian house until the early-sixteenth century, at which time it changed its allegiance to the Cistercian Order. Whilst parts of the complex lie in ruins or have disappeared over the years, the MacKenzies rebuilt the north transept in 1901 to serve as a mausoleum for the family..

rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827

rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This is a page of a letter from M Green to Mr Urban incorporating a sketch of Iona Abbey. The sketch says it is by 'Lilliman, Oct. 1761'. The letter discusses the illustrations in certain volumes of books and the lack of a schoolmaster on Iona. The whole is an extract from the 'Gentleman's Magazine' published in July 1793 (Volume 1 xiii). This sketch was to be an illustration in one of these volumes. This illustration is one of nine views of Iona contained in the Hutton Collection. This view of Iona is a little more unusual as it is contained on an extracted letter. The other views are mainly copies of whole paintings and drawings. The views cover a wide date range - about 75 years - and illustrate many of the island's religious features..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Eye draught of Kirkcudbright and parts adjacent.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Cocking, Thomas, active approximately 1783-1791
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This map is dated 1790 and was drawn by Thomas Cocking. Cocking assisted Captain Francis Grose (1731-91), whose illustrations feature significantly in the Hutton Collection. This is the only image relating specifically to the town of Kirkcudbright in the collection, although there are others relating to separate sites in Kirkcudbrightshire. Although Cocking's map dates from 1790, it shows that Kirkcudbright had not grown much beyond the medieval town centre that existed in the twelfth and thirteenth centuries. The street running from east to west is 'High Street', and the street that runs north from the west end of the High Street is Castle Street. This leads to the castle and parish church, which are both annotated on the map. The page also includes a larger-scale plan of Castledykes Hill, which stands west of the town overlooking the River Dee..

rdf:Description.dc:title: North-east view of Beauly Priory, Ross-shire.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This light pencil sketch shows the north-east view of Beauly Priory. It dates from 25th August 1815 and includes a note of the location underneath the drawing. Interestingly, the artist has used the French spelling of Beauly, 'Beau Lieu'. Much of the surrounding area has also been sketched, including fields, trees, and a number of people who appear to be watching sailing vessels on Beauly River. The Hutton Collection also includes drawings of the south view and south-west view. It has been suggested that the name Beauly originates from the French 'beau lieu', meaning 'beautiful place'. During a visit to the priory in 1564, Mary, Queen of Scots is purported to have admired the area and described it as the 'beau lieu'. However, the name could date from an even earlier time. When Valliscaulian monks arrived in the 1230s, they liked what they saw so much that they described it as 'Prioratus de Bello Loco' or 'Priory of the Lovely Spot'!.

Note describing the bells from Holywood Abbey, Dumfriesshire. This short descriptive note relates to two drawings of church bells, which are also included in the Hutton Collection. The two bells, taken from the ruins of Holywood Abbey, near Dumfries, are now in the village's parish church. Although the identity of the writer is unknown, this note says '1811'. The note reads: 'The bell is 19 inches high and measures round the mouth 54 inches, and round the inscription 31 ½ inches. The above are the dimensions of the bell which has the inscription, the other bell being one inch higher & one inch wider round'. Built in the English Gothic style, monks of the Premonstratensian Order probably founded Holywood Abbey around 1180. Sadly, only a few ruins now remain..

rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827

rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This fragment of writing, on Kilmartin, Argyllshire, may once have been a description of now missing picture. The note, which appears to be in Hutton's handwriting, reads 'Mr Daniell informed me that several years ago (probably about 25) a great many coins were found in the excavation in the centre of the druidical circle, which were afterwards distributed among many various hands'. The note dates from May 30th 1818. 'Mr Daniell' is a reference to William Daniell, an artist responsible for several drawings in the Hutton Collection. Kilmartin, in Kilmartin Glen, Argyllshire, lies among some of the earliest known human settlements in Scotland. There are around 350 ancient sites, 150 of which are prehistoric, within six miles of the village. The stone circle referred to in this fragment of text is probably Templewood stone circle..

These two notes are by George Henry Hutton. It is not clear whether he intended to publish his collection of drawings and plans, but these notes show the detail into which he went in his academic research. In the first note, which begins 'This View shows the ruins of the Abbots' House', he examines the structure of the buildings of Kinloss Abbey and speculates as to how it might have looked. He is also interested in piecing together the original structure, which the last Abbot dismantled..

Although clearly labelled a 'bird's eye view' the rest of the title of this pencil sketch has been smudged and obscured. The sheet, however, depicts a carved slab with warrior and ecclesiastical representations as well as animals and decorative motifs. This sheet is one of series that records many of the ornamental slabs at Saddell Abbey. There is no further information recorded with any of these sheets. Although Saddell Abbey began in 1148 as an ecclesiastical house of the Order of the Cistercians, its patron was the powerful secular lord, Somerled. Much of the information preserved there reveals details of the social life and politics of the day. The warrior class was a powerful element in early medieval society and monuments such as this record many of their attributes, skills and achievements..

This drawing shows a monument in the burial ground at Arbroath Abbey. The top depicts a hands-clasped figure with the date of 1633 located above the form's head. The measurements for this monument are included at the top and left-hand side of the sketch. Below the drawing is a caption explaining the monument's exact location in the abbey grounds, plus a short biographical note mentioning the monk that the tomb commemorates. This drawing dates from 1816..

rdf:Description.dc:title: No 1. Inscription on the Monument of an Ecclesiatic at Sadael Abbey in Cantyre, 17 Aug 1802.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

The title on this pencil rubbing reads, 'no 1. Inscription on the Monument of an Ecclesiastic at Sadael Abbey in Cantyre, 17 Aug 1802'. It is difficult to decipher the inscription from this rubbing. It is from one of the many carved stones located in the ruins of Saddell Abbey, which lies on the eastern edge of the Kintyre peninsula. There are two further rubbings of stones at Saddell contained in the Hutton Collection. A number of the carved stones at Saddell commemorate the patrons of the abbey and its early churchmen. They were originally grave slabs. Finely carved, they offer a rich pictorial history of a time when Somerled, Lord of the Isles - who founded the abbey around 1131 - and his descendants were at the height of their powers..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Pencil rubbing of an inscription, from Saddell Abbey, Argyllshire from the Hutton Collection.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This is one of three pencil rubbings taken from one of the many carved stones located in the ruins of Saddell Abbey, Argyllshire. The note in the bottom left-hand corner reads, 'no 2. Inscription on the Monument of an Ecclesiastic at Sadael Abbey in Cantyre, 17 Aug 1802'. It is difficult to decipher the inscription from this rubbing. Originally, people thought the carved stones at Saddell were the work of craftsmen from the large school of carving on Iona. However, we now think that between the fourteenth and fifteenth centuries there were actually four or five workshops in the region, one of which was located at Saddell Abbey. The twelve stones that are in the grounds of the abbey today include six grave covers and five effigies..

Pencil rubbing of an inscription, taken from a monument in Saddell Abbey, Argyllshire. This is one of three pencil rubbings taken from one of the many carved stones located in the ruins of Saddell Abbey, Argyllshire. The note in the bottom right-hand corner reads, 'Inscription upon the Monument of an Ecclesiastic at Sadael Abbey in Argyllshire - 1802. The inscription occupies five lines'. It is impossible to decipher the inscription from this rubbing. Saddell Abbey is located on the eastern coastline of the Kintyre peninsula, Argyllshire, near where the Saddell Water meets the Kilbrannan Sound. Its quiet and isolated location proved ideal for the Cistercian monks who lived there following its foundation by Somerled, Lord of the Isles, in the early-twelfth century..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Remains of the Old Church of Abbey Saint Bathans.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Morton, Alexander, of Dunfermline, active 1813-1817
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

The signature indicates that Alexander Morton in Dunfermline drew this plan in December 1816. Morton's note beneath the title reads, 'the green is old and the red is modern building'. Morton has measured the church, marked as the ‘place of worship’, at 32 feet in length and 19 in breadth. The 'old' walls referred to by Morton in his note, coloured green in the plan, may indicate parts of the church of Abbey St Bathans that were originally part of the Cistercian nunnery of St Mary, founded in 1170 by Ada, Countess of Dunbar or March. Henry VIII's troops burnt the nunnery in 1544. The church later appeared on the same site, incorporating some of the remains..

Plan of Beauly Priory, Ross-shire. The note under the title clarifies the dimensions given - they are all in paces, which equal 2 feet 3 inches. This plan looks initially complex but actual carries quite a lot of descriptive and architectural detail. The priory itself is of a standard cruciform layout, which lies east to west. Beauly Priory is one of three Valliscaulian houses founded in Scotland, from the area of Burgundy in France. This and Ardchattan Priory were the only two which were founded by lay-men however, the other, Pluscarden, enjoyed the royal patronage of Alexander I. The Hutton Collection includes twelve images of Beauly in total, but this floor-plan is a most useful visualisation and architectural aid..

rdf:Description.dc:creator: Watson, William, Rev.
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This drawing shows the plan of Biggar Collegiate Church, which is located in Lanarkshire. A note at the top of the page, immediately after the title, states that the plan was 'communicated by the Rev W. Watson February 7. 1790'. In this note, Hutton would have been referring to William Watson. In this plan, there are no dimensions and no scale to indicate size. Malcolm, Lord Fleming, the Lord High Chancellor of Scotland, founded and endowed Biggar Collegiate Church in 1545. Although work on the building started in 1545, however, it is likely that it replaced an earlier building. He dedicated the Church to the Holy Trinity, the Blessed Virgin Mary, St Nicholas the patron of Biggar, and St Ninian. As Malcolm, Lord Fleming, died during its early construction, his son carried on the building work, until the Reformation interrupted the work..

rdf:Description.dc:creator: Morton, Alexander, of Dunfermline, active 1813-1817
Hutton, George Henry, -1827

This drawing, made by Alexander Morton in 1816, shows a plan of Coldingham Priory. There is a numbered list of the rooms and areas in the plan. These numbered areas all contain measurements to indicate room size, while a scale at the bottom of the plan indicates the overall mass of the building. It was Edgar, King of Scots, who most likely established the church at Coldingham in 1098. The church soon developed into a priory, and the monks of St Cuthbert from Durham, in Northumbria, set up their most northerly settlement here. Destroyed during the Scottish Reformation, the area is now part of a nature reserve - St Abb's Head - owned by the National Trust for Scotland..

Hutton, George Henry, -1827

This plan was drawn by Alexander Morton in 1817, and shows Dirleton Collegiate Church. Morton has included a compass and scale, along with individual measurements. Much of the writing on the plan is extremely faint and almost illegible. Little appears to be known about Alexander Morton. Although it is impossible to say with absolute certainty, it seems likely that Morton lived in Dunfermline: he often wrote the name Dunfermline and the date alongside his signature. The Hutton Collection includes several plans executed by him, including those of St Mary's Priory and St Andrew's Church in North Berwick, Dunbar Collegiate Church and Gullane Church..

This plan was drawn by Alexander Morton in 1816, and shows Seton Collegiate Church. Morton has included a compass and scale, along with individual measurements and numerical key highlighting significant areas of the interior. Some of the writing on the plan is extremely faint and almost illegible. Morton's drawing is one of two plans of Seton Collegiate Church that can be found in the Hutton Collection: the other is anonymous and dated 1802. Whether Hutton commissioned plans from Morton is unclear, but the collection does include a large number of his plans, most of which appear to have been drawn up in the 1810s..

A watercolour of the main west door to Arbroath Abbey, Angus, this painting shows the portcullises, west entrance door of Arbroath Abbey and is dated '19 June 1790'. Abberbrothick (or Aberbrothock) is the original name of Arbroath. During the abbey's heyday, a great circular stained glass window – with a diameter of 28 feet - was located above this entrance door. Sadly, the four entrance towers are now little more than ruins..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Window in the Fransciscan Church, Aberdeen, now the church of the Marischal College.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This sketch has been 'communicated by Prof. Stuart, 1790'. Other notes on the sketch read 'Long free stone pillar jointed, & reaching from the top to bottom, about 6 inches wide' and at the bottom, 'about 15 feet in width & 24 high'. A pencil note from a later date reads 'See the drawings by Mr J. Logan, 1819'. Logan was responsible for many drawings of Aberdeen in the Hutton Collection. Marsichal College, on the site of a Franciscan Friary founded in 1593, was originally a Protestant alternative to King's College in Old Aberdeen. The two colleges united to form the University of Aberdeen in 1860. The modern façade of the building was mostly constructed in the 1890s, but the window shown in this sketch appears to have been part of a church incorporated into the college on its sixteenth-century foundation..

rdf:Description.dc:creator: Grimm, Samuel Hieronymus, 1733-1794
Hutton, George Henry, -1827

rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This is a sketch of a chapel in Udny, Aberdeenshire 'by Mr Grimm'. It shows what seems to be the front wall and entrance of a ruined chapel. Two people are sitting on the grass outside the chapel, looking towards a ruined castle on a hill in the distance. The sketch is not dated. Udny is a hamlet in Aberdeenshire, located about nine kilometres west of the town of Ellon. The chapel and castle of Udny were the earliest known buildings in the settlement, the castle dating from the fifteenth century. The castle depicted in this sketch may be Udny Castle, but it is more likely to be Tolquhoun Castle, a larger castle built nearby for the Forbes family in the fifteenth and sixteenth centuries..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Deer Abbey 1815.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This annotated sketched ground plan of Deer Abbey, Aberdeenshire is one of several images relating to Deer Abbey in the Hutton Collection. As no artist’s name is given, it is likely that this is one of Hutton's own drawings. The extensive annotations do not only refer to the layout and contents of the abbey, but also describe some of the surrounding geography. The ruins of Deer Abbey lie approximately ten miles west of Peterhead, in the heart of the Buchan region of Aberdeenshire. St Columba reputedly founded an abbey here in the sixth century. All that remains of this original abbey is the 'Book of Deer', a manuscript dating from the ninth to the twelfth centuries, which includes the earliest surviving Scots Gaelic writing. The later Deer Abbey, for three Cistercian monks from Kinloss in Morayshire, dates from 1218..

rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Logan, J., of Aberdeen, active 1819-1820

The artist, of this drawing of St Machar's, is ‘J. Logan’ and the date is 1820. The printed notes beneath the title read: 'The arch is 6 feet 5 inch in span, 5 feet 8 inch from the floor to the top, 2 feet 8 from Dº to the spring of the arch'. This drawing gives no clue as to the significance of the monument shown. It may be one of several tombs within the cathedral. These include the burial places of the Roman Catholic Bishop of Aberdeen, Gavin Dunbar (d.1532), and the Scottish Episcopalian Bishop of Aberdeen, Patrick Forbes (d.1635)..

rdf:Description.dc:title: In the West Church of Aberdeen.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

The drawing depicts a monument or memorial stone with Latin inscriptions on it, one of which appears to be the date 22nd January 1593. The monument also carries what appears to be an engraved shield, with the letters 'E' and 'L' on either side of it. A note beneath the drawing records the size of the monument as '1 foot 11 in by 1 foot 7½'. Aberdeen's West Church and East Church were both part of the same building, the Parish Church of St Nicholas. St Nicholas' was founded in the twelfth century, but was divided into two congregations, the 'Auld' and 'New' kirks, after the Reformation of 1560. The West Church was built to replace the Auld Kirk wing between 1751 and 1755, with the East Church replacing the New Kirk in 1835. The date on the monument shown here suggests, however, that this is a relic from the Auld Kirk..

This drawing, of a pulpit, frontal view, in St Machar's Cathedral, Aberdeen, is signed 'J. Logan of Aberdeen', and dated 1819. It is one of several drawings by Logan of interior details from St Machar's contained in the Hutton Collection. This is probably a drawing of Bishop Stewart's (William Stewart, ca. 1490-1545) pulpit, made for St Machar's Cathedral in the 1530s. A note beneath the title of this drawing gives the dimensions of the pulpit: 'The Height of the front of the Pulpit form the base of the pannels is 4 feet including the cornice which is 7 inches. The height from the base of the pannels to the sound board is 5 feet 5 inches. The sound board & Pulpit project 4 feet and are 4 feet 4 inches in breadth'.

This is a drawing of a standing stone at Monymusk, Aberdeenshire. A handwritten note under the title reads, '7/4 high, 2/6 broad, drawn by Mr Jas Logan from a sketch by his brother Mr John Logan in 1819. - Mr L says it stood originally in a field, he thinks 4 or 500 yards North East from the church, but it has been removed a short distance from its original situation. It appears in a little publication, entitled "Don, a Poem". The tradition is that it was erected in memory of a Sir John Aikenwall (see the other side)..

rdf:Description.dc:title: In the Cathedral of Old Aberdeen.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

The drawing, which is not dated, and unsigned by the artist, depicts a tombstone in St Machar's Cathedral, Aberdeen. Beneath the drawing there is a note giving the dimensions of the tombstone as ' 3 feet 1, by 2 feet 10'. The inscription on this tombstone is in Scots rather than in Latin. The portion of text along the top and down the right hand side of the tombstone appears to read, 'Heir • lyis • ane • honorabil • Man • hendry • Murray'. The text along the bottom of the stone is obscured, but on the left hand side it reads 'RV • of • Martyr • 1582 • A • M • 1638'. It is likely that Hendry Murray was a martyr to one of the religious denominations that warred intermittently in Scotland in the sixteenth and seventeenth centuries. Protestants and Catholics fought and suffered for years either side of the Reformation of 1560, and the major wings of the Protestants, the Presbyterians and Episcopalians, were in conflict over control of the church. The inscription does not specify Hendry Murray's sympathies..

This drawing shows part of a tombstone, which is inscribed with an epitaph and also seems to carry an inscription of a family shield. Beneath the drawing a note records the dimensions of the tombstone as '4 feet by 2 feet 10 inches'. This tomb may be the burial place for several generations of the same family. The inscription running around the outside of the tombstone, where it is legible, appears to be in Latin. and is dated 1531. The inscription in the middle of the stone is in Scots and reads: 'AS · ALSO · ALEXANDE · HOUISON LATE DEAN OF GILD OF ABD WHO DEPARTED THE 28 DAY OF APRILL 1687 & OF AGE 76'..

rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827

rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This drawing is signed, ‘J. Logan, Abdn. 1819’. It does not tell us the effigy's precise location in Aberdeen. The Battle of Harlaw, fought between the followers of Donald, Lord of the Isles, and Crown troops led by the Earl of Mar, took place at Harlaw, twenty miles north-west of Aberdeen, on the 24th of July 1411. Donald's soldiers ultimately retreated, but the Crown forces lost around five hundred men, one of whom was Sir Robert Davidson..

Inscribed buttress in St Machar's Cathedral, Aberdeen. The artist is given as J. Logan and the drawing is dated 1819. This is one of a number of drawings by Logan of the interior of St Machar's Cathedral, which are contained in the Hutton Collection. The notes beneath the title of the drawing read: 'The Projection of the Buttress is 4 feet 8 inches. The stone on which the inscription is, being 2 feet 1 inch, by 1 foot 2 inches.’ A scale inserted along the bottom of the drawing illustrates this. The Latin inscription on the buttress looks faded and is difficult to decipher, although the date '1530' seems to appear directly beneath it..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Inscription on a stone ... near Newton, Aberdeenshire.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Irvine, H.
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

On the left-hand side of this sheet is a detailed drawing of a standing stone and, at the top of the sheet, the artist has included magnified versions of the runic inscriptions on the stone. A note to the left of the drawing reads, 'Inscription on a stone 6½ feet high (Granite) near Newton, Aberdeenshire. The marks on the edge are notches there being no other ornament. The dotted lines in the plate indicate uncertainty of the forms. H. Irvine. 1821'. The place the artist describes as 'Newton' is probably the farming area near Huntly now known as Logie Newton, where there is a standing stone believed to date from Neolithic times. At the bottom of the sheet there is a handwritten note by Hutton describing how the drawing came into his possession: 'Presented to me this day, 7th April 1821, by my worthy friend Prof. Stuart (Mar. Col. Aberd.), who received it from Mr Irvine the ingenious artist'..

rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This sketch, of an inscribed stone at St Machar's Cathedral, Aberdeen, is very faint, but appears to comprise the outline of a stone, and a few words inscribed on it. Its faintness makes it quite difficult to decipher the inscription, but the apparent presence of the words 'of' and 'fra', meaning 'from', suggest that it may be in Scots rather than Latin. It was rare to use Scots in inscriptions or monuments in ecclesiastical buildings prior to the reformation of 1560 and it may be that the inscription dates from later than this..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Bishop Lichton's monument.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Logan, J., of Aberdeen, active 1819-1820
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This is one of several detailed drawings from St Machar's made by J. Logan and contained in the Hutton Collection, and is dated 1819. Today, Bishop Leighton’s monument stands near the north-west corner of the main body of the cathedral, but it has occupied several different locations in the past. A note under the title gives the dimensions of the monument: 'The Length of the Tomb is 8 feet; the depth is 2 feet 7 inches, the height of the arch, from the slab on which the figure reclines 3 feet 1 inch. The height from the ground is 2 feet 2 inches, including the slab, the thickness of which is 6 inches. The stone, which bears the inscription, is 5 feet 11inches long, and 1 foot 3 inches broad. The small stone is 2 feet 4 inches in length, and 11 inches in breath at the bottom. It formerly lay in Bishop Dunbar's aisle'..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Cape stones on the garden wall of Inverugie Castle.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Cheney family
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This is a drawing of stones from Inverugie Castle, Aberdeenshire. The artist’s name is missing, although it is likely to have been Hutton himself. The drawing says’9th November 1809’. A note below the title gives more information about the capstones pictured: 'The letters GB and date 1670 appear to have been done at a much later period than the sculptured coach, which is probably three or four hundred years old'. Inverugie Castle lies a few miles north of Peterhead in the county of Buchan. Most of the existing castle dates from the fifteenth century, but there are remnants of the medieval castle that passed into the ownership of Sir John de Keith in 1380. The capstones featured in this drawing would have provided a decorative finish to the castle walls..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Ceiling of the east end of St Nicholas Church, Aberdeen.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Logan, J., of Aberdeen, active 1819-1820
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This drawing, of the ceiling of the apse, east end of the church of St Nicholas, Aberdeen, is not dated. The parish church of St Nicholas divided into two congregations, the 'Auld' and 'New' Kirks, after the Reformation of 1560. The New Kirk was located in the east end of the building, and this part of the building rebuilt in 1835, eighty years after the replacement of the west wing of the church. Logan's drawings for Hutton date mainly from the period 1819-20. This means that the ceiling shown here was probably part of the old east wing of St Nicholas's Kirk. It is most likely a depiction of a decorative ceiling, installed in the church in 1495, based on styles from the Low Countries. Another similar ceiling was built a few years later in King's College chapel in Old Aberdeen..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Chapel of St Mary Magdalen beneath the east end of St Nicholas Aberdeen, from the south-west corner.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Logan, J., of Aberdeen, active 1819-1820
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This drawing is dated 1820 and signed by J. Logan. The Chapel of St Mary Magdalene, or St Mary's Chapel, was built by Lady Elizabeth Gordon (d. 1438), whose remains were buried within the chapel after her death. It is one of the few parts of the medieval kirk of St Nicholas to have survived the Reformation of 1560 and many later alterations. It is one of the earliest buildings in Aberdeen constructed from granite; during the medieval period most stone buildings used sandstone..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Deer Abbey, south View.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

This sketch was made in July 1819 by an unknown artist. It shows the south view of the ruins of thirteenth-century Deer Abbey, near Old Deer in Aberdeenshire. It has a companion in the Hutton Collection. There is an earlier, 1796, watercolour by the same artist, of the same view. William Comyn, Earl of Buchan, founded deer Abbey in 1218. Monks, who were members of the Cistercian Order, occupied it until the seventeenth century when they abandoned it and it fell into disrepair..

rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

A note, underneath the title of this south-east aspect of Bishop Dunbar's Hospital, Aberdeen, explains: 'from a drawing in the prospection of Prof Ogilvie, King's Col. which he caused to be made previous to the taking down the building, a few years ago, 1796.’ This is one of a number of drawings of ecclesiastical and historic sites in Aberdeen contained in the Hutton Collection. Bishop Dunbar's Hospital in Old Aberdeen was demolished in the eighteenth century..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Lintel of Bishop Dunbar's Hospital.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Logan, J., of Aberdeen, active 1819-1820
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

These are drawings of stone fragments from St Machar's Cathedral and Bishop Dunbar's Hospital, Aberdeen. This sheet contains two drawings; both credited to 'J.L.A.' and dated 1820. The one to the right is captioned 'Lintel of Bishop Dunbar's Hospital'. The other, to the left, is captioned 'Fragment in the Cathedral Churchyard of Old Aberdeen. The length is 2 feet 7½ and the width is 9½ inches. The signature ‘J.L.A.’ probably stands for 'J. Logan, Aberdeen'. There are a number of drawings by Logan in the Hutton Collection. As well as founding Bishop Dunbar's Hospital, Gavin Dunbar, Bishop of Aberdeen from 1518-32, was instrumental in the development of St Machar's Cathedral. He erected the stone spires that remain to this day, and was responsible for the creation of the cathedral's heraldic ceiling..

rdf:Description.dc:title: Plan of the pulpit.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Hutton, George Henry, -1827
Logan, J., of Aberdeen, active 1819-1820
rdf:Description.dc:description: Metadata context: metadata created as part of normal Library activities. Metadata created specifically for digitisation project.

The artist has signed himself as J. Logan, but has not dated the plan, of a pulpit in St Machar's Cathedral, Aberdeen. This is one of several detailed drawings from inside St Machar's, made by Logan and contained in the Hutton Collection. The plan illustrates the irregular seven-sided design of the pulpit, noting the measurements of each side and the breadth across the pulpit between two of its corners, The pulpit described by this plan was probably Bishop Stewart's pulpit. Built for St Machar's Cathedral, in the 1530s, it shows the transition between gothic and renaissance styles of design. The pulpit was rebuilt and erected in King's College Chapel, Aberdeen University, in 1844, after being discovered in a lumber room in St Machar's..
